name: Aleksić von Maina Jovan (1783-1861)
entity_description: Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861) was an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman of Serbian origin. Aleksić was born in Kotor (today Montenegro, in Italian Cattaro) in a noble family, whose ancestors had moved from the Montenegrin mountains to the Boka Kotorska in 1621. The family of Aleksić von Maina bore five captains, two majors, two colonels and two generals. They served in the armed forces of Venice, France and Austria. Jovan's uncle Rade Maina was promoted to the rank of General in the Republic of the Venice in 1779. Jovan Aleksić von Maina was, following the service in the Venetian army, also in the French army under Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821). From 1815 he joined the Austrian army, where he was promoted to the rank of General in Sremska Mitrovica in 1835. He was awarded the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd grade. He was ennobled and elevated to knighthood (Ritterstand) in 1840. After his retirement in 1844, when he was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant, he moved to Vienna, where he stayed for the next eleven years. He lived at first (already before 1853) in Johannesgasse 969 (the so-called "Fleischhof", today Johannesgasse 1, 1010 Vienna).  His wife Marija Aleksić von Maina (born Klaić) died in this house on 21 December 1857 at the age of 54. She was buried on the St. Marx cemetery, then exhumated and transferred to Hietzing cemetery in 1899. Jovan Aleksić von Maina died on 19 February 1861 in the house No. 618 ("Trattnerhof", Graben 29-29a / Trattnerhof 1/2, 1010 Vienna) and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 22 February 1861.
location_description: Here lived and died Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman of Serbian origin Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861) on 19 February 1861. The building was demolished in 1911 and a new one was erected.

name: Leonhardi Elisabeth Baronin von (1828-1915)
entity_description: Baronin Elisabeth von Leonhardi (1828-1915), the sister of the Serbian General Major and nobleman Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908), was born on 28 July 1828 in Kulpin (today Serbia). She married Baron Franz von Leonhardi (1815-1883), an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant, on 18 September 1847 in Kulpin. They had a son, Theodor von Leonhardi (1856-1927), also a Field marshal-lieutenant, and a daughter, Marianne Ronay de Zombor (1868-1933). Elisabeth von Leonhardi died in Greisenasyl (today St. Carolusheim) in Gentzgasse 104 (1180 Vienna) at the age of 87 on 7 September 1915. She was buried in the family tomb in Bratislava four days later.
location_description: Baronin Elisabeth von Leonhardi (1828-1915) died here on 7 September 1915.

name: Milanković Uroš (1800-1849)
entity_description: Uroš Milanković (1800-1849) was born in Dalj (today Croatia) in 1800. He was the brother of Milutin Milanković's grandfather. Uroš Milanković studied Philosophy in Szeged (today Hungary) and later he studied Law at the University of Vienna. He worked for the duration of one year as a lawyer at the court in Vienna and later as a lawyer in the Military Frontier. He published several books in German and Serbian in Vienna, e.g. "Weltorganismus und System des gesammten Lebens: dargestellt in einzelnen Geschöpfen und in einzelnen Wirkungen, als allgemeine Thätigkeit der gesammten nichtsinnlichen, sinnlichen und geistigen Natur, in ihrem Zusammenhange mit der Kritik der Einheit über das Unvereinbare" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1843), "Organismus des Weltalls und System des gesammten Lebens, oder Polarsystem der physischen und geistigen Natur" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1845) and "Просвјета човека" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1847). After his retirement in 1835 he lived in Trieste and Vienna. Uroš Milanković died in Vienna in Stiegengasse 12 (1060 Vienna) on 27 December 1849 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/3359
location_description: Uroš Milanković died here on 27 December 1849 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). The building does not exist anymore.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Mihajlo (1841-1916)
entity_description: Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna (1841-1916) was a landowner and house owner in Vienna and the son of Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) and Jelisaveta-Savka Obrenović (1814-1848), the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). He was married to Gräfin Marianne Kinsky von Wchinitz und Tettau (1854-1938) from 1877 until 1880. An interesting episode occurred on 22 March 1876, when Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna paid a fine of 10 florins, because of driving too fast with his carriage through Kärntnerstraße (1010 Vienna). In February 1882 he bought the house in Hegelgasse 8 (1010 Vienna) for 410,000 florins. Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna was the owner of the building in Belvederegasse 6-8 (1040 Vienna) from 1896. He adopted Johann Thierfelder (1884-?) in 1905 and gave him the epithet "von Obrenow" as a reminiscence that the family of Nikolić was a descendant of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). He was also landowner in Banat with 4,630 acres. Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna died in Vienna in Sanatorium Löw on 21 November 1916.
location_name: House of Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna
location_description: This house was bought by Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna (1841-1916), a landowner and house owner, in Vienna.

name: Stanković Svetozar
entity_description: Svetozar Stanković was a Serbian merchant in Vienna. From 1856 to 1862 he was a business partner of Vasilije Nedeljković in the Company “Nedelkovits & Stankovits”. Its address was Lazzenhof 1 (1010 Vienna). From 1863 to 1864 he was the owner of the Company "S.A. Stankovits", but went bankrupt. Svetozar Stanković donated 300 florins and his wife Julijana Stanković (né Adamović) 100 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1862.
location_description:
Here was the seat of several companies:
"Bosanetz & Welicskovits" (1850-1866)
"Millicsevits Georg" (1869-1890)
 "Nedelkovits & Stankovits" (1856-1862)
The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1910.

name: Jovanović Nikola (1873-1957)
entity_description: Nikola Jovanović (1873-1957) was born in Podravska Slatina (today Croatia) on 1 July 1873. He married Josefa Olga Berneher in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 18 June 1903. His address was Piaristengasse 7 (1080 Vienna). Marta Jovanović, the daughter of Nikola Jovanović, was born on 13 September 1903 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 4 October. His younger daughter Olga was born on 15 January 1906 and also baptised in the St. Sava Church on 25 January. Jovanović's Company in Vienna was founded in 1901 and still exists. Since its foundation until the end of the Second World War (1945) the shop was located in Piaristengasse 7 (1080 Vienna). Nikola Jovanović moved to the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in the 1930s and died in Zagreb on 20 September 1957. He was buried in Zagreb's Mirogoj Cemetery. Among more than one hundred shops of Serbian merchants in Vienna in the 19th and at the beginning of the 20th centuries the only one, which exists nowadays, is the Jovanović furrier shop. It is located since the end of the 1940s in Weihburggasse 3 and 9 (1010 Vienna) and is run by Jovanović's grandchildren.
location_description: Nikola Jovanović was a furrier, who founded his company in Vienna in 1901, which still exists. Since its foundation until the end of the Second World War (1945) the shop was located in Piaristengasse 7 (1080 Vienna). The building does not exist anymore. Among more than one hundred shops of Serbian merchants in Vienna in the 19th and at the beginning of 20th centuries, the only one, which exists nowadays, is the Jovanović furrier shop. It is located since the 1940s in Weihburggasse 3 and 9 (1010 Vienna) and is run by Jovanović's granddaughter.

name: Putnik Mojsije (1728-1790)
entity_description: Mojsije Putnik (1728-1790) was Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) from 1782 to his death in 1790. He had the title of Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat") and was also awarded the Order of Saint Stephen. He died in Kohlmarkt 144 (today Kohlmarkt 8, 1010 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore) on 9 July 1790.
location_name: Place of Death of Mojsije Putnik
location_description: Here died Mojsije Putnik (1728-1790), Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), on 9 July 1790. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Stanojević Stanoje (1874-1937)
entity_description: Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937) was a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade. He was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia) on 13 August 1874. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, Stanoje Stanojević studied History at the University of Vienna from 1892 to 1896. He lived in Neustiftgasse 97 (1080 Vienna). His professors at University were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). Stanoje Stanojević received his titel of Dr on 16 July 1896. His dissertation is entitled "Die Biographie Stefan Lazarević's von Konstantin dem Philosophen als Geschichtsquelle". From 1903 until his death in 1937 Stanoje Stanojević was Professor at the University of Belgrade. His main field of research was the Serbian medieval history. During the First World War (1914-1918) he was in exile and lectured as a visiting Professor at the Sorbonne in Paris and at London University. At the Paris Peace Conference in the years 1919 and 1920 he was a member of the Serbian delegation in the historical-ethnographic section. Stanoje Stanojević died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.
location_description: Here lived during his studies at the University of Vienna Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937), a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade, from 1892 to 1896.

name: Živković Pantelejmon (1795-1851)
entity_description: Pantelejmon Živković (1795-1851) was a Serbian Bishop of Dalmatia, Timișoara and Budapest. After attending grammar school and finishing the studies of Theology in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), he studied Law in Vienna. He was Bishop of Dalmatia from 1834 to 1836. After that he was named Bishop of Budapest. Finally, in 1839 Pantelejmon Živković was appointed as Bishop of Timișoara. He was honored by the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) with the distinction Knight Commander of the Order of Saint Stephen in 1848. He was also Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat"). Pantelejmon Živković died in Kleine Schulenstraße 850 (today Domgasse 9, 1010 Vienna) on 22 March 1851.
location_description: Here died the Serbian Bishop of Dalmatia, Timișoara and Budapest Pantelejmon Živković (1795-1851) on 22 March 1851. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Vladislav Jovan
entity_description: Jovan Vladislav was a Viennese canvas merchant, who worked in the beginning together with his uncle Gavrilo Vladislav in his company "G. Wladislaw". In 1851 he founded his own Company "Wladislaw's G. Neffe". Its address was Fleischmarkt 695 (Fleischmarkt 10, 1010 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore). The Company was deleted from the commercial register on 25 July 1866.  Jovan Vladislav was one of the main initiators for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. On 9 December 1860 this Community was founded in his apartment, and Jovan Vladislav was its first Vice President.
location_description: Here was the seat of the Company "Wladislaw's G. Neffe". Its owner was Jovan Vladislav, a canvas merchant and one of the main initiators for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. On 9 December 1860 this Community was founded in his apartment, and Jovan Vladislav was its first Vice President. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Ljubiša Dimitrije (1856-1900)
entity_description: Dimitrije Ritter von Ljubiša (1856-1900) was the son of Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša (1824-1878) and was born in Budva (today Montenegro) in 1856. He worked in Vienna as a civil servant. Olimpija Ljubiša was the daughter of Dimitrije Ljubiša. She was born on 30 March 1894 and was baptised in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 20 May 1894. The family lived in Pazmanitengasse 14 (1020 Vienna). Dimitrije Ljubiša's other daughter called Sofija was born on 30 September 1896 and was baptised in the St. Sava Church on 22 November. His sons Mirko Milan (born on 4 August 1898) and Gustav (born on 26 August 1900) were also baptised in the St. Sava Church on 30 August 1898  and on 23 September 1900 respectively. Dimitrije Ljubiša died in Ausstellungsstraße 25 (1020 Vienna) on 3 June 1900 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna). After his death his wife Rosalia was owner of a tobacconist in Sonnwendgasse 2 (1100 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša (1824-1878), Serbian politician and writer and Member of the Lower House of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna, on 23 November 1878.

name: Jovanović Zaharije (1810-1850)
entity_description: Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča, was one of the Serbian leaders in the war against the Hungarians in 1848/49 with the rank of Colonel. He arrived in Vienna in 1850 in order to get a pension, but he fell ill and died. Zaharije Jovanović died in the House No. 8 auf der Wieden (today Wiedner Hauptstraße 14, 1040 Vienna) on 18 November 1850 at the age of 40. He was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča; lithograph by Anastas Jovanović, 1851.
Muzej Grada Beograda, AJ 133.
location_description: Here died Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča,  Colonel of the Serbian troops, which were loyal to the Habsburg dynasty in the war against the Hungarians in 1848/49, on 18 November 1850 at the age of 40. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Milenković Stefan von (1785-1863)
entity_description: Stefan von Milenković (1785-1863) was a Serbian officer and nobleman, who was born in Požarevac (today Serbia). Due to his merits he was ennobled in 1849. After his retirement in 1848 Stefan von Milenković lived in Vienna, where he died on 18 March 1863 in his apartment in Alser Straße 19 (1080 Vienna) at the age of 78. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna) he was buried on 21 March in Schmelz Cemetery (Schmelzer Friedhof). He was the father of the writer and poet Stefan von Milenković (1836-1915) and the grandfather of Benno von Milenković (1869-1946) and Max von Milenković (1866-1945).
location_description: Here died the Serbian officer and nobleman Stefan von Milenković (1785-1863) on 18 March 1863 at the age of 78.

name: Stefanović Vilovski Angelina (1857-1879)
entity_description: Angelina Stefanović Vilovski (1857-1879) was the daughter of Major Jovan Stefanović Edler von Vilovo (1821-1902). She was born in Bratislava (today Slovakia) and died at the age of 22 in her family's apartment in Burggasse 24 (1070 Vienna) on 13 October 1879. Angelina Stefanović Vilovski was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_name: Apartment of the Family Stefanović von Vilovo
location_description: Here died Angelina Stefanović Vilovski (1857-1879), the daughter of Major Jovan Stefanović Edler von Vilovo (1821-1902), on 13 October 1879. Jovan's son Todor lived here with his wife, and here was also his editorial office of "Srpska Zora". The building does not exist anymore.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Teodor (1871-?)
entity_description: Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) was the son of Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1836-1903). He was promoted to Legation-Attaché ("Gesandschafts-Attaché") in May 1901. He married Melanie Eisner (1872-1942) in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 6 October 1907. He was member of the Vienna Hunting Club ("Wiener Jagdklub"), in which his trophies were exhibited in 1908 and which was visited by Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916). He lived in Vienna in Theresianumgasse 5 (1040 Vienna) from 1919 to 1925.
location_name: Apartment of Baron Teodor Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?)
location_description: Here lived Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) together with his wife Melanie Nikolić de Rudna (né Eisner, 1872-1942) from 1919 to 1925. After that Melanie Nikolić de Rudna stayed in the same apartment until her death in 1942. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Jeftanović Petar (1832-1855)
entity_description: Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855) was a Serbian merchant who was born in Sarajevo (today Bosnia and Herzegovina). He was the owner of the Company "P. M. Eftanovits" for the trade with Turkish goods in grosso. He died on 26 October 1855 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Tombstone of Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855) in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
Photograph by Zlatan Stojadinović (2019).
location_name: Apartment and Store of Petar Jeftanović
location_description: Here lived, traded and died Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855), a Serbian merchant. (today Lichtensteg 2, Rotgasse 2, Rotenturmstraße 15). The building does not exist anymore.

name: Utješenović Ostrožinski Ognjeslav (1817-1890)
entity_description:
Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski (1817-1890) was a Serbian politician and poet, who was born in Ostrožin (today Croatia) at the Military Frontier. As an educated lawyer, he worked firstly in the Croatian Parliament as associate of Ban Josip Jelačić (1801-1859). In 1856 he was appointed to ministerial secretary in Vienna and from 1862 to 1867 he worked as an advisor to the Croatian Court Chancellery. Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski held a title of Court Councillor ("Hofrat"). In his Viennese years he was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was one of the initiators of the foundation of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in 1860 as well as its second President from 1864 to 1870. Following Vuk Stefanović Karadžić's death in 1864, Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski, Jovan Subotić (1817-1886) and Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891) founded a committee, which took care for the release of Vuk's unpublished manuscripts as well as new editions of already published works and of his family. The first in a series of these works was the fifth book "Serbian Folk Songs", published in 1865, on the first anniversary of Vuk's death. During his stay in Vienna, Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski's son Milan (1867) and wife Jelena (1870) died. From 1875 to 1886 Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski was the governor (župan) of the Varaždin County and retired in 1886.  In 1884 the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) decorated him with the Order of Leopold, and at the same time he was ennobled as "Ritter von" with the title "Ostrožinski". He received also the Order of Franz Josef. Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski died in Zagreb in 1890.
In Vienna he published manifold works on the subject of the history of the Military Frontier:
"Die Hauskommunionen der Südslaven: Eine Denkschrift zur Beleuchtung der volkstümlichen Acker- und Familienverfassung des serbischen und des kroatischen Volkes" (1859)
 "Die Militärgränze und die Verfassung: eine Studie über den Ursprung und das Wesen der Militärgränzinstitution und die Stellung derselben zur Landesverfassung" (1861)
"Programm zur Konstituierung des österreichischen Kaiserstaates nach den Prinzipien der konstitutionellen Freiheit und der nationalen Gleichberechtigung aus dem Jahre 1848" (1861)
"Das Donau-Adria-Bahnnetz" (1865)
"Die Naturschätze im nördlichen Croatien" (1879)
"Lebensgeschichte des Kardinals Georg Utiešenović genannt Martinusius: mit dessen Bildnis, Familien-Wappen u. einer Skizze der Ruinen seines Ahnenschlosses; mit Benützung der Akten des K. K. geheimen Haus- Hof- und Staats-Archivs von 1528-1553"  (1881)
He published in Vienna also his poems:
Вила Острожинска (Volume I, 1845; Volume II, 1871)
Недељко (Volume I, 1860; Volume II, 1888)
Псалми Давидови (1868)
location_description: Here lived Ognjeslav Utješenović Ostrožinski (1817-1890), a Serbian politician and poet, with his family between 1865 and 1867. In this house died his son Milan on 15 December 1867, who is buried in the same grave with his mother Jelena, who died in 1870. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Teodorović Vasa (1851-1919)
entity_description:
Vasa Teodorović (1851-1919) was born in Stari Sivac (today Serbia) on 24 April 1851. He was an engineer, inventor, merchant and the President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna from 1907 to 1913. Since 1 July 1889 he and Max Mylius had the joint Company "Theodorović & Cie" (Stephansplatz 7, 1010 Vienna). Vasa Teodorović was the owner of several patents. Amongst others he patented and produced, together with the industrialist Georg Roth (1834-1903), the Roth-Theodorovic pistol in 1895. It was a long-recoil, locked-breech, single or double-action semi-automatic pistol.
Vasa Teodorović married Anna Wilhelmine Hlouvitschka on 4 November 1880. They had two sons, Teodor (1893) and Milan (1887), and a daughter Olga (1888). Vasa Teodorović died in Mariahilferstraße 27 (1060 Vienna) on 15 March 1919 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Vasa Teodorović (1851-1919), an engineer, inventor, merchant and the President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna, on 15 March 1919.

name: Milenković Benno von (1869-1946)
entity_description: Benno von Milenković (1869-1946) was the son of Stefan von Milenković (1836-1915) and an Austro-Hungarian Rear Admiral (Konter Admiral) of Serbian origin. In 1899 he joined the Austro-Hungarian Navy after graduation at the Naval Academy in Fiume (Rijeka, today Croatia). After having different positions in the Navy, he was promoted to the rank of Rear Admiral with the end of the First World War. In the same year he retired and lived in Vienna untill his death in 1946. He was the son of Stefan von Milenković (1836-1915) and the brother of Max von Milenković (1866-1945).
location_description: Here was the last apartment of Benno von Milenković (1869-1946), an Austro-Hungarian Rear Admiral of Serbian origin.

name: Bosanac Stefan (1802-1871)
entity_description:
Stefan Bosanac (1802-1871) was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna and one of the initiators of the founding of this community in 1860. He was also a member of the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) on 13 December 1860. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his approval for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Community of St. Sava.
In July 1850 Stefan Bosanac was the founder of the Company "Bosanetz & Welicskovits" in Lazzenhof 1 (Bauernmarkt 21, 1010 Vienna) together with Jovan Veličković (1818-1863). The company was deleted from the commercial register on 14 November 1866.
Stefan Bosanac died at the age of 69 on 30 August 1871 in Währinger Straße 35 (1180 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore). He was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 2 September 1871.
location_description:
Here was the seat of several companies:
"Bosanetz & Welicskovits" (1850-1866)
"Millicsevits Georg" (1869-1890)
 "Nedelkovits & Stankovits" (1856-1862)
The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1910.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Wilhelmine (1847-1918)
entity_description: Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna (né Hirsch) (1847-1918) was an opera singer. She married Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna in Vienna on 18 May 1869. After her husband’s death she lived mostly in Baden near Vienna. Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna died in Vienna on 25 March 1918 in the Sanatorium Svetlin (Leonhardgase 3-5, 1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here in the Sanatorium Svetlin died Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna (1847-1918) on 25 March 1918.

name: Jokić Petar (1831-1883)
entity_description: Petar Jokić (1831-1883) was a Viennese merchant, born in Zemun in 1831. He married Johanna, daughter of the goldsmith and juweler Biedermann, in Vienna in 1858. Petar Jokić became known in 1861, when he bought the Beethoven collection, two violins (Amari 1690, Guarneri 1718), one viola (Regeri 1690) and one cello (Guarneri 1712), and donated it to the Prussian Royal Library. The instruments were preserved in the so-called Jokits-Foundation ("Jokits-Stiftung"). As a reward the Prussian King Wilhelm I (1797-1888) honoured him in the same year with the Order of the Red Eagle 3rd class.  Until 1859, when he founded his own Company "Peter Th. Jokits", Petar Jokić worked for the Greek merchant Spirta. Jokić donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1862. He died in his apartment in Teinfaltstraße 6 (1010 Vienna) on 10 March 1883 and was buried two days later in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Petar Jokić (1831-1883), a Serbian merchant from Vienna on 10 March 1883. The building was demolished and new one was built in 1893.

name: Tesla Nikola (1856-1943)
entity_description: Nikola Tesla (1856-1943) was a Serbian inventor and engineer, who discovered and patented the rotating magnetic field, the basis of most alternating-current machinery. He also developed the three-phase system of electric power transmission. Nikola Tesla was born in Smiljan (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in the family of the Serbian Orthodox Priest Mliutin Tesla and his wife Djuka. He immigrated to the United States of America in 1884 and sold the patent rights to his system of alternating-current dynamos, transformers, and motors to George Westinghouse (1846-1914). In 1891 he invented the Tesla coil, an induction coil widely used in radio technology. George Westinghouse used Tesla's alternating current system to light the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893. This success was a factor in their winning the contract to install the first power machinery at Niagara Falls, which bore Tesla's name and patent numbers. The project carried power to Buffalo by 1896. Nikola Tesla died in New York on Orthodox Christmas, 7 January 1943. Despite the fact that Nikola Tesla had never studied in Vienna, but in the Polytechnic Institute in Graz, the Council of Professors at the Viennese College of Technology ("Technische Hochschule") in Vienna (now TU Vienna) awarded Nikola Tesla for his work with the honorary Dr title on 19 June 1907. The official announcement of this PhD was on 3 March 1908. After the unveiling of the Nikola Tesla's bust, sculpted by Ivan Meštrović (1883-1962), at the Vienna Technical Museum ("Technisches Museum Wien") on 29 June 1952, this Museum organised a conference on Nikola Tesla from 6 September to 13 September 1953. The Council Committee for Culture ("Gemeinderatsausschuß für Kultur") of the City of Vienna named a street, Teslagasse, in the 21st Viennese districts after him on 15 October 1952.
location_description: The Council Committee for Culture ("Gemeinderatsausschuß für Kultur") of the City of Vienna named a street, Teslagasse, in the 21st Viennese district after Nikola Tesla (1856-1943) on 15 October 1952.

name: Veličković Jovan (1818-1863)
entity_description: Jovan Veličković (1818-1863) was a merchant, who was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia). In July 1850 he was the founder of the Company "Bosanetz & Welicskovits" in Lazzenhof 1 (Bauernmarkt 21, 1010 Vienna), together with Stefan Bosanac (1802-1871), in 1850. He was also one of the initiators of the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna in 1860. Jovan Veličković died at the age of 45 on 17 September 1863 in Untere Donaustraße 23 (1020 Vienna) and was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 19 September 1863. The aforesaid company was deleted from the commercial register on 14 November 1866.

 "Nedelkovits & Stankovits" (1856-1862)
The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1910.

name: Miličević Djordje
entity_description: Djordje Miličević was a Serbian merchant in Vienna from 1860 to 1890. At first he was wrking in the Company "Janovski & Millicsevits" from 1860 to 1869, and then he founded his own company "Millicsevits Georg" (Lazzenhof 1, 1010 Vienna) in 1869. The bankrupcy of the Company was announced in 1890.  Djordje Miličević donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1862. His business partner Adolf Janovski donated 200 florins.

name: Ljubiša Stjepan Mitrov (1824-1878)
entity_description: Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša (1824-1878) was a politician and writer. He was the mayor of Budva (today Montenegro) and member of the Dalmatian Parliament from 1861 to 1864 and from 1866 to 1870. In 1870 Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša became President of the Dalmatian Parliament. He was a Member of the Lower House of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna from 1861 to 1878. Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša was awarded the Order of Franz Joseph and was Knight of the Iron Crown 3rd class.  He died in Burggasse 2 (1070 Vienna) at the age of 54 on 23 November 1878 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In 1885 his remains were transferred to his hometown Budva.
location_description: Here died Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša (1824-1878), Serbian politician and writer and Member of the Lower House of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna, on 23 November 1878.

name: Milenković Stefan von (1836-1915)
entity_description: Stefan von Milenković (1836-1915) was a writter and poet of Serbian origin. As a son of the officer Stefan von Milenković (1785-1863) he also served first in the Army, but then left in 1869 and started his career as writer. His pseudonym was Stefan Milow. In 1865 he married Baroness Elisabeth von Reichlin Meldegg in Timișoara (today Romania). After his retirement he lived in Vienna and worked in the k.k. Militärgeographisches Institut. In 1902 Stefan von Milenković received the Bauernfeldpreis and from 1909 he had a lifelong pension from the Schillerstiftung in Weimar. Stefan von Milenković lived in Mödling since 1899, where he died on 12 March 1915. He was buried in the city's cemetery according to Orthodox rite. Stefan von Milenković corresponded with the Serbian writer Laza Kostić (1841-1910), who helped Milenković with the translation of the poem "Moru" ("To the Sea") of the Montenegrin Prince Nikola Petrović (1841-1921). Milenković translated also poems of Petar Preradović (1818-1872) into German. He was the father of Benno von Milenković (1869-1946) and Max von Milenković (1866-1945).
location_name: Former Building of the k.k. Militärgeographisches Institut
location_description: Stefan von Milenković (1836-1915), writer and poet of Serbian origin, worked here.

name: Tekelija von Kevermes Petar (1784-1844)
entity_description: Petar Tekelija (1784-1844) was a nephew of Sava Tekelija (1761-1842), one of the most educated Serbs and famous benefactor, who bequeathed his entire property to the cultural and educational enlightenment of the Serbian people. Petar Tekelija was born in Kevermes (today Hungary) in 1784 as a son of Petar, Sava Tekelija's brother. Petar Tekelija had a brother Djordje and three sisters. Like his uncle Sava Tekelija, he was a great Serbian patriot and visited Serbia during the First Serbian Uprising in 1812. Before that he travelled, together with his uncle, to their cousins in the Russian Empire. Petar Tekelija was high ranking official in the Austrian Empire. He had the title of a Hungarian Court Councillor ("königl. ungarischer Rat") and was the head ("comes") of the Csanád County (today divided between Hungary and Romania). He married Marija Tekelija von Kevermes (1821-1870). After his father's death in 1820 he inherited great landed property. Petar Tekelija was also Knight of the Golden Spur ("Ritter vom goldenen Sporn"), which is a Papal Order of Knighthood. He died in Vienna in the house Leopoldstadt 522 (Praterstraße 9, 1020 Vienna) on 31 July 1844 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Petar Tekelija was the last male descendant of the noble family Tekelija.
picture_description: Csergheö de N.-Tacskand, Wappenbuch des Adels von Ungarn sammt den Nebenländern der St. Stephans-Krone (Nürnberg 1885-87), Tafel 468.
location_description: Here died Petar Tekelija (1784-1844), a nobleman, landowner and the head ("comes") of the Csanád County, on 31 July 1844. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Barbulović Dimitrije (1772-1850)
entity_description: Dimitrije Barbulović (1772-1850), a Serbian merchant from Pest, died on 16 June 1850 in Landstraße 490 (Ungargasse 6, 1030 Vienna; the building does not exist anymore). He was at the age of 78 and was buried on 18 June 1850 in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Dimitrije Barbulović (1772-1850), a Serbian merchant from Pest, on 16 June 1850. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Barbulović Jovan
entity_description:
Jovan Barbulović was the owner of a factory for French ties. He received a privilege for this kind of trade on 27 October 1845. Therefore, he founded his company entitled "Barbulowits Joh. D" for textiles and men's wear in 1846. Its address at that time was in Vienna's city centre, namely house No. 589 (that is Bauernmarkt 2a, 1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore). Jovan Barbulović was exporting his products even to Italy and the Orient.
In 1848 his company was to be found in Bauernmarkt No. 581 (that is Bauernmarkt 11, 1010 Vienna, does not exist anymore) and, apart from ties, he was selling also shirts, collars, gloves, hats, braces, etc. His motto was “Eleganz, Solidität, Billigkeit". In 1849 he moved to the first floor of the house Graben No. 619 (the so-called "Elephantenhaus", does not exist anymore, today Stock-im-Eisen-Platz). In 1857 his company situated in Ungargasse No. 364 (today Ungargasse 5, 1030 Vienna, still exists) and was deleted from the commercial register in January 1860.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Jovan (1810-1880)
entity_description: Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) married Jelisaveta-Savka Obrenović (1814-1848), the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860), on 16 October 1831. In 1832 he donated 250 forints to the Matica Srpska. He received the title of Austrian Baron in 1854. The private teacher of his sons Teodor (Fedor) and Mihajlo in Vienna was Svetozar Miletić (1826-1901), a student of Law in Vienna. The family Nikolić de Rudna was an old Serbian noble familly. Miroslav Nikolić was knighted in 1693, which was confirmed in 1778 and again in 1783. Jovan Nikolić from Osijek bought together with Teodor Jovanović Mirijevski landed property in Rudna in 1781.
location_description: Here stood the famous guesthouse "Fetzer" until 1956. Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) lived here in the 1840s with his family. In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Veljović Djordje (1789-1838)
entity_description: Djordje Veljović (1789-1838) was a Serbian merchant in Vienna and Ottoman citizen. His father was Jovan Veljović (1755-1803). He died in Fleischmarkt 14 (1010 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore) at the age of 49 on 27 December 1838 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His wife Anastasia was born in Zemun in the family Karamata. She died at the age of 38 in Vienna on 8 July 1831.

name: Tekelija von Kevermes Tereza (1809-1873)
entity_description: Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes (1809-1873) was born in the Serbian noble family Kojić von Fereghyhaz in Timișoara (today Romania) in 1809. She married Djordje Tekelija, the brother of Petar Tekelija (1784-1844) and nephew of Sava Tekelija (1761-1842), in 1825, with whom she had a daughter. Djordje Tekelija died two years later. Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes died in Kärntner Straße 17 (1010 Vienna) on 26 October 1873 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

name: Zavišić Severin (1817-1885)
entity_description: Severin Zavišić (1817-1885) was a medical doctor, surgeon and President of Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council in Vienna from 1876 to 1884. He was the owner of several patents for the invention of different instruments in the field of medicine and hygiene. In 1856 Severin Zavišić lived in Fleischmarkt 700/728 (today Fleischmarkt 1, the original building does not exist anymore). He was head physician in the Viennese "Garnisons-Spittal" and archducal Court Physician ("erzherzoglicher Hofarzt") as well as the personal physician of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). Severin Zavišić was honored with the Serbian Takovo Order (1882) and was also a honorary member of the Belgian Life Saving Society. He died in his apartment in Seitenstettengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) on 15 June 1885 at the age of 68. Severin Zavišić was buried on 17 June 1885 in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Severin Zavišić (1817-1885), a medical doctor, surgeon and President of Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council in Vienna from 1876 to 1884, on 15 June 1885.

name: Davidović Dimitrije (1789-1838)
entity_description:
Dimitrije Davidović (1789-1838) was a journalist, publisher and writer in Vienna from 1812 to 1821. After his return to Serbia he was the secretary of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860), Minister of Education and diplomat. In 1835 he was the creator of the first Serbian constitution. He was also a publisher and editor of the "Novine Srbske" in Serbia in the years 1834/1835.
Davidović's father, Gavrilo Georgijević, was an Orthodox priest in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Vienna. Dimitrije Davidović took his last name after his grandfather, David Georgijević, who was a teacher and Orthodox priest in Zemun and in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). Davidović came to Vienna together with Dimitrije Frušić (1790-1838) in autumn 1812. They were both students of Medicine. Supported by Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), the imperial censor for Slavic languages, they started to publish the Serbian newspaper "Novine serbske" in 1813. Davidović and Frušić were the owners, editors and publishers of this newspaper, which was published until February 1822. During the Congress of Vienna ("Wiener Kongreß") in 1814 they helped the former Serbian Minister Matija Nenadović substantially to inform the Great European Powers on the Serbian question. From 1818 to 1822 Davidović had his own printing house in Fleischmarkt 746 (1010 Vienna). On 1 October 1818 he received a privilege for printing books in Oriental languages. He left Vienna in autumn 1821 and the editor's position to his co-worker, Petar Matić, a law student from Zemun. He married Jelisaveta-Savka Diamandi on 30 May 1817 in Pest. They lived in the house Innere Stadt 699 (1010 Vienna). Jelisaveta died during childbirth on 23 May 1818 in this house at the age of 35. She was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 25 May 1818. Their son was named Svetozar (he died in Vienna in the 1850s). Dimitrije Davidović married one year later his second wife, Jelena, on 26 January 1819. They had the sons Milan, Jovan (born in Vienna in 1820) and a daughter Savka (born in Serbia about 1828 and died 1841). Dimitrije Davidović published in Vienna his two books "Sobranie nauka svakomu čoveku nuždni" (1814) and "Dejanija k istoriji Srbskoga naroda" (1821).
location_description: In this house Dimitrije Davidović lived with his family at least from 1818 to 1821. Here were born his sons Svetozar (1818) and Milan (1820) and died his first wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 May 1818. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Žefarović Georgije (1722-1752)
entity_description: Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752) was a Serbian painter, engraver and coppersmith. He was the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), who had appointed him as his successor. Georgije Žefarović came on his invitation to Vienna in 1740s and begun his studies at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts on 5 October 1744. Some authors are pointing out that Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter. Only three of his coppersmith works are known, which were all made in Vienna. Georgije Žefarović died in Vienna a the age of 30 in Salzgries 9 (1010 Vienna) on 24 December 1752.
location_description: Here died Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752), a Serbian painter and coppersmith, the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), on 24 December 1752. The original building does not exist anymore.

Some authors are pointing out that Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter. Only three of his coppersmith works are known, which were all made in Vienna. Georgije Žefarović died in Vienna a the age of 30 in Salzgries 9 (1010 Vienna) on 24 December 1752.
location_description: Here died Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752), a Serbian painter and coppersmith, the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), on 24 December 1752. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Veljović Jovan (1755-1803)
entity_description: Jovan Veljović (1755-1803) was a Serbian merchant, who was born in Vidin (today Bulgaria) in 1755. He lived and worked in Vienna since the 1790s in the house No. 747 (today Fleischmarkt 7, 1010 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore). He died in this house on 14 December 1803 and was buried a few days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Jovan Veljović (1755-1803), a Serbian merchant from Vidin, at the age of 48 on 14 December 1803. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Teodorović von Maligrad Djordje (1830-1889)
entity_description: Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad (1830-1889) was an Austrian Major General Major. He was Knight of the Leopold Order and the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class. Moreover, Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad was decorated with the Military Merit Cross with War decoration. Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad died in his apartment in Margaretenstraße 10 (1040 Vienna) on 19 April 1889 at the age of 59. He was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_name: Apartment of Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad
location_description: Here was the last living place of Djordje Teodorović von Maligrad (1830-1889), where he died on 19 April 1889. The original building does not exist anymore. It was demolished and a new one was built in 1936.

name: Stojić Petar (1838 -1907)
entity_description: Petar Stojić (1838-1907) was a Major General of the Austro-Hungarian Army and Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. He donated 300 florins for the building of the Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1891. Petar Stojić collected money for the building of the Church of St. Sava among the Serbs in Banat, Bačka, Dalmatia, Croatia, Slavonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Until April 1892 he and Aleksandar Štova (1836-1898) had amassed more than 20,000 florins. Because of his merits in the building of the church he was declared Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava at its annual meeting in 1893. Together with Aleksandar Štova he was also a member of the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) in November 1893. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his donation for the church building and also for his presence at the inauguration ceremony. Petar Stojić retired as commander of the 4th Ulan Regiment in 1894, when he received the honorary rank of Major General.
location_description: Here lived Petar Stojić (1838-1907), Major General of the Austro-Hungarian Army and Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna, in 1888.

name: Josifović Katinka
entity_description: Katinka Josifović was the wife of the Viennese merchant of woven goods Josif Josifović (1835-1885). She was born in Vukovar (today Croatia) in the family Bira. After her husband's death she was his legal successor. Katinka Josifović lived in Vienna and in 1903 her address was Strozzigasse 22 (1070 Vienna). She donated 200 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna.
location_description: Here lived Katinka Josifović, a donor for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna, between 1886 and 1895. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Kočić Petar (1877-1916)
entity_description: Petar Kočić (1877-1916) was a Serbian writer and politician from Bosnia and Herzegovina. After showing his national attidudes, he was expelled from school in Sarajevo and continued his education in a grammar school in Belgrade, where he graduated in 1899. After that Petar Kočić studied Slavonic Studies at the University of Vienna from 1899 to 1904. His professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923), Milan von Rešetar (1860-1942) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). For a short time he was Professor in the Serbian grammar school in Skoplje and later he moved to Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1910 Petar Kočić was elected as parliamentarian of the Agrarian Party to the newly established Parliament ("Sabor") of Bosnia and Herzegovina. He advocated an agrarian reform and the freedom of press. Petar Kočić stayed in the "Sabor" until 1913, when he resigned because of a mental illness. He died in Belgrade in a hospital during the Austro-Hungarian occupation on 27 August 1916.
location_description: Here lived from 1903 to 1904 Petar Kočić, a Serbian writer and politician, during his studies at the University of Vienna from 1899 to 1904.

name: Zec Nikola (1883-1958)
entity_description: Nikola Zec (1883-1958) was a Serbian opera singer, who was born in Zagreb on 12 October 1883. He studied at the Viennese Conservatorium. Nikola Zec performed several times in Serbian concerts: on 1 March 1906 the Mercantile Society of the Viennese Serbs ("Serbischer Kaufmännischer Verein") organised a charity concert for the Serbian Orthodox Church and its school in the Ronacher Ballsaal; on 27 January 1908 at the Serbian Students' Association "Zora" in the Kursalon (Stadtpark) and together with the famous Serbian composer and violinist Petar Stojanović (1877-1957) at the Academy of St. Sava in the Hotel Continental (Taborstraße 2, 1020 Vienna) on 26 January 1925. From 1907 to 1912 he was a member of the Viennese Volksoper and then of a theatre in Prague. Since 1916 he was a member of the Hofoper (today Wiener Staatsoper) in Vienna, where he had an appearance as a guest in 1912. According to the Archive of the Wiener Staatsoper, Nikola Zec had 1121 appearances on stage from 1912 to 1940. His first appearance was as "Marcel" in "Les Huguenots" and his last on 8 June 1940 as "Cancian" in "I quattro rusteghi". Nikola Zec lived in an apartment in Otto Bauer Gasse 2 (1060 Vienna) and died in Bad Aussee on 9 July 1958. He was buried seven days later in the Hietzing Cemetery (Hietzinger Friedhof, 1130 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Nikola Zec (1883-1958), a famous Serbian opera singer, on 9 July 1958.

name: Veljović Nikola (1796-1848)
entity_description: Nikola Veljović (1796-1848) was a Serbian merchant and managing director, who was born in Vienna in 1796. His father was Jovan Veljović (1755-1803). He died in Leopoldstadt 661 (Ferdinandstraße 30, 1020 Vienna) at the age of 52 on 8 May 1848 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Nikola Veljović (1796-1848), a Viennese merchant and managing director of Serbian origin, at the age of 52 on 8 May 1848. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Konstantinović de German Stefan (?-1828)
entity_description: Stefan Konstantinović de German (?-1828) was a Viennese house owner, merchant and wholesaler of Serbian origin. He was born in Vršac (today Serbia) and was ennobled on 30 November 1821 for his merits to "Fatherland and Country". He was raised to Hungarian nobility and became owner of the landed property German in the County of Timișoara (today Romania). Therefore, he acquired the epithet "de German". He died in German on 27 November 1828. Stefan Konstantinović de German was the owner of houses in Vienna with the numbers 699 (Grashofgasse 4, 1010 Vienna) and 704 (Fleischmarkt 9, 1010 Vienna). His first address was "am alten Fleischmarkt im goldenen Bären 741". In this house died his son Nikola at the age of 3 on 1 May 1806. Nikola was buried on 3 May 1806 in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His daughter died in the same house on 8 January 1809 during childbirth and was buried on 10 January 1809 in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Stefan's wife Jefimija, who was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia) in the family Petrović, died just two days later at the age of 30 on 10 January 1809 and was also buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 12 January 1809. In the same house died Stefan's daughter Jelisaveta (1807-25 June 1812) and was also buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In the house "am alten Fleischmarkt 736" died Stefan's daughter Maria on 18 January 1814. She was only 11 months old.
picture_description: Csergheö de N.-Tacskand, Wappenbuch des Adels von Ungarn sammt den Nebenländern der St. Stephans-Krone (Nürnberg 1885-87), Tafel 80.
location_name: Konstantinović de German house in Grashofgasse
location_description: Stefan Konstantinović de German bought this house on 5 April 1814. After his death his sucessors were Dimitrije, Konstantin, Helene, Anna, Alexandra, Johann, Eugen and Isidor Konstantinović de German.  From 1856 Dimitrije was the only owner and sold the house to Michael Sterio Dumba (1828-1894) in 1863. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Kurtović Jelena (1752-1808)
entity_description: Jelena Kurtović (1752-1808) was married to Maksim Kurtović (1731-1799), a Viennese merchant. She died at the age of 56 on 24 November 1808 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Her last place of living was "Beim goldenen Kreuz" No. 690 (Rotenturmstraße 27, 1010 Vienna).

name: Karadjordjević Petar King (1844-1921)
entity_description: King Petar I Karadjordjević (1844-1921) was King of Serbia (1904-1918) and first King of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (1918-1921). After his father's (Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević) abdication in 1858 he spent 45 years in exile. He moved from Switzerland to France, where he graduated at the renowned Military Academy of Saint-Cyr (École spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr) in 1864. During the war between France and Prussia in the years 1870/71 he fought in the French Foreign Legion. He was one of the leaders against the Ottomans in Herzegovina in 1875. Petar Karadjordjević joined the uprising under the name Petar Mrkonjić. Later he lived in exile in Montenegro, where he married Zorka (1864-1890), the daughter of the Montenegrin Prince Nikola Petrović (1841-1921). After May 1903, when King Aleksandar Obrenović (1876-1903), the last ruler from the Obrenović dynasty, was mudered in Belgrade, Petar Karadjordjević was elected to King of Serbia. He was ruling during the two Balkan Wars (1912-1913) and the First World War (1914-1918). Although a monarch, he was a strong supporter of Parliamentarism, Liberalism and Democracy. His reign was seen as the "golden time of Serbian democracy". Petar Karadjordjević was a follower of John Stuart Mill's ideas of Utilitarianism, freedom of speech, freedom of press etc. He translated Mill's work "On Liberty" into Serbian in 1867, and it was printed in Vienna in 1868.
location_description: Here in the Hotel “Zur Kaiserin Elisabeth” lived Prince Petar Karadjordjević in 1858.

name: Stratimirović Sofija von (1824-1849)
entity_description: Sofija von Stratimirović (1824-1849) was a sister of the Austrian Major General of Serbian origin and nobleman Djordje Stratimirović Ritter von Kulpin (1822-1908). She died in the house in Rauhensteingasse 8 (1010 Vienna) on 26 February 1849 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Sofija von Stratimirović (1824-1849), the sister of the Austrian Major General of Serbian origin and nobleman Djordje Stratimirović Ritter von Kulpin (1822-1908), on 26 February 1849. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Mrkalj Sava (1783-1833)
entity_description: Sava Mrkalj (1783-1833) was a Serbian philologist, poet, teacher and monk. He was born in Sjeničak (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in 1783 and educated in Plaški and Zagreb. After that he studied Philosophy and Mathematics in Pest from 1807 to 1810, where he met Dimitrije Davidović (1789-1838) and Dimitrije Frušić (1790-1838). His first meeting with Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) was also in Pest in 1810. This year was the most important in Mrkalj's life, because he published his main work entitled "Сало дебелога јера либо азбукопротрес". In this short work (only 18 pages) he presented his ideas on the reform of the Serbian language. Sava Mrkalj, a remarkable polyglot, was already familiar with the works of John Lock (1632-1704) and especially of Johann Christoph Adelung (1732-1806). Mrkalj's credo was "Write as you speak and read, as it is written". Vuk Stefanović Karadžić created his reform of the Serbian orthography having Mrkalj's work as a model. Sava Mrkalj became a monk in 1811. Later he lived as a teacher with many difficulties. He fell ill and after a few years in Karlovac (today Croatia) he was sent to the psychiatry in Vienna ("Narrenturm") in 1829. In his last days he was visited by Vuk Stefanović Karadćić who brought him books. Sava Mrkalj died in the aforesaid psychiatry on 24 August 1833. His place of burial is unknown. In the year 2016 a commemorative plaque was put on the front of the Serbian Orthodox Church of Saint Sava (Veithgasse 3, 1030 Vienna) on the initiative of two scholars from the field of Slavonic Studies, Gordana Ilić-Marković and Dušan Ivanić.
location_description: Here, in the oldest psychiatry in Continental Europe (founded in 1784), died Sava Mrkalj, Serbian philologist and reformer of the Serbian orthography, on 24 August 1833.

name: Muškatirović Jovan (1743-1809)
entity_description: Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) was a Serbian writer and representative of Rationalism. He was born in Senta (today Serbia) in 1743. After completing Law Studies in Pest in 1773, he became the first lawyer among the Serbs. He was a senator in Pest's city council. Jovan Muškatirović was a rationalist and critic of church institutions. He was the first to document folk traditions among Orthodox Serbs. In 1786 he published a treatise entitled "Краткое размишленије о праздници" ("A Short Deliberation on Holidays"), advocating a reduction in the number of religious holidays. The most important work of Jovan Muškatirović was his collection of Serbian proverbs entitled "Причте илити по простому пословице тјемже сентенције илити рјеченија", published in Vienna in 1787. In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house in Vienna. Jovan Muškatirović was a close friend of Dositej Obradović (1739-1811), by whose enlightened ideas he was influenced.
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Julinac Pavle (1737-1785)
entity_description: Pavle Julinac (1737-1785) was a historian, translator and one of the first novel writers among the Serbs. He was born in Szeged (today Hungary) in 1737. Following his studies in Bratislava (today Slovakia), he moved to the Russian Empire in 1753, where he joined the diplomatic service. From 1781 Pavle Julinac was Russian consul in Naples. He was the author of the first printed history of the Serbs entitled "Kratkoje v'vedenije v istoriju proishoždenija slaveno-serbskago naroda" ("A Short Introduction to the History of the Slavo-Serbian People"), which was published in Venice in the year 1765. This history was written under the influence of his Professor from Bratislava Ján Tomka-Sásky (1692-1762). In 1776 Julinac's translation of Jean-François Marmontel's "Bélisaire" became one of the most prominent works of Enlightenment in the Serbian literature. Pavle Julinac published in Vienna, where he died as Russian diplomat on 25 February 1785. He died in house Wollzeile 9 and was buried next day in St. Marx cemetery.
location_description: Here died Pavle Julinac (1737-1785), a historian, translator and one of the first novel writers among the Serbs, on 25 February 1785. The current building does not date to the 18th, but to the 19th century.

name: Ljubibratić Jeftimije (1716-1779)
entity_description: Jeftimije Ljubibratić (1716-1779) was born in a Serbian noble family in Dubrovnik (today Croatia) in 1716. The family of Ljubibratić was mentioned for the first time in the medieval period. At the age of 14 he joined the Habsburg army as a cadet. Because of his braveness and merits he was ennobled becoming a Baron and received the title "von Trebinya" on 26 January 1760. Two years later, on 30 April 1762, he was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Maria Theresia Order. Jeftimije Ljubibratić was promoted to the rank of Major General in 1770 and to Field marshal-lieutenant in 1773. He died in an apartment in Krugerstraße 10 (1010 Vienna) on 4 November 1779 and was buried in the Monastery of Savina (in Herceg Novi, today Montenegro), where his brother was Archimandrite.
picture_description:
Dimitrije Avramović, Portrait of General Jeftimije Ljubibratić, 1834. Property of: Галерија Матице Српске
http://www.galerijamaticesrpske.rs/portret-18-veka.html
location_description: Here died Jeftimije Ljubibratić (1716-1779), Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant, Knight of the Maria Theresia Order and Baron, on 4 November 1779. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Ljuština Vikentije (1761-1805)
entity_description: Vikentije Ljuština (1761-1805) was born in Medak (in Lika, today Croatia) and was educated in the Monastery of Gomirje (today Croatia), where he became a monk. He served as a deacon in Trieste, Vienna, Sopron and Vršac. Apart from his knowledge of classical language Vikentije Ljuština spoke German, French, Italian, Romanian and Hungarian. In 1794 he published his Grammar of Italian at the printing house of Stefan Novaković. In 1798 he edited two monographs on the Monasteries of Mesić and Zlatica.

name: Maksimović Mihailo (?-1819)
entity_description: Mihailo Maksimović (?-1819) was the first Serbian satirist. Initially he was an official in Zemun and Petrovaradin, and in 1791/92 he worked at the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. Mihailo Maksimović translated Joseph Valentin Eybel's (1741-1805) critique of the Pope entitled "Was ist der Papst?" (Vienna 1784) into Serbian. He wrote his first satiric book in Serbian language entitled "Мали буквар за велику децу" ("Small Spelling Book for Big Children") with 117 satiric stories and published it at the printing house of Stefan Novaković (1760-1823) in Vienna in 1792. In the same year Mihailo Мaksimović released also in Vienna his work "Илирически народ в памјат Леополда II Миротворца" ("The Illyrian People in the Memory of Leopold II").

name: Mikašinović Mihailo (1715-1775)
entity_description: Mihailo Mikašinović (1715-1775) was a Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman, born in Plavšinac near Koprivnica (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in an officer's family in 1715. He was the first Serb in the Habsburg Army, who reached the rank of General in 1763. He was ennobled to Baron on 28 June 1760 with the title "von Schlangenfeld". Mihailo Mikašinović was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant two years later (1765). He fought in the War of the Austrian Succession ("Österreichischer Erbfolgekrieg", 1740-1748) and in the Seven Years War ("Siebenjähriger Krieg", 1756-1763). He was also a deputy at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) in 1769. Mihailo Mikašinović was a benefactor of many Serbian churches and monasteries, to which he gave substantial donations. In his memoirs Dositej Obradović (1739-1811) mentioned his friendship with General Mikašinović, calling him "our national hero". In 1771 Mihailo Mikašinović retired from military service. In 1774 he fell ill and moved to Vienna for medical treatment. Here he died on 5 November 1775.
picture_description: Ivan Bojničić von Knin und Plavno, Der Adel von Kroatien und Slavonien (Nürnberg 1899), Tafel 85.
location_name: Place of Death of Mihailo Mikašinović
location_description: Here died Mihailo Mikašinović, Field marshal-lieutenant, nobleman and the first Serb in the Habsburg Army, who reached the rank of General, on 5 November 1775. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Nikolić von Obrenow Johann Viktor Freiherr (1884-?)
entity_description: Johann Thierfelder was born on 4 September 1884 in Gosaumühle near Halstatt (Upper Austria). He was adopted by Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna (1841-1916) in 1905, who gave him the epithet "von Obrenow" as a reminiscence that the family of Nikolić was a descendant of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). In May 1918 Johann Nikolić von Obrenow inherited two houses in Belvederegasse 6 and 8 (1040 Vienna). In 1919 he lived in Belvederegase 8. Johann Nikolić von Obrenow married Martha Mikola von Klokotfels. They had a son called Johann, who was born in Vienna on 4 November 1911.
location_name: House of Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna
location_description: This house was bought by Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna (1841-1916), a landowner and house owner, in Vienna.

name: Danilović Toma (1871-1905)
entity_description: Toma Danilović (1871-1905) was a Serbian merchant and owner of a restaurant in Vienna, who was born in Serbia in 1871. He was the owner of the famous Viennese restaurant "Zum weißen Wolf" (Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna) in 1897. He died in his apartment in Dominikanerbastei 21 (1010 Vienna) on 26 May 1905.
location_description: Toma Danilović (1871-1905) was a Serbian merchant and the owner of the famous Viennese restaurant "Zum weißen Wolf" in 1897. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Vezilić Aleksije (1753-1792)
entity_description: Aleksije Vezilić (1753-1792) was a Serbian poet, who introduced the German Enlightenment to the Serbian people. He attended a teacher's course of Stefan Vujanovski (1743-1829) in 1780. Before that he had learned German and Latin in Budapest (today Hungary). Aleksije Vezilić studied Law in Vienna in 1785. He was teaching German and Latin in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) until 1790. After that he was appointed as school inspector. Aleksije Vezilić published the "Краткоје сочиненије о приватних и публичних делах" (Vienna 1785 and 1792) and the "Краткоје написаније о спокојној жизни" (Vienna 1788 and Buda 1813), which represents the first collection of verses in modern Serbian literature, in the printing house of Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) and Stefan von Novaković. Aleksije Vezilić also wrote a Serbian-German Dictionary entitled "Речник мали Немецко-Сербски" (Vienna 1793), which was published posthumously.
picture_description:
Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/index/string:%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%98%D0%B5+%D1%81%D0%BE%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5+%D0%BE+%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%85+%D0%B8+%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%85+%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85+/tags:publication
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Stefanović Vilovski Todor (1854-1921)
entity_description:
Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), the son of Jovan Stefanović Vilovski (1821-1902) and Emilija (né Tamburić, 1836-1917), moved to Vienna with his parents in 1867, when he was 13 years old. He edited the newspapers "Srbadija" (1875-1877) and "Srpska Zora" (1876-1881) in Vienna, whose owner he was. Todor Stefanović Vilovski was a prominent figure among the Viennese Serbs. From 1875 to 1881 he was the President of the Serbian Students' Association "Zora". In 1879 he was named as deputy and secretary of the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). Todor Stefanović Vilovski met his future wife Camilla von Ottenfeld in the building, where both families lived (Burggasse 24, 1080 Vienna). They married in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) on 5 February 1885. His best man was the Austrian and then Serbian General Djura Horvatović (1835-1895). Since 1887 Todor Stefanović Vilovski was a corresponding member of the Anthropological Society in Vienna. In 1881 he moved from Vienna to Belgrade, where he became the editor of the newspaper "Videlo" and director of the Serbian Press Bureau (1881-1887 and 1912-1915). Because of political issues he returned to Vienna in 1887, where he stayed until 1895. Todor Stefanović Vilovski was director of the Serbian Post and Telegraph until 1899, when he moved again to Vienna after a conflict with the Prime Minister Vladan Djordjević (1844-1930). This time he stayed in Vienna until 1909. He lived in Belgrade from 1909 to 1915, when he was arrested after the Austro-Hungarian occupation of Serbia and sent to Vienna.  He died on 9 January 1921. In his memoirs "Iz moga života" he narrates important information, not only about his life in Vienna, but also about the Serbian community and the social life of the Serbs in Vienna.
Here are some examples: Vilovski's grandfather, Djordje Tamburić, was a frequent guest at Mayreder's Serbian café, located in Rotenturmstraße (1010 Vienna), until his death. He died in 1881 and was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). As other meeting places of the Viennese Serbs Todor Stefanović Vilovski mentions the "Mirakelkeller" (Haarhof, Rotenturmstraße 16, 1010 Vienna) and "Zu den drei Raben" (Rotenturmstraße 21, 1010 Vienna). The friends and supporters of Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) gathered in the "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich") of Аndrija Gerlović in Bauernmarkt (1010 Vienna) every afternoon.
Todor Stefanović Vilovski met Felix Kanitz (1829-1904) in the house of Wilhelmine-Mina Karadžić (1828-1894) in 1869. Felix Kanitz was a faithful friend of Vuk's family for the rest of his life in recognition of Vuk's support for his scholarly work in Serbia. Based on Kanitz's recommendation, Todor Stefanović Vilovski became a correspondent on the Balkans and Serbian literature in the Augsburger Allgemeine Zeitung for the duration of ten years and also one of the authors of Baron Joseph Alexander von Helfert's (1820-1910) "Die Völker Österreich-Ungarns" (1880). The 11th volume of this series is entitled "Die Serben in Dalmatien und im Südlichen Ungarn, in Bosnien und im Herzegowina" and was written by Todor Stefanović Vilovski. Vilovski's book "Aus Belgrads Vergangenheit" (Vienna, Druck und Verlag Adolf Holzhausen, 1894) is also of great significance, because the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) himself in person took it for the Imperial Library (today the National Library of Austria in Vienna) and thanked the author.
location_description: "Srpska Zora" was a Serbian illustrated journal, which was published monthly from 1876 to 1881, having a total of 44 issues. The first issue was edited on 1 January 1876. The owner and publisher was Konstantin Kosta Mandrović (1840-1920), the editor Mita Georgiević. The address of the editorial office was in the beginning Pragerstraße 13 (1030 Vienna) and, starting with the third issue, Gärtnergasse 24 (1030 Vienna). The owner of "Srpska zora", starting with the fourth issue, was Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), and the publisher Konstantin Kosta Mandrović. With Issue No. 6 the address of the editorial office was was Burggasse 24 (1070). "Srpska Zora" had a patriotic content, which becomes evident through the war illustrations of the Ottoman-Serbian wars 1876-1878. Apart from that poems and novels of the most famous Serbian authors were published in this journal, like those of Djura Jakšić, Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, Jakov Ignjatović, Milorad Šapčanin, Jovan Jovanović Zmaj, Prince Nikola Petrović of Montenegro, Laza Kostić, Laza Lazarević and many others. In 1877 the journal had 1,000 subscribers, and since 1878 novels of European authors like Turgenjev, Keller, Sacher-Masoch etc. were published in translation in every issue. The journal was printed in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation and later in the printing house of Janko Kovačev.

name: Drndarski Budislav von (1873-1936)
entity_description:
Budislav Edler von Drndarski (1873-1936) was an official and a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna. He was Vice-President of the Community Council. Budislav Drndadrski was born in Wadowice (today Poland) on 30 March 1873. He married Helene Kietzl  in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 11 February 1901. Budislav Drndadrski lived at this time in St. Pölten (Neugasse 8).
They had five children: Danica was born on 30 November 1901 in Sankt Pölten and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 1 March 1902.  Dušan was born on 25 January 1903 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 19 March 1903. Uroš was born on 10 September 1906 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 28 November. Zorka was born on 1 July 1908 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 27 August. Vera was born on 10 March 1911 and baptised in the St. Sava Church on 17 April. Zorka's and Vera's godmother was Jelena Ostojić (1874-1967).
Budislav Drndarski was promoted to Ministerial Vice-Secretary in 1906 and then to Ministerial Secretary in the Ministry of Finance in 1910. His father, Lieutenant colonel Velizar Drndarski, was ennobled in 1900. Budislav Drndarski died in the City's Hospital (1130 Vienna) on 28 June 1936 and was buried three days later. In his family tomb in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) are buried also his mother Sofija (1845-1908) and his children Zora (died in 1908) and Uroš (died in 1907). His wife Helene (né Kietzl in St. Pölten on 5 June 1875) died in their family apartment in Lainzerstraße 124 (1130 Vienna) on 23 October 1936 and was also buried in the tomb next to her husband three days later.
picture_description: The family tomb of Budislav von Drndarski in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna). Photograph by Zlatan Stojadinović (2019).
location_description: Here was the last Viennese apartment of Budislav von Drndarski. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Nikolić von Serbograd Isidor (1805-1862)
entity_description: Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd (1805-1862) was a politician and writer. In 1837 and 1842 he was member of the Serbian National Congresses. From 1849 to 1852 he was head  ("Obergespan") of the Counties of Bačka and Banat. Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd donated 10 ducats for the building of the Votivkirche in Vienna in 1853. In 1849 he printed a monograph on his political views on Serbian autonomy within the Hungarian part of the Austrian Empire entitled "Vojvodstvo Serba Austriski" in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation in Vienna.
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske, Novi Sad.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/2930
location_description:
The Votivkirche (Votive Church) is a neo-Gothic church in the city centre of Vienna. It was built following the attempted and failed assassination of Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) in 1853. The Emperor's brother Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian (1832-1867) inaugurated a campaign to create a church to thank God for saving the Emperor's life. Funds for the construction were collected throughout the Empire.
Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd (1805-1862), politician and writer, donated 10 ducats for the building of the Votivkirche in Vienna in 1853.

name: Novaković Stefan von  (1760-1823)
entity_description: Stefan von Novaković (1760-1823) was born in Osijek (today Croatia) and was a Hofagent at the Hungarian Court Chancellery ("Ungarische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. In 1792 he bought a printing house from Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) and became a privileged imperial Cyrillic printer in the Habsburg Empire. He sold the printing house to Pest University in 1795 and returned to Osijek. There he worked at the court in the Counties of Bačka and Virovitica. He wrote anonymously the "Dissertatio brevis ac sincera Hungari Auctoris de Gente Serbica perperam Rasciana dicta ejusque Meritis ac fatis in Hungaria cum Appendice Privilegiorum" (sine loco, 1790) and in German "Kurzgefasste Abhandlung über die Verdienste und Schicksale der serbischen oder rascischen Nation in Hungarn, mit einem Anhange der derselben verliehenen Privilegien" (Neusatz und Belgrad bei Janković 1791). Stefan von Novaković received a privilege by the Emperor Franz II (1768-1835) on 18 April 1793 for printing  in the next 15 years, but after 1796 he had some financial obligations to the Illyric National fund.
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/index/pubid:2822/id:0/searchPublishedSince:1793
