Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Frušić Dimitrije (1790-1838)
entity_description: Dimitrije Frušić (1790-1838) was born in 1790 in Divoš (today Serbia). He came to Vienna in autmn 1812 together with Dimitrije Davidović in order to study Medicine. Together they founded as editors and owners the "Novine Serbske" and published them from 1813 to 1816. In 1816, after he had finished his studies, he moved to Trieste, where he worked as a doctor and died in 1838.
picture_description:
Dimitrije Frušić with his family. Painting by Giuseppe Tominz, ca. 1832.

https://sr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0:Jo%C5%BEef_Tominc_-_Dr._Fru%C5%A1i%C4%87_z_dru%C5%BEino.jpg

https://www.ng-slo.si/si/stalna-zbirka/1820-1870/druzina-dr-frusica-jozef-tominc?workId=1700 (NG S 463, Narodna galerija, Ljubljana)
location_description: After numerous applications Dimitrije Davidović received a privilege to print books in Oriental languages in 1818. His printing house was active until 1822. Its address was Alter Fleischmarkt 746. This house was popularly called "Darvarhof", named after the owner, a Greek merchant from the Darvar family. After the renumeration it was Fleischmarkt 5, but this building was demolished at the beginning of the 20th century.

name: Obrenović Jekatarina- Katica  (1826-1848)
entity_description: Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848) was the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother, Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856). She died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 27 July 1848.
location_name: Tomb of Jekatarina Obrenović in the St. Marx Cemetery
location_description: Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848), the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in tomb No. 3 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 27 July 1848.

name: Obrenović Marija (1831-1876)
entity_description: Marija Obrenović (1831-1876) was born in the Romanian noble family of Catargiu in 1831. She married Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861), the son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother. Their son Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) was Prince and King (from 1882) of Serbia. As a young boy Milan lived in Vienna with his mother. In their neighborhood was Arthur Schnitzler (1862-1931), who wrote in his autobiography about the childhood of the young Milan. Milan's mother Marija was the owner of the house in Hirschengasse 29 (today Billrothstraße 29, 1190 Vienna). This house does not exist anymore. Marija Obrenović died in Paris in 1876.
location_description: As a young boy Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) lived in Vienna with his mother Marija Obrenović (1831-1876). In their neighborhood was Arthur Schnitzler (1862-1931), who wrote in his autobiography about the childhood of the young Milan. Milan's mother Marija was the owner of the house in Hirschengasse 29 (today Billrothstraße 29, 1190 Vienna). This house does not exist anymore.

name: Obrenović Miloš  (1829-1861)
entity_description: Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861) was a son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother. He studied  from 1841 to 1842 at the k.u.k. Ingenieurakademie in Vienna. Miloš Obrenović was an officer in the Prussian and Romanian armies. He married Elena Maria Catargiu (Marija Obrenović, 1831-1876) and their son was the Prince and King of Serbia Milan Obrenović (1854-1901).
location_description: Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861), son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother, studied here from 1841 to 1842 at the k.u.k. Ingenieurakademie.

name: Žefarović Hristofor (1690-1753)
entity_description:
Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753) was a coppersmith and engraver, painter and monk, who was born ca. 1690 in Dojran (then Ottoman Empire, today Republic of North Macedonia). As a church painter of the Metropolis of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) he came to Vienna in 1741. His works were printed by the Viennese coppersmith Thomas Meßmer. Until 1753 he was intermittently in Vienna, when he finally moved to Moscow and died in the same year. Initially, Hristofor Žefarović had come to Vienna with his nephew Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752). Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter, but unfortunately died early. Hristofor Žefarović then adopted his sister's son Danilo Žefarović (1736-1806), who was appointed as his only successor in his testament.
He printed his most famous work entitled "Stemmatography" ("Stematografija") in 1741. The role model for his publication was Pavel Ritter Vitezović's (1652-1713) heraldic book "Stemmatography" from the year 1702. Hristofor Žefarović translated from Latin into Church Slavonic and created several engravings and pictures, which are: the portraits of the Serbian Saints of the Middle Ages, especially the rulers and Saints of the Nemanjić Dynasty, the coats of arms of the 56 Slavic and other Balkan countries and coats of arms of different cities and states. The importance of the "Stemmatography" is remarkable, not only for the the Serb people, but also for all the other Southern Slavs. This book played an extremely important role in the spiritual awakening and enlightenment of the Serbs in the 18th century. It is also worth mentioning that it is dedicated to the Serbian Patriarch Arsenije IV Jovanović Šakabenta (1698-1748). In 1743 Hristofor Žefarović wrote the first translation of imperial privileges for the Serbs by the Habsburg rulers Leopold I (1640-1705), Josef I (1678-1711), Charles VI (1685-1740) and Maria Theresia (1717-1780) and printed them in Vienna.
picture_description:
Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/3021
location_description: Here was located the copperplate manufactory Thomas Meßmer copperplate manufacture in the middle of the 18th century, with whom Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753) was cooperating.

name: Živanović Dušan (1853-1937)
entity_description: Dušan Živanović (1853-1937) was a Serbian architect, who was born in Senta (today Serbia). He studied Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1871 to 1873 as a student of the famous Professor Teophil von Hansen (1813-1891). During his studies he lived in Theresianumgasse 13 (1040 Vienna) from 1871 to 1872. Dušan Živanović worked later as an architect in the Ministry of Infrastructure of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in Belgrade. He designed many public buildings and Orthodox churches, among which the most important is the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity in Banja Luka (today Republic of Srpska, Bosnia and Hercegovina) from 1925 to 1929.
location_description: Here lived Dušan Živanović (1853-1937), Serbian architect and student of the famous Professor Teophil von Hansen (1813-1891), during his studies in Vienna from 1871 to 1872.

name: Kostić Laza (1841-1910)
entity_description: Laza Kostić (1841-1910) was a Serbian poet, lawyer, writer, politician and polyglot. He was one of the pioneers of the systematic translation of Shakespeare into Serbian. After the graduation of Law Studies at the University of Pest, he received his doctoral title in 1866. Laza Kostić was an associate of Svetozar Miletić (1826-1901), the political leader of the Serbs in the region of Vojvodina. Laza Kostić was a deputy in the Hungarian Parliament and also at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). During his visits to Vienna in the 1880s he stayed at the home of his friend Jovan Jovanović Zmaj (1833-1904). As Jovan Jovanović wrote in his diary, they were often together at the restaurant "Griechenbeisl" (Fleischmarkt 11, 1010 Vienna). Laza Kostić died in the Cottagesanatorium (Sternwartestraße 74, 1180 Vienna) on 9 December 1910. He stayed there from the beginning of November 1910, and his last days were described by Dr. Milan Šević. On this very building the Matica Srpska placed a commemorative plaque in 1960.
location_description: Here died Laza Kostić, Serbian poet, lawyer, writer, politician and polyglot, on 9 December 1910.

name: Petronijević Milan (1831-1914)
entity_description: Milan Petronijević (1831-1914) began his diplomatic career in Constantinople in 1854. Later he worked in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Belgrade and was Serbian ambassador in Bucharest, Berlin, Vienna (1889-1890) and in St. Petersburg. Milan Petronijević was Minister of Foreign Affairs in the years 1867 and 1868. He married Kleopatra Karadjordjević (1835-1855), the daughter of Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević (1806-1885), in 1855. Milan Petronijević was a honorary member of the Serbian Royal Academy since 1892.
location_description: The Serbian legation in Vienna was located at this place from 1887 to 1897.

name: Petrović Ladislav Eugen (1839-1907)
entity_description: Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907) was born on 25 January 1839 in Vienna and was the son of the famous sculptor Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854). He was a landscape painter, illustrator, and caricaturist. From 1857 to 1861 Ladislav Eugen Petrović was a student at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste"), where he devoted himself to landscape and architectural painting. He was drawing for newspapers ("Illustrierte Zeitung" in Leipzig, "L'Illustration" in Paris) and was illustrating books. Ladislav Eugen Petrović created a series of Viennese topographical oil paintings and from 1887 he was painting watercolors (reproduced in full color, including the series "Wiener Ansichten", "Wiener Bilderbögen", "Erinnerung an Wien" and "Wiener Typen"). Ladislav Eugen Petrović died on 1 April 1907 in his apartment in Landstraßer Hauptstraße 21 (1030 Vienna). He had lived there since 3 December 1894 with his wife Mathilde (né Nowotny). Before this last place of living he had lived in Erdbergstraße 3 (1030 Vienna). Ladislav Eugen Petrović was born as an Orthodox and converted to Catholicism on 1 December 1894.
picture_description:
Ladislav Eugen Petrović, Monumental-Plan der Haupt- und Residenzstadt Wien (1887).

https://www.digital.wienbibliothek.at/wbrobv/content/titleinfo/1476426
location_description: Here died the Viennese painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907) on 1 April 1907. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Čokor Jovan (1849-1911)
entity_description:
Jovan Čokor (1849-1911) was born as Johann Nepomuk Csokor on 4 April 1849 and was baptised on 6 April in the Roman Catholic church of St. Leopold (1020 Vienna). He was born in the house No. 371 in Leopoldstadt (today Große Stadtgutgasse 11, 1020 Vienna). His father was Aleksandar Čokor (1815-1884) and his mother Anna Schindler (1818-1856). He started his education at Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) at his uncle the Archimandrite Julijan Čokor and stayed there from 1854 to 1864. After that he finished the grammar school in Pest in 1866 and continued to study medicine in Vienna. Jovan Čokor was promoted to Dr. of Medicine in 1873. In 1875 he graduated in Veterinary Science and gained a position as assistant at the Department of Anatomy and Physiology in Vienna. He gave lectures on Histology and Parasitology and introduced histological-microscopic teaching at the University.

Jovan Čokor married Emilie Müller on 28 July 1877 in Vienna. They had five children:
Emilie Sofia Maria Čokor (6 June 1878),
Franz Theodor Čokor (8 September 1885 - 5 January 1969),
Johann Čokor (22 October 1886 - 1915),
Eugenie Čokor (24 November 1887 - 1979),
Sofie Čokor (6 July 1891 - 1967).

From 1876 as a temporary and from 1879 as a permanent Lecturer at the Chair of Zoology, Čokor was appointed as Professor of General Pathology and Forensic Veterinary Medicine in Vienna in 1880. In 1884 he deepened his knowledge by working together with Robert Koch (1843-1910) in Berlin. Already from 1889 he was also an eminent Professor of Infectious and Parasitic Diseases and turned more to parasitology. In 1906 a chair was established for this discipline. Čokor also founded and widely publicised diagnostic vaccine stations. In addition, he taught as a Privatdozent from 1890 and as a Professor of Veterinary Medicine from 1895 at the University of Vienna. In 1909 he retired as Professor.
Jovan Čokor published regularly in several scientific journals, namely the "Österreichische Vierteljahresschrift für wissenschaftliche Veterinärkunde", "Allgemeine Wiener Medizinische Zeitung" and "Wiener Wochenschrift". He published a "Lehrbuch der gerichtlichen Thierheilkunde" (1898, 2nd ed. 1902). He received the Knight's Cross in 1898 and the Officer's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1909. He was Knight of the Serbian Order of Saint Sava and a member of the Society of Doctors as well as honorary member of the Serbian Society of Doctors in Belgrade. Finally, he bore the title of "Hofrat". Jovan Čokor died on 7 January 1911 in his apartment in Mödling (Jasomirgottgasse 8) and was buried on the local cemetery.
location_description: Here was born Jovan Čokor, Professor at the University of Vienna, on 4 April 1849. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Radonić Jovan (1873-1956)
entity_description: Jovan Radonić (1873-1956) was a Serbian historian, Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade. He was born in Mol (today Hungary) on 28 January 1873. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, Jovan Radonić studied History at the University of Vienna from 1891 to 1896. During this period he lived in Lederergasse 26 (1080 Vienna). His Professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). Jovan Radonić received his title of Dr on 16 July 1896. His dissertation was entitled "Der Grossvojvode von Bosnien Sandalj Hranić-Kosača". Since 1919 he was Professor at the University of Belgrade. Jovan Radonić was also a member of the Serbian Royal Academy as well as of many other scholarly societies and academies. He participated in political life and from 1923 he was a deputy in the Parliament of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes. Jovan Radonić died in Belgrade on 25 November 1956.
location_description: Here lived Jovan Radonić (1873-1956), Serbian historian and Professor at University, during his studies at the University of Vienna from 1891 to 1892.

name: Radošević von Radoš Dimitrije (1767-1832)
entity_description: Dimitrije Radošević von Radoš (1767-1835) was a Baron, Field marshal-lieutenant, Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat") and Vice President of the War Council ("Hofkriegsrat") of Serbian origin. He was born in Medak (today Croatia, Military Fontier) in 1767. From 26 June 1825 to 4 June 1835 the 53rd Infantry Regiment from Osijek (today Croatia) was named after Major General Dimitrije Radošević ("Infanterieregiment Freiherr Radossevich von Rados Nr. 53").  In February 1823 he was knighted with the title of Baron and became part of Hungarian nobility. In 1829 Dimitrije Radošević was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant. In 1831 the Austrian Emperor Franz I (1768-1835) promoted him to commander of the united Military Frontier ("Banat-Warasdiner-Carlstädter-Gränze"). In July 1834 Dimitrije Radošević became Vice President of the War Council ("Hofkriegsrat") in Vienna. He was Knight of the Leopold Order, Knight of the Russian St. Anna Order, Owner of the French Legion of Merit and of the Silver Civil Honor Cross. Dimitrije Radošević von Radoš died in his apartment (House No. 136 in der Stadt – today Schottengasse 2, 1010 Vienna) on 4 June 1835 at the age of 68 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).in Vienna.
location_name: Apartment of Dimitrije Radošević von Radoš
location_description: Here died Dimitrije Radošević von Radoš (1767-1835) on 4 June 1835 at the age of 68. He was a Baron, Field marshal-lieutenant, Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat") and Vice President of the War Council ("Hofkriegsrat") of Serbian origin.

name: Rajić Jovan (1726-1801)
entity_description: Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) was a Serbian historian, pedagogue, writer and Archimandrite of the Monastery of Kovilj (today Serbia). He was educated in the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in Kiev. Jovan Rajić was one of the best educated Serbs of his time. He wrote in Serbian, Russian, Latin, German and Hungarian and published a Serbian catechesis for children, which was printed in Vienna in 1774. His most important work was his "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"), which was published in the printing house of Stefan Novaković in Vienna between 1794 and 1795. This history was one of the first written by a Serb and had an enormous influence on the subsequent generations of historians. Jovan Rajić collected sources in the Russian Empire and on the Holy Mount Athos. He also used parts of the manuscript of Count Djordje Branković (1645-1711). Apart from its scholarly character, Jovan Rajić's "History" was the first Serbian book, which was printed by subscription. Namely, the advertisement for the book was published in Novaković's daily newspaper in Vienna, called "Slaveno-Serbskija Vjedomosti", in 1794 and the readers assembled the money for this book. Jovan Rajić died in the Monastery of Kovilj in 1801.
picture_description:
A lithograph of Jovan Rajić by Anastas Jovanović from 1852.

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jovan_Rajic.jpg
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Petrović Dimitrije (1799-1854)
entity_description:
Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854) was a sculptor in Vienna. He was born in Baja (today Hungary) and came to Vienna in 1819. He studied first with Josef Klieber (1773-1850) and continued his studies in 1821 at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts. Here Dimitrije Petrović received two awards in 1823. After that he worked together with the sculptor Johann Nepomuk Schaller (1777-1842), and his most important work was a statue of Count Kinsky from 1830, which was presented to the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt ("Wiener Neustadt – Theresianische Militärakademie. Franz Graf Kinsky. Büste 1829 beauftragt und 1830 von Johann Nepomuk Schaller geschaffen, gegossen von Demeter Petrowitsch"). From 1831 he worked alone and created many sculptures, among them two of Jesus Christ for Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and one for the Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci. He also designed altars in chapels for the Count Schwarzenberg.
Dimitrije Petrović died at the age of 55 on 25 December 1854 in his apartment in Leopoldstadt No. 378. He was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His son was the famous painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907).
picture_description:
Wiener Neustadt – Theresianische Militärakademie. Franz Graf Kinsky. Büste 1829 beauftragt und 1830 von Johann Nepomuk Schaller geschaffen, gegossen von Demeter Petrowitsch.


https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Theresianische_Milit%C3%A4rakademie,_Wiener_Neustadt_2.jpg
location_description: Here died the Viennese sculptor Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854) on 25 December 1854.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Jelisaveta-Savka  (1814-1848)
entity_description: Jelisaveta-Savka Nikolić de Rudna (né Obrenović, 1814-1848) was the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). She married Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) on 16 October 1831. Jelisaveta-Savka died on 23 September 1848 in the house Leopoldstadt No. 579 (today Praterstraße 8, 1020 Vienna) and was buried on 30 September in Tomb No. 4 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In the same cemetery were buried her two sons. The first died after birth on 14 January 1847 and the second, Mladen, on 12 February 1849. Then they were transferred to Vöslau on 4 August 1881 and after that to the landed property of Rudna (today Romania).
picture_description:
Savka Obrenović, painted by Miklós Barabás (1810-1898)
Residence of Princess Ljubica
Belgrade, Serbia

Description:
"This Biedermeier portrait, painted in Vienna, shows Jelisaveta Savka Obrenović, the third child and the youngest daughter of Prince Miloš and Princess Ljubica. She is depicted in a silk dress and a libade trimmed with fur, also known as škurteljka. This is the only traditional element in her dress. The medallion with a portrait of prince Miloš supported by her hand alludes to her ancestors. According to tradition, Prince Miloš was particularly closely related to Savka, who was his favourite child. At the age of seventeen she got married to Baron Jovan Nikolić of Rudna, with whom she had five sons."
https://izi.travel/en/286d-miklos-barabas-savka-obrenovic/en
location_description: Here stood the famous guesthouse "Fetzer" until 1956. Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) lived here in the 1840s with his family. In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Nikolić de Rudna Micheline (1882 -1901)
entity_description: Micheline Nikolić de Rudna (1882 -1901) was the daughter of Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1836-1903) and his wife Wilhelmine (né Hirsch, 1847-1918). She married Ludwig Wich von der Reuth in Vienna on 16 June 1900 in the Protestant Church (Evangelische Kirche A.B., Dorotheergasse 18, 1010 Vienna). She died in Riva on 1 July 1901 and was buried in Wich's family tomb in Götzendorf on 5 July 1901.
location_description: Here in the Protestant Church (Evangelische Kirche A.B.) Micheline Nikolić de Rudna (1882-1901), the daughter of Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1836-1903) and his wife Wilhelmine (né Hirsch), married Ludwig Wich von der Reuth on 16 June 1900.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Mladen (1845-1849)
entity_description: Mladen Nikolić (1845-1849) was the son of Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) and Jelisaveta-Savka Nikolić de Rudna (né Obrenović, 1814-1848). He died on 12 February 1849 at the age of 4 in the house Leopoldstadt No. 579 (today Praterstraße 8, 1020 Vienna) and was buried on 14 February 1849 in Tomb No. 4 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In the same tomb was buried his mother Jelisaveta-Savka. They were both transferred to Vöslau on 4 August 1881 and after that to the landed property of Rudna (today Romania).
picture_description: Jelisaveta Nikolić with her sons (photograph to be dated between 1845 and 1848), standing: Miloš (-1863) and Teodor (Fedor) (1836-1903), sitting: Mihajlo (1841-1916) and Mladen (1845-1849). Private collection.
location_description: Here stood the famous guesthouse "Fetzer" until 1956. Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) lived here in the 1840s with his family. In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Nikolić de Rudna Melanie (1872-1942)
entity_description: Melanie Nikolić de Rudna (né Eisner, 1872-1942) married Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) in in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 6 October 1907. She lived from 1919 until her death in 1942 in Thersianumgasse 5 (1040 Vienna).
picture_description: Grave stone of Melanie Nikolić de Rudna in Central cemetery, Vienna.
location_name: Apartment of Baron Teodor Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?)
location_description: Here lived Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) together with his wife Melanie Nikolić de Rudna (né Eisner, 1872-1942) from 1919 to 1925. After that Melanie Nikolić de Rudna stayed in the same apartment until her death in 1942. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Ristić-Hadži Petar (1823-1869)
entity_description:
Petar Hadži-Ristić (1824-1869) was born in Sarajevo (today Bosnia and Herzegovina) in 1824. He was a merchant of Ottoman goods in Vienna, especially those from Bosnia and Herzegovina, since 1855. He died on 13 September 1869 at the age of 45 in his apartment in Wollzeile 21 (1010 Vienna). He was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 15 September 1869. In the same tomb was buried his eight year old daughter Vera on 25 December 1869, who was born in Vienna in 1861. She had also died in the apartment in Wollzeile 21 (1010 Vienna) on 21 December 1869.
The Company "Haghi Risto's Söhne" was founded in 25 July 1855 with its seat in Wollzeile 21 (1010 Vienna) by Petar Hadži-Ristić, Ottoman citizen, and Vasilije Hadži-Ristić in Sarajevo. The Company was deleted from the commercial register in 1865, and Petar founded a new Company "P. Haggi Risto", which was registered on 23 September 1865. Its address was again Wollzeile 21. Since 15 July 1870, i.e. after the death of Petar Hadži-Ristić, the existence of a Company "P. Haghi Risto & Cie." is attested at the same address. Its owners were Katarina and Risto Hadži-Ristić. At the same time the Company "P. Haggi Risto" was deleted from the commercial register. In 1883 the Company "P. Haghi Risto & Cie." was moved to Grashofgasse 4 (1010 Vienna, the building does not exist anymore), and apart from Katarina Hadži-Ristić, its owners were Stefan and Konstantin Hadži-Ristić.
Since 2 May 1908 the Company's owner was Dr. iur. Stephan Hadži Ristić with its seat in Rauchensteingasse 3 (1010 Vienna). In 1928 the Company was in the process of liquidation. Konstantin Hadži-Ristić died on 6 June 1928 in Hofgasse 9 (1050 Vienna, the building does not exist anymore). Finally, the Company was deleted from the commercial register in October 1931.
location_description: At this address was to be found the apartment of Petar Hadži-Ristić (1824-1869). His companies "Haghi Risto's Söhne" and "P. Haggi Risto" were registered at the same address.

name: Duka de Kadar Petar (1756-1822)
entity_description: Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822) was a General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugmeister"), commanding General in the region of Banat, nobleman ("Baron"), "k. k.Geheimer Rat" and Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresia. He was born in Osijek (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in a merchant's family of Serbian origin in 1756. Duka began a very long military career in 1776. After the victorious Battle of Famars (1793) against the French Revolutionary Army he became Knight of the Maria Theresia Order. In 1800 Duka was promoted to Major General. He became commander of the fortress in Timișoara (today Romania) and in 1813 General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugsmeister"). In 1815 Duka was honored with the title of "k. k. Geheimer Rat" by the Austrian Emperor Franz I (1768-1835). The Infantry Regiment No. 39 carried his name since 1803. Apart from the Large Cross of the Leopold Order he was also the holder of many Russian, Prussian, Bavarian, French and Sicilian decorations. Duka received Hungarian nobility with the rank of "Baron" and became the owner of the landed property Kadar in Banat (today Romania). Therefore, his title was "de Kadar" or "von Kadar". From 1815 he was a member of the State Council ("Staatsrat") and because of that he settled in Vienna. Petar Duka de Kadar died on 29 December 1822 in the house in Renngasse 10 (1010 Vienna). He was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) and in 1907 his mortal remains were exhumed and buried in Kadar.
picture_description:
Lithograph by Josef Lanzedelly the Elder, ca. 1820.

https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Peter_von_Duka_Litho.jpg
location_name: Apartment of Baron Petar Duka de Kadar
location_description: Here was the last living place of the General of the Artillery and Baron Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822). He died here on 29 December 1822. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Romanić Bogdan (1852-1924)
entity_description: Bogdan Romanić (1852-1924) was a Major General in the Austro-Hungarian Army. He was of Serbian origin and was born in Mali Gradac (Military Frontier, today Croatia) on 11 January 1852. He studied at the k.u.k. Technische Militärakademie in Vienna from 1869 to 1871. Bogdan Romanić retired in 1905 and received the title of Major General in 1907. He was an active member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. Bogdan Romanić died in Dubrovnik (today Croatia) on 12 January 1924.
location_description: Here lived Bogdan Romanić (1852-1924), a Major General in the Austro-Hungarian Army, between 1905 and 1910.

name: Ruvarac Ilarion (1832-1905)
entity_description: Jovan Ruvarac (1832-1905, as monk called Ilarion) was a Serbian lawyer, historian and theologian. He was born in Sremska Mitrovica (today Serbia) in 1832. He studied Law at the University of Vienna from 1852 to 1856 and after that Theology in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) from 1856 to 1859. He stayed there as Professor and Rector. Jovan Ruvarac became a monk with the name Ilarion in 1861 and an Archimandrite of the Monastery of Grgeteg (today Serbia) in 1882. He died in this monastery in 1905.
location_description: Here lived Ilarion Ruvarac (1832-1905), a Serbian lawyer, historian and theologian, during his studies in Vienna (1852-1856). The building does not exist anymore.

name: Zamfir Jovan von Jr. (1867-1887)
entity_description: Jovan Zamfir Junior (1867-1887), the son of Jovan Zamfir (1834-1914), was born on 30 November 1867 in Piaristengasse 41 (1080 Vienna). Like his father he was a pharmacist. Jovan Zamfir Junior was baptised in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) and his godfather was Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880). Jovan Zamfir Junior died at the age of 20 on 4 December 1887 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
picture_description: Csergheö de N.-Tacskand, Wappenbuch des Adels von Ungarn sammt den Nebenländern der St. Stephans-Krone (Nürnberg 1885-87), Tafel 399.
location_description: In this house was born Jovan Zamfir Junior (1867-1887) on 30 November 1867. The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1893.

name: Sandić Aleksandar  (1836-1908)
entity_description:
Aleksandar Sandić (1836-1908) was a journalist and Professor. He studied and lived in Vienna from 1857 to 1866. In 1866 he returned to Novi Sad (today Serbia), where he was a Professor of Serbian language until his retirement in 1900. Aleksandar Sandić was a member of the "Matica Srpska" and also a deputy at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) in 1897. In politics he was associated with Svetozar Miletić (1826-1901). Aleksandar Sandić died in Novi Sad in 1908.
In 1857 he began to study Law and Slavonic Studies in Vienna, and graduated in both academic fields in 1861. He was a secretary of Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) and since 1862 he was in the editorial office of the the political newspaper "Ost und West". Aleksandar Sandić wrote articles in Aleksandar Andrić's (1816-1876) "Svetovid" since 1857. After the arrest of the editor Imbro Tkalac (1824-1912) in 1863, Aleksandar Sandić replaced him and stayed on this position until 1865. In 1865 Aleksandar Sandić was sentenced to six months in prison because of his article "Die Slaven Österreichs", which was published on 17 January 1865 in "Ost und West".  On 20 December 1864 the newspaper itself was abolished. Aleksandar Sandić translated books about the Serbs in the Austrian Empire from German into Serbian, e.g. the book by Baron Johann Christoph Bartenstein "Kratak izveštaj o stanju rasejanoga mnogobrojnoga ilirskog naroda po carskim i kraljevskim nasledničkim zemljama”(1866) and Felix Kanitz's "Vizantiski spomenici po Srbiji" (1862). Aleksandar Sandić also published his works in Vienna: "Beseda u spomen pokojnom Nestoru Dimitrijeviću" (1860),"Srpski narodni kalendar za prostu godinu 1863." (1863) and "Beseda na opelu dr-a Vuka Stefanovića Karadzića (29 januara 1864) u Grčkoj crkvi u Beču" (1864).
location_description: Here was Aleksandar Sandić's last address in Vienna, before he moved to Novi Sad in 1865. The building was demolished in 1893.

name: Sečujac von Heldenfeld Arsenije (1720-1814)
entity_description: Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld (1720-1814) was Major General, Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresia and Hofrat in the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. He was born in an officer's family on the Military Frontier. His father was Captain Djordje Sečujac, who was awarded due to his military merits the noble title "von Heldenfeld" on 7 July 1759. Arsenije Sečujac started his military career in 1741. On 30 April 1762 he received the Knight's Cross of the Military Order of Maria Theresia and in 1767 he was raised to the noble rank of Baron. In 1783 Arsenije Sečujac was promoted to the rank of Major General and in the same year he retired and moved to Vienna. Arsenije Sečujac was named Hofrat in the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna, where he worked until his death in 1814. According to Dositej Obradović (1739-1811) Arsenije Sečujac helped the Serbs in Vienna very much. His doors were always open for every Serb, who had come to Vienna. Arsenije Sečujac died on 13 January 1814 in his apartment Wollzeile 914 (today Wollzeile 14, 1010 Vienna) at the age of 94 and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_name: Apartment of Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld
location_description: Here was the last living place of Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld (1720-1814), an Austrian Major General of Serbian origin, where he died on 13 January 1814. The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1882.

name: Sečujac von Heldenfeld Arsenije (1720-1814)
entity_description: Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld (1720-1814) was Major General, Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresia and Hofrat in the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. He was born in an officer's family on the Military Frontier. His father was Captain Djordje Sečujac, who was awarded due to his military merits the noble title "von Heldenfeld" on 7 July 1759. Arsenije Sečujac started his military career in 1741. On 30 April 1762 he received the Knight's Cross of the Military Order of Maria Theresia and in 1767 he was raised to the noble rank of Baron. In 1783 Arsenije Sečujac was promoted to the rank of Major General and in the same year he retired and moved to Vienna. Arsenije Sečujac was named Hofrat in the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna, where he worked until his death in 1814. According to Dositej Obradović (1739-1811) Arsenije Sečujac helped the Serbs in Vienna very much. His doors were always open for every Serb, who had come to Vienna. Arsenije Sečujac died on 13 January 1814 in his apartment Wollzeile 914 (today Wollzeile 14, 1010 Vienna) at the age of 94 and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_name: Apartment of Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld
location_description: Here was the last living place of Baron Arsenije Sečujac von Heldenfeld (1720-1814), an Austrian Major General of Serbian origin, where he died on 13 January 1814. The original building was demolished and a new one was built in 1882.

name: Stanišić Aleksandar (1849-1899)
entity_description: Aleksandar Stanišić (1849-1899) was a Viennese merchant of Serbian origin. In 1869 he published an advertising in "Zastava", in which he appears as "Wäschwar-Fabrikant" with his store in Wollzeile 9 (1010 Vienna). He died in his apartment in Leonhardgasse 22 (1030 Vienna) on 4 April 1899.
picture_description:
Zastava, 14.12.1869.

Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.
location_description: Here the Serbian merchant Aleksandar Stanišić (1849-1899) had his store ("Wäschwar-Fabrikant") since 1869.

name: Obrenović Miloš Prince (1780-1860)
entity_description:
Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) was the leader of the Second Serbian Uprising (1815-1817) against the Ottoman Empire, ruler of Serbia (1815-1839 and 1858-1860) and founder of the Obrenović Dynasty. Under his rule Serbia became an autonomous principality within the Ottoman Empire. During his reign the modernisation of Serbia had begun through numerous reforms (first schools, courts, administration, publishing houses, the first Constitution in 1835, church reforms etc.).
Miloš Obrenović lived in Vienna with interruption from 1841 to 1858. In this period he had contact not only with many renowned Viennese Serbs (e.g. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, Djura Daničić...), but also with other important Slavs and Orthodox personalities in Vienna as well – especially with the Greek families Sina, Dumba and Tirka and with the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884).
picture_description:
Painting of Prince Miloš Obrenović from 1848.

Cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MilosObrenovic_1848.jpg
location_description: This palace was a gift to Prince Mihailo Obrenović by his father Prince Miloš Obrenović. The house was in possession of the Obrenović family from 1855, and after Prince Mihailo's divorce from Princess Julie in 1865, she received this house with an estimated value of 100,000 ducats. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Obrenović Mihailo Prince (1823-1868)
entity_description:
Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was born on 16 September 1823 in Kragujevac (today Serbia). He was Prince of Serbia from 1838 to 1842, and after his exile from 1860 to his assassination on 10 June 1868 in Belgrade. His second rule was characterised by the liberation of Serbian cities from Ottoman garrisons, which was a great diplomatic effort and success. It was also his idea to create a Balkan Federation against the Ottoman Empire. Mihailo Obrenović was an enlightened ruler who travelled through Europe during his period of exile (1844-1850). He wanted to incorporate many of the Western European achievements into Serbian society. Mihailo Obrenović died childless in 1868. He was succeeded by his cousin, Milan Obrenović (1854-1901), whose grandfather was Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), a brother of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Prince Mihailo's uncle.
Prince Mihailo Obrenović lived in Vienna with some interruptions between 1843 and 1860. He was the friend and supporter of many Serbian poets and writers in Vienna, starting with Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), on whose recommendation the Prince travelled through the German states and met Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886) and Jacob Grimm (1785-1863), then Anastas Jovanović (1817-1899), Djura Daničić (1825-1882), Branko Radičević (1824-1853), etc. In July 1853 Djura Daničić returned to Vienna on the Prince's invitation to be a teacher of the Serbian language for the Princess Julie Obrenović (1831-1919).
Prince Mihailo Obrenović was also best man and godfather of the family of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in Vienna. On 10 May 1854 the Prince was best man at the wedding of Djordje Stratimirović in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, and then he and later the Prince and King Milan Obrenović were godfathers of the Stratimirović children. There are also several compositions of famous Austrian composers, which were dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović: Johann Strauss Son op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" from 1846; Phillip Fahrbach Senior op. 151 "Serben Polka" from 1853  and Johann Dubez Op. 17 "Divertissement sur des motifs de l'Opéra: Ernani pour la Zither". He married Countess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919) in the Russian Orthodox chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna on 1 August 1853. His best man was the Russian diplomat Peter von Meyendorff (1796-1863). The Austrian newspapers wrote that the Prince was dressed in national costume and had a sabre with diamonds worth 80,000 florins. On the other side the Princess wore a diamond diadem. They lived in the "Obrenovic-Palais" in Vienna and the Castle of "Ivanka" near Bratislava (Ivanka pri Dunaji, today Slovakia). They separated by a signed agreement on 18 November 1865. The house in Vienna (estimated to be worth 100,000 ducats) and also the Castle of "Ivanka" became a property of the Princess and she received a yearly allocation of 5,500 ducats.
location_description: This palace was a gift to Prince Mihailo Obrenović by his father Prince Miloš Obrenović. The house was in possession of the Obrenović family from 1855, and after Prince Mihailo's divorce from Princess Julie in 1865, she received this house with an estimated value of 100,000 ducats. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Stanković Kornelije (1831-1865)
entity_description: Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865) was a Serbian composer, conductor and pianist. He was born in Buda (today Hungary) on 23 August 1831. Since 1850 he studied in Vienna under the guidance of Professor Simon Sechter (1788-1867). In the years 1851 and 1852 he published the two volumes of his liturgical composition "Liturgy". Kornelije Stanković also released in Vienna one of his main works entitled "Serbian Folk Songs" ("Српске народне песме", 1859, 1862, 1863) and  also three books on the Orthodox Church Chant of the Serbian People ("Православно црквено појање у српског народа“, 1862, 1863, 1864). Kornelije Stanković's importance for the development in music among the Serbs is enormous. He belonged to the Serbian circle around Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) in Vienna, for whose collected folk songs he composed the respective music. The first appereance of Kornelije Stanković as a composer and conductor was most probably in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna). Apart from being friend with many prominent Viennese Serbs, Kornelije Stanković was also a good friend of the Russian Orthodox priest in Vienna, Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884). On the feast of St. Sava (27 January) in 1859 Kornelije Stanković performed his "Liturgy" in the Russian Orthodox chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna (Walfischgasse 5, 1010 Vienna). One of his most important Viennese concerts was a charity concert of spiritual music in the Viennese Musikverein (then in Tuchlauben 12, 1010 Vienna) on 1 April 1861. The entire revenue was given for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna. Kornelije Stanković left Vienna in 1854 and lived in Belgrade in the years 1862 and 1863. He died in Buda on 5 April 1865.
picture_description:
Kornelije Stanković, Lithograph by Anastas Jovanović (Vienna 1851).

Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske
http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/818
location_description: One of the most important Viennese concerts of Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865) was a charity concert of spiritual music in the Viennese Musikverein (then in Tuchlauben 12, 1010 Vienna) on 1 April 1861. The entire revenue was given for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna.

name: Milanković David (1833-1912)
entity_description: David Milanković (1833-1912) lived with his cousin Miloš Milankovć (1828-?) in Wieden 931 (today Mayerhofgasse 7, 1040 Vienna). David Milanković was born in Dalj (today Croatia) in 1833. He was the uncle of the famous scientist Milutin Milanković (1879-1958). After finishing his Law Studies at the University of Vienna, he worked as a jugde. David Milanković died in Zagreb in 1912 and left almost all of his property as a charity to Serbian cultural institutions and societies.
location_description: Here lived David Milanković together with his cousin Miloš during their studies of Law in Vienna.

name: Ilić Mihailo (1823-1885)
entity_description: Mihailo Ilić (1823-1885) was a jeweler, goldsmith and inventor born in Baja (today Hungary) in 1823. He was the owner of several privileges for patents in the field of watch systems. In 1854 his address was Mariahilferstraße 121 (1060 Vienna) and in 1856 Wieden No. 725. Mihailo Ilić had a store in Wipplingerstraße 35 (1010 Vienna). He was awarded with medals at the Zagreb exhibition of 1871 and also with one Viennese medal. Mihailo Ilić died in Alserstraße 4 (1090 Vienna) at the age of 62 on 23 April 1885 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna). His son was the famous Viennese sculptor Aleksandar Ilić (1860-1943).
location_description: Here Mihailo Ilić (1823-1885), a jeweler, goldsmith and inventor, had his store. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Stojaković Djordje (1810-1863)
entity_description: Djordje Stojaković (1810-1863) was an official ("Hofrat") at the Supreme Court in Vienna since 1856, a "Sektionschef" in the Hungarian Court Chancellery since 1861 and also the first President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. His role in the founding of this community in 1860 was crucial.  Djordje Stojaković led the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) on 13 December 1860. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his approval for the founding of the Serbian Orthodox Community of St. Sava. Djordje Stojaković studied Law in Pest (today Hungary), where he was promoted to Dr of Law in 1833. After that he worked as a lawyer and official in Pest and Timișoara (today Romania). He also took a part in the first Slavic Congress in Prague in 1848 and played an important role among the Serbs in the revolutionary years of 1848-1849 as well as in the establishment of the Serbian autonomous region ("Vojvodstvo Srbija"), which existed as a province of the Austrian Empire from 1849 to 1860. In 1856 Emperor Franz Joseph I honored him with the title of Knight of the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd class. Djordje Stojaković was a deputy at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in 1848 and 1861, where he presented his views on the issue of Vojvodina ("Vojvodstvo Srbija"), which he also introduced to the Emperor Franz Joseph I during an audience in 1862. Djordje Stojaković  died in his apartment in Salesianergasse 2 (1030 Vienna) on 28 November 1863 and was buried three days later in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna) in the presence of several ministers, among whom was also Anton von Schmerling (1805-1893).
location_description: Here died Djordje Stojaković, an official ("Hofrat") at the Supreme Court in Vienna, a "Sektionschef" in the Hungarian Court Chancellery and also the first President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna, on 28 November 1863.

name: Ilkić Jovan (1857-1917)
entity_description: Jovan Ilkić (1857-1917) was a Serbian architect born in Zemun in 1857. He studied Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") as a student of the famous Theophil von Hansen (1813-1891) from 1876 to 1883. In 1883 Jovan Ilkić moved to Belgrade, where he worked as an engineer in the Ministry of Construction until 1910. After one year spent in Budapest, Jovan Ilkić returned to Belgrade and worked as an independent architect. His most important works in Belgrade are amongst others: Stari dvor (the Royal Residence), the Houses of Parliament, the house of Aleksa Krsmanović and Hotel Moskva. Jovan Ilkić died in an internment camp in Neusiedl am See (Nežider) in 1917.
location_description: Here lived Jovan Ilkić (1857-1917), a Serbian architect, during his studies at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste")  in 1876.

name: Vojinović de Užički Djordje (1833-1895)
entity_description: Djordje Vojinović de Užički (1833-1895) was a Serbian Count, politician and member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament. He was born in Herceg Novi (today Montenegro) in a noble family. Djordje Vojinović studied Law in Vienna and Padua from 1851 to 1853. Djordje Vojinović de Užički studied together with his brother Konstantin in Vienna. They lived at that time in Wieden 15 (today Wiedner Hauptstraße 25, 1040 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore). He was mayor of Herceg Novi and member of the Dalmatian Parliament since 1867, its Vice-President  from 1870 to 1876 and its President from 1877 to 1895. Djordje Vojinović was also elected two times as member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Parliament in Vienna from 1870 to 1873 and from 1879 to 1891. He became a member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament in 1892. He had very good relations with Serbian diplomats in Vienna as well as with King Nikola of Montenegro (1841-1921) and King Milan Obrenović of Serbia (1854-1901). After the split in the National Party he was one of the founders of the Serbian Independent Party ("Srpska Samostalna Stranka") in the Dalmatian Parliament. In 1884 he received the Commander's Cross of the Order of Franz Josef. Djordje Vojinović died in Zadar (today Croatia) in 1895 and was buried in the Serbian Orthodox Monastery of Savina in his hometown Herceg Novi. He was decorated with the Serbian Grand Officer's Order of Takovo. Djordje Vojinović was a friend of Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria (1858-1889) and helped him to buy the island of Lokrum near Dubrovnik.
picture_description: Carl Georg Friedrich Heyer von Rosenfeld, Wappenbuch des Königreichs Dalmatien (Nürnberg 1873), Tafel 15.
location_description:
Djordje Vojinović de Užički (1833-1895) was elected two times as member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Parliament in Vienna from 1870 to 1873 and from 1879 to 1891. He became a member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament in 1892.

From 1901 to 1907 Andrija Vujatović Šarov (1841-1934) was a member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna.

name: Milanković Miloš (1828-?)
entity_description: Miloš Milankovć (1828-?) was from the famous Serbian family Milanković from Dalj (today Croatia). He studied Law at the University of Vienna since 1850. During his studies he lived with his cousin David Milanković (1833-1912) and Jovan Živković Fruškogorski (1826-1902) in Wieden 38 (today Paniglgasse 4, 1040 Vienna).
location_name: Apartment of Jovan Živković and Miloš Milanković
location_description: Here lived Miloš Milanković and Jovan Živković Fruškogorski during their studies of Law in Vienna. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Ivačković Svetozar (1844-1925)
entity_description: Svetozar Ivačković (1844-1925) was born on 10 December 1844 in Deliblato (today Serbia). He studied Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1869 to 1874 and was a student of the famous Theophil von Hansen (1813-1891). During his studies he received two awards, namely the "Preisstipendium Kunstausstellungsfond" in 1870 (300 florins) and the "Pein-Preis" in 1871. During his studies he lived in Hechtengasse 8 (today Rienößlgasse, 1040 Vienna, does not exist anymore). After finishing his studies, Svetozar Ivačković moved to Belgrade, where he worked in the Ministry of Construction as an engineer. He was a corresponding member of the Serbian Royal Academy. Svetozar Ivačković designed many churches and chapels (one of the most important is the Church of the Transfiguration of Jesus Christ in Pančevo, 1874-1877 ) as well as private houses and the Ministry of Justice in Belgrade (1884). Svetozar Ivačković died in Belgrade on 30 January 1924.
location_description: Here lived Svetozar Ivačković (1844-1925), a Serbian architect, during his studies at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") in 1874. The original building in Hechtengasse 8 (today Rienößlgasse, 1040 Vienna) does not exist anymore.

name: Ostojić Djordje (1831-1901)
entity_description: Djordje Ostojić (1831-1901) was a Viennese cattle merchant of Serbian origin. He was one of the founders of the company "Baich & Ostoits" with his son in law Teodor von Bajić (1846-1897) in 1896. Its addresses were Hainburger Straße 21 (1030 Vienna) and St. Marxer Zentral-Viehmarkt  (1030 Vienna). The company donated 300 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna. Djordje Ostojić was married to Danica Teodorović, a daughter of the Viennese wine merchant Mihajlo Djordje Teodorović (1815-1877). Djorjde Ostojić was a member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna for a long time and was also its President from 1888 to 1894. On 22 February 1898 Teodor von Bajić was deleted from the commercial register after his death, and Djordje Ostojić was appointed as only owner of their once joint company "Baich & Ostoits". Djorjde Ostojić died on 18 November 1901 at the age of 70 and was buried in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 20 November 1901. His legal successors were Zora von Bajić (his daughter) and Dušan von Bajić ( his grandson).
picture_description: Family Tomb of Djordje Ostojić in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna). Photograph by Zlatan Stojadinović (2019).
location_description: Here was located the company "Baich & Ostoits", which was founded in 1896.

name: Subotić Jelisaveta Savka (1834-1918)
entity_description: Jelisaveta Savka Subotić (1834-1918) was born in the family Polit of Greek origin in Novi Sad (today Serbia). She was a philanthropist and one of the most important supporters of women in her time. Jelisaveta Subotić was one of the founders of the "Kolo Srpskih sestara" ("Circle of Serbian Sisters"), one of the oldest humanitarian and patriotic societies of women among the Serbs, which still exists today in Serbia as well as in the Serbian diaspora worldwide. She established the first female charity in Novi Sad which supported young women in their education. Since 1849 her family lived in Vienna, where she met Jovan Subotić (1817-1886). They married in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna) on 1 May 1851. At the wedding were present Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) with his family, Djordje Stojaković (1810-1863), Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865), the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884) and Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868). Their best men were the lawyer and official Pavle Trifunac (1796-1882) and the Viennese merchant Jovan Vladislav. Their first child Dejan was born in Vienna on 7 May 1852. Jelisaveta Subotić held lectures in the Viennese Scientific Club ("Wissenschaftlicher Club") on the status of women in Serbia and in the Balkan Peninsula entitled "Nationale, soziale und Frauenfrage" (15 December 1910) and "Die Frau im Orient" (30 November 1911).
location_name: Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity
location_description:
The Greek Orthodox Confraternity of the Holy Trinity (Ἑλληνικὴ Κοινότης  Ἁγίας Τριάδος) was founded by the Greeks with Austrian citizenship in 1787. The Confraternity bought a house in Fleischmarkt 13 (1010 Vienna), which was transformed into a church by the architect Peter Mollner (1732-1801). The Confraternity received imperial privileges by the Habsburg emperors Joseph II (1741-1790) in 1787 and by Franz II (1768-1835) in 1796. The renovation of the Church of the Holy Trinity took place in 1833 and from 1856 to 1858. The renovation in the 1850s was mostly financed by Baron Simon von Sina (1810-1876), who donated an amount of 70,000 florins. The renowned architect Theophil von Hansen (1813-1891) created a facade and church spire in Neo-Byzantine-style, which the Viennese population called "Das goldene Haus" ("The Golden House"). The church's last renovation was undertaken from 1989 to 1993.
Jovan Subotić (1817-1886) and Jelisaveta Savka Subotić (1834-1918) married in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity on 1 May 1851. At the wedding were present Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) with his family, Djordje Stojaković (1810-1863), Kornelije Stanković (1831-1865), the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884) and Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868). Their best men were the lawyer and official Pavle Trifunac (1796-1882) and the Viennese merchant Jovan Vladislav.
On 10 May 1854 Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was best man at the wedding of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity.
Cezar Popović (1876-1938), a Viennese architect and artist, was baptised in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) on 21 March 1876. In 1890 a memorial service was celebrated in the church for the Austrian General and nobleman Gavrilo Rodić (1812-1890).

name: Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota Maks
entity_description: Maks Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota was a civil servant and the son of Djordje Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota (1843-1908). He was born in Vienna in 1864 and studied Law at the University of Vienna between 1884 and 1888. He received the title of "Hofrat" in 1911 and was honored with the title of "Sektionschef" in May 1914. He was deputy chief of the provincial government ("Landesregierung") in Bosnia and Herzegovina since 1917. Djurković married Angelina Stefanija Andjelić in Budapest on 20 March 1898. Persida, their daughter, was born on 6 March 1899 and baptised in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 1 May 1899. Djurković was awarded with the Commander's Cross ("Komturkreuz") 1st Class of the Saxon Albrecht Order in 1915. Djurković was honored with the title of "Geheimrat" in December 1917. Furthermore, he received the Order of the Iron Crown 2nd class in 1916. He was awarded the "Kriegskreuz für Zivilverdienste" 1st class in 1917. Djurković wrote for the newspaper "Die Presse" and translated the novel of the Serbian writer Laza Lazarević (1851-1891) entitled "Prvi put s ocem na jutrenje" ("Mein erster Gang zur Frühmesse") in "Die Presse" (25 August 1892).
location_name: Family Apartment of the Family Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota
location_description: Here lived Maks Djurković von Rozsa-Lehota between 1884 and 1888.

name: Ivić Aleksandar (1881-1948)
entity_description: Aleksandar "Aleksa" Ivić (1881-1948) was a prominent Serbian historian at the beginning of the 20th century, who contributed remarkably to Serbian historiography, especially on the history of the Serbs in Austria and in Austria-Hungary. He was born in Budjanovci (today Serbia) on 10 December 1881. Aleksandar Ivić studied History and Slavonic Studies at the University of Vienna from 1901 to 1905. He had a scholarship of the Matica Srpska. His professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923), Milan von Rešetar (1860-1942) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). He received his PhD on 20 December 1905. His dissertation dealt with the medieval nobleman Radoslav Pavlović. After his studies Aleksandar "Aleksa" Ivić stayed in Vienna for five years, where he conducted research in the Austrian Archives and published many written sources on the Serbs in the Habsburg Empire. From 1910 to 1912 he was a deputy in the Croatian Parliament, and later he worked in the Archive of Zagreb. After the First World War Aleksandar "Aleksa" Ivić was a Professor of Diplomatic History at the Faculty of Law in Subotica, which was a department of the University of Belgrade. He died in Belgrade on 23 November 1948.
location_description: Here lived the Serbian historian Aleksandar "Aleksa" Ivić (1881-1948) during his studies at the University of Vienna in 1905 .

name: Karadjordjević Aleksandar Prince (1806-1885)
entity_description:
Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević (1806-1885) was the son of Karadjordje Petrović, the leader of the First Serbian Uprising (1804-1815) and founder of the Karadjordjević Dynasty. Following the first rule of Prince Miloš Obrenović and Mihailo Obrenović (1815-1842) Aleksandar Karadjordjević was the ruling Prince of Serbia from the 1842 to 1858. During his reign the reform and modernisation of the Serbian state was accomplished: the foundation of new schools, the Code of Civil Rights (1844), the foundation of the National Library and the National Museum etc. In December 1858, after a disagreement with his Ministers, the National Assembly forced him to abdicate and at the same time Prince Miloš Obrenović was elected to be Prince of Serbia.
Aleksandar Karadjordjević lived in Vienna between 1871 and 1875, when he moved to Timișoara (today Romania). He lived there until the rest of his life and died on 3 May 1885. He was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 8 May 1885 in his uniform with all his decorations next to his wife Princess Persida.  The memorial service was held by Bishop Djordje Branković and 17 other clergymen in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Griechengasse 5 (1010 Vienna). From the church to the cemetery two carriages with flowers, the prince's horse with a black robe, a carriage with the prince's body and his crown, sword and decorations were leading the solemn procession.
location_name: Apartment of Persida and Aleksandar Karadjordjević
location_description: Here lived Princess Persida Karadjordjević and Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević with their grandchildren, the children of their daughter Poleksija, between 1870 and 1872.

name: Nedeljković Vasilije
entity_description: Vasilije Nedeljković was a manufacturer of woven goods in Vienna since 1856. From 1856 until 1862 he was a business partner of Svetozar Stanković in the Company "Nedelkovits & Stankovits". Its address was Lazzenhof 1 (1010 Vienna). In 1865 he founded his own Company "Basil Nedelkovits" in Mariengasse 3 (today Ertlgasse, 1010 Vienna). This company was active until 1871. Vasilije Nedeljković donated 400 florins for the building of the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1862.
location_description: Here was the seat of the Company "Basil Nedelkovits" from 1865 until 1871. The building was built in 1842.

name: Jovanović Pavle Paja (1859-1957)
entity_description: Pavle Paja Jovanović (1859-1957) was one of the most famous Serbian painters. His painting "Bashibozuk" was sold at an auction at Sotheby's in London in April 2018 for £ 465,000. This was the most expensive painting of a Serbian painter to be sold worldwide. Pavle Jovanović studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1877 to 1884, where he received several awards and scholarships. In 1882 he was awarded the first prize in the Academy's annual exhibition and an imperial scholarship for the painting "Wounded Montenegrin". The public and many art critics turned their attention to the young painter, and in 1883 he signed a contract with a gallery in London. Jovanović then travelled through the Caucasus, Morocco, Egypt, Greece, Turkey, Italy and Spain. After spending time in Paris and Munich, Pavle Jovanović stayed in Vienna, where he had his studio at Mariahilferstraße 3 (1060 Vienna). In 1899 he received the Reichel Artist Award at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna for his work "Furor Teutonicus". For the World Fair in Paris in 1900 he painted a great historical composition "The Proclamation of Dušan's Law", for which he received the Golden Award. Since 1905 he almost exclusively painted portraits. He has portrayed almost all famous Serbian scientists, composers and members of the Karadjordjević dynasty. Pavle Jovanović has painted more than ten portraits of Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916). The Emperor's valet Eugen Ketterl describes in his memoirs that Pavle Jovanović was the best painter of the Emperor's portraits. Ketterl writes: "Unter den Kaiserbildern ragen die von Jovanovic geschaffenen Ölgemälde durch künstlerische Vollendung und Ähnlichkeit hervor. (...) Da der Kaiser wenig Zeit zum Sitzen hatte, stellte der Künstler einmal ein Porträt in bloß zwei Stunden fertig. Es war für den Dampfer "Franz Josef I." der Donau-Dampfschiffahrts-Gesellschaft bestimmt, der gelegentlich der Eröffnung der Donaufahrtrinne bei Orsova eingeweiht wurde. Der Dampfer hatte einen wundervollen Speisesaal, der durch verschiebbare Wände in zwei weitere Räume - Schlafzimmer und Arbeitskabinett des Kaisers - abgeteilt werden konnte. Das Gemälde gehört zu den besten, die vom Monarchen existieren. Es stellt ihn in Kampagneuniform (blauem Waffenrock) dar und ist so sprechend ähnlich und naturgetreu, daß man vermeint, den Kaiser aus dem Rahmen heraustreten zu sehen." (Eugen Ketterl, Der alte Kaiser wie nur Einer ihn sah. Der wahrheutsgetreue Bericht des Leibkammerdieners Kaiser Franz Josephs I. Mit 23 Abbildungen. Wien et al. 1980, p. 123) He spent the period between the two World Wars mostly in Belgrade and Vienna. At the end of the 1930s he returned to Belgrade, where he remained until 1946. Pavle Jovanović then moved back to Vienna, where he died in Laudongasse 67 (1080 Vienna) on 30 November 1957.
location_description: Here died the famous Serbian painter Paja Jovanović on 30 November 1957.

name: Vujatović Šarov Andrija (1841-1934)
entity_description: Andrija Vujatović Šarov (1841-1924) was a lawyer and politician. He was born in Knin (today Croatia) on 15 February 1841. From 1864 to 1867 he studied Law in Vienna. From 1880 Andrija Vujatović Šarov worked as a notary in Kistanje (today Croatia). At the end of 1881 he moved to Knin, where he also worked as a notary. As a founding member of the People's Party ("Narodna Stranka") in Dalmatia he was a member in the Dalmatian Parliament from 1876 to 1883. After the split in the People's Party he founded with other Serbs the Serbian People's Party ("Srpska Narodna Stranka") in 1880. From 1901 to 1907 Andrija Vujatović Šarov was a member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna. In response to the Resolution of Fiume (Rijeka) in 1905, he initiated in October of the same year and signed the so-called Zara Resolution, an agreement on the future co-operation between the Serbian and Croatian political parties. After leaving the Parliament in 1907, Andrija Vujatović Šarov worked again as a notary in Knin. He was honored with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1906. In 1912 he also received the Montenegrin Danilo Order 3rd class. Andrija Vujatović Šarov died on 15 November 1924 in Knin and was buried in Vrbnik (today Croatia).
location_description:
Djordje Vojinović de Užički (1833-1895) was elected two times as member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Parliament in Vienna from 1870 to 1873 and from 1879 to 1891. He became a member of the Upper House ("Herrenhaus") in the Austrian Parliament in 1892.

From 1901 to 1907 Andrija Vujatović Šarov (1841-1934) was a member of the Lower House ("Abgeordnetenhaus") of the Austrian Parliament in Vienna.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Mihajlo (1841-1916)
entity_description: Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna (1841-1916) was a landowner and house owner in Vienna and the son of Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) and Jelisaveta-Savka Obrenović (1814-1848), the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). He was married to Gräfin Marianne Kinsky von Wchinitz und Tettau (1854-1938) from 1877 until 1880. An interesting episode occurred on 22 March 1876, when Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna paid a fine of 10 florins, because of driving too fast with his carriage through Kärntnerstraße (1010 Vienna). In February 1882 he bought the house in Hegelgasse 8 (1010 Vienna) for 410,000 florins. Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna was the owner of the building in Belvederegasse 6-8 (1040 Vienna) from 1896. He adopted Johann Thierfelder (1884-?) in 1905 and gave him the epithet "von Obrenow" as a reminiscence that the family of Nikolić was a descendant of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). He was also landowner in Banat with 4,630 acres. Baron Mihajlo Nikolić de Rudna died in Vienna in Sanatorium Löw on 21 November 1916.
location_description:
Teodor von Bajić (1846-1897) died in the Sanatorium Löw on 26 March 1897 at the age of 50 and was buried on 28 March in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof) in 1110 Vienna.

Bogdan Medaković (1854-1930), a Serbian politician and lawyer, died also in the Sanatorium Löw in Vienna on 11 May 1930.

Prince Mirko Petrović Njegoš (1879-1918) died in the Sanatorium Löw on 3 March 1918, where he was treated due to his illness since 1916. He was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna) on 14 March 1918 with all military honors.

Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937), a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade, died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.

name: Stanojević Stanoje (1874-1937)
entity_description: Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937) was a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade. He was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia) on 13 August 1874. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, Stanoje Stanojević studied History at the University of Vienna from 1892 to 1896. He lived in Neustiftgasse 97 (1080 Vienna). His professors at University were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). Stanoje Stanojević received his titel of Dr on 16 July 1896. His dissertation is entitled "Die Biographie Stefan Lazarević's von Konstantin dem Philosophen als Geschichtsquelle". From 1903 until his death in 1937 Stanoje Stanojević was Professor at the University of Belgrade. His main field of research was the Serbian medieval history. During the First World War (1914-1918) he was in exile and lectured as a visiting Professor at the Sorbonne in Paris and at London University. At the Paris Peace Conference in the years 1919 and 1920 he was a member of the Serbian delegation in the historical-ethnographic section. Stanoje Stanojević died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.

Teodor von Bajić (1846-1897) died in the Sanatorium Löw on 26 March 1897 at the age of 50 and was buried on 28 March in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof) in 1110 Vienna.

Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937), a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade, died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.

name: Zastavniković Gedeon (1824-1869)
entity_description: Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković (1824-1869) was an Austrian Major General of Serbian origin, who was born in Kula (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in 1824. After his military education in Graz he was adjutant of Ban Josip Jelačić (1801-1859). Later, Gedeon Zastavniković became a commander of the Slunj Regiment and commander of the Militay Frontier. After this duty he went to Vienna, where he worked in the Ministry of War. Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković died on 6 January 1869 at the age of 45 in his apartment Landstraßer Hauptstraße 68 (1030 Vienna) and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Major General Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković (1824-1869) on 6 January 1869 at the age of 45.

name: Zastavniković Gedeon (1824-1869)
entity_description: Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković (1824-1869) was an Austrian Major General of Serbian origin, who was born in Kula (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in 1824. Gedeon Ritter von Zastavniković died on 6 January 1869 at the age of 45 in his apartment Landstraßer Hauptstraße 68 (1030 Vienna) and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).

name: Milanković Bogdan (1884-1966)
entity_description: Bogdan Milanković (1884-1966) was Dr of Philosophy and a musician. He was born in Dalj (today Croatia) on 31 December 1884. His brother was the famous scientist Milutin Milanković (1879-1958). After attending grammar school in Osijek (today Croatia), Bogdan Milanković studied Philosophy in Vienna since 1903. In 1904 he moved to Paris, where he finished his Romanistic studies, and then came back to Vienna, where he received the title of Dr of Philosophy in 1908. Bogdan Milanković was a corresponding member of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts (SANU) since 1958. He died in Sarajevo (today Bosnia and Herzegovina), where he was Professor of music and founder of the Sarajevo Philharmonic Orchestra on 10 July 1966.
location_description: Here lived Bogdan Milanković (1884-1966), the brother of the famous scientist Milutin Milanković (1879-1958), in 1908.

name: Milekić von Carlowizgrad Jovan (1817-1877)
entity_description: Jovan Milekić von Carlowizgrad (1817-1877) was a Serbian officer and deputy at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci  who was born in Sremska Mitrovica (today Serbia) in 1817. Jovan's father Djordje, a merchant from Sremska Mitrovica, was ennobled with the title "von Carlowizgrad" on 14 July 1850. Jovan Milekić von Carlowizgrad lived in Schleifmühlgasse 8 (1040 Vienna), where he died on 14 July 1877 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Major Jovan Milekić von Carlowizgrad (1817-1877); work of Anastas Jovanović, ca. 1851.
Muzej Grada Beograda, AJ 903.
location_name: Apartment of Jovan Milekić von Carlowizgrad
location_description: Here died Jovan Milekić von Carlowizgrad (1817-1877), Serbian officer, nobleman and landowner from Sremska Mitrovica (today Serbia), on 14 July 1877.
