location_description: After numerous applications Dimitrije Davidović received a privilege to print books in Oriental languages in 1818. His printing house was active until 1822. Its address was Alter Fleischmarkt 746. This house was popularly called "Darvarhof", named after the owner, a Greek merchant from the Darvar family. After the renumeration it was Fleischmarkt 5, but this building was demolished at the beginning of the 20th century.

name: Kapamadžija Nikola (1851-1908)
entity_description:
Nikola Kapamadžija (1851-1908) was a merchant, newspaper editor, commercial school director and President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Comunity Council of St. Sava in Vienna from 1897 to 1907. Nikola Kapamadžija was born on 22 February 1851 in Pančevo (today Serbia) and was married to Marie since 23 May 1885. He was the owner of the house in Millergasse 43 (1060 Vienna; the building does not exist anymore) together with his wife Marie. They bought this house in 1900. In the same year they purchased the house in Bürgerspitalgasse 30 (1060 Vienna). Nikola Kapamadžija was also a member of the association of houseowners in the sixth Viennese disctrict. In this building he founded a commercial school ("Handelsschule"), himself being the director. Apart from the school there was also a dorm for the students. In 1900 he was honored with the Serbian St. Sava Order. The school was renamed after 30 years in 1911, and since then it was known as "Mariahilfer Handelsschule". Members of the school  board were amongst others Dr. M. Jakovljević and Marie Kapamadžija.
Nikola Kapamadžija was the owner and editor of the journal "Mlada Srbadija". The journal was published only for a short period of time starting from January 1876. The first issue on 1 January 1876 showed a picture of Svetozar Miletić, the political leader of the Serbs in the region of Vojvodina. The content was rich and manifold, e.g. texts by Jovan Stefanović Vilovski and Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, poems and biographies. The journal was planned to be published three times a month and printed in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery (Mechitaristengasse 4, 1070 Vienna). Only three issues were printed, all of them in January 1876. Nikola Kapamadžija died in his house at the age of 57 on 24 January 1908 and was buried in the Serbian part 68B of the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_description: “Mlada Srbadija” was a short-time published journal from January 1876. The owner and editor was Nikola Kapamadžija. The first issue from 1 January 1876 had a picture of Svetozar Miletić, the political leader of the Serbs in Vojvodina. The content was rich and manifold: texts from Jovan Stefanović Vilovski and Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, poems and biographies. The journal was planned to be published three times a month and printed in the Mechitarist Monastery printing house. Only three issues were published, all of them in January 1876.The address of the editorial office was Ottakringer Hauptstrasse 9, but the building does not exists anymore.

name: Stefanović Vilovski Todor (1854-1921)
entity_description:
Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), the son of Jovan Stefanović Vilovski (1821-1902) and Emilija (né Tamburić, 1836-1917), moved to Vienna with his parents in 1867, when he was 13 years old. He edited the newspapers "Srbadija" (1875-1877) and "Srpska Zora" (1876-1881) in Vienna, whose owner he was. Todor Stefanović Vilovski was a prominent figure among the Viennese Serbs. From 1875 to 1881 he was the President of the Serbian Students' Association "Zora". In 1879 he was named as deputy and secretary of the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). Todor Stefanović Vilovski met his future wife Camilla von Ottenfeld in the building, where both families lived (Burggasse 24, 1080 Vienna). They married in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in Fleischmarkt (1010 Vienna) on 5 February 1885. His best man was the Austrian and then Serbian General Djura Horvatović (1835-1895). Since 1887 Todor Stefanović Vilovski was a corresponding member of the Anthropological Society in Vienna. In 1881 he moved from Vienna to Belgrade, where he became the editor of the newspaper "Videlo" and director of the Serbian Press Bureau (1881-1887 and 1912-1915). Because of political issues he returned to Vienna in 1887, where he stayed until 1895. Todor Stefanović Vilovski was director of the Serbian Post and Telegraph until 1899, when he moved again to Vienna after a conflict with the Prime Minister Vladan Djordjević (1844-1930). This time he stayed in Vienna until 1909. He lived in Belgrade from 1909 to 1915, when he was arrested after the Austro-Hungarian occupation of Serbia and sent to Vienna.  He died on 9 January 1921. In his memoirs "Iz moga života" he narrates important information, not only about his life in Vienna, but also about the Serbian community and the social life of the Serbs in Vienna.
Here are some examples: Vilovski's grandfather, Djordje Tamburić, was a frequent guest at Mayreder's Serbian café, located in Rotenturmstraße (1010 Vienna), until his death. He died in 1881 and was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). As other meeting places of the Viennese Serbs Todor Stefanović Vilovski mentions the "Mirakelkeller" (Haarhof, Rotenturmstraße 16, 1010 Vienna) and "Zu den drei Raben" (Rotenturmstraße 21, 1010 Vienna). The friends and supporters of Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) gathered in the "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich") of Аndrija Gerlović in Bauernmarkt (1010 Vienna) every afternoon.
Todor Stefanović Vilovski met Felix Kanitz (1829-1904) in the house of Wilhelmine-Mina Karadžić (1828-1894) in 1869. Felix Kanitz was a faithful friend of Vuk's family for the rest of his life in recognition of Vuk's support for his scholarly work in Serbia. Based on Kanitz's recommendation, Todor Stefanović Vilovski became a correspondent on the Balkans and Serbian literature in the Augsburger Allgemeine Zeitung for the duration of ten years and also one of the authors of Baron Joseph Alexander von Helfert's (1820-1910) "Die Völker Österreich-Ungarns" (1880). The 11th volume of this series is entitled "Die Serben in Dalmatien und im Südlichen Ungarn, in Bosnien und im Herzegowina" and was written by Todor Stefanović Vilovski. Vilovski's book "Aus Belgrads Vergangenheit" (Vienna, Druck und Verlag Adolf Holzhausen, 1894) is also of great significance, because the Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) himself in person took it for the Imperial Library (today the National Library of Austria in Vienna) and thanked the author.
location_description: "Srbadija" was an illustrated journal, which was printed on a monthly basis in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation from 26 October 1874 (first issue) until 1 March 1877 (last issue). It had 18 issues in total. The editorial office was in Ungargasse 2 (1030 Vienna; the building does not exist anymore). The first owner and publisher of "Srbadija" was Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), its editor Srećko Majer. Starting with issue No. 2 the owner and publisher was Stevan Ćurčić, the editor Srećko Majer. Since 1876 (issue No. 5) the owner and publisher was Stevan Ćurčić, the editor Franja Ptačovski, and the journal was printed in the Bulgarian printing house of Janko Kovačev. The last issue of 1877 was coordinated by the owner, publisher and editor Jovan F. Lulej.

name: Mandrović Konstantin Kosta (1840-1920)
entity_description:
Konstantin Kosta Mandrović (1840-1920) was a Viennese publisher, writer and journalist of Serbian origin, born in Nova Gradiška on 17 August 1840. He married Barbara Kastner on 20 April 1877. Mandrović worked in A. Hartleben's publishing house from 1876 for more than 40 years. Konstantin Kosta Mandrović published the Serbian edition of Robinson Crusoe in Vienna in 1873. He wrote the chapter entitled "Der serbische Buchhandel in Ungarn" in "Österreich-Ungarische Buchhändler-Korrespondenz. Festnummer anlässlich des 50 jährigen Bestehens 1860-1910". Mandrović published also two books on Serbian history in Vienna: "Ilustrovana istorija srpskog naroda od najstarijih vremena do proglašenja nove kraljevine: Sa 120 slika i jednom kartom Balkanskog poluostrova" (1885) and "Ilustrovana istorija srpskog naroda od najstarijih vremena do XIX veka za narod i školu" (1903).
Mandrović died in family apartment in Neulinggasse 25 (1030) on 28 December 1920 and was buried two days later on Serbian part 68B in Viennese Central Cemetery. His wife Barbara was born in Aspern on 22 August 1841. She died in same apartment on 25 Januaary 1922 and was buried next to her husband three days later
picture_description: Tombstone of family Mandrović in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof) in 1110 Vienna. Photograph by Zlatan Stojadinović (2019).
location_description: "Srpska Zora" was a Serbian illustrated journal, which was published monthly from 1876 to 1881, having a total of 44 issues. The first issue was edited on 1 January 1876. The owner and publisher was Konstantin Kosta Mandrović (1840-1920), the editor Mita Georgiević. The address of the editorial office was in the beginning Pragerstraße 13 (1030 Vienna) and, starting with the third issue, Gärtnergasse 24 (1030 Vienna). The owner of "Srpska zora", starting with the fourth issue, was Todor Stefanović Vilovski (1854-1921), and the publisher Konstantin Kosta Mandrović. With Issue No. 6 the address of the editorial office was was Burggasse 24 (1070). "Srpska Zora" had a patriotic content, which becomes evident through the war illustrations of the Ottoman-Serbian wars 1876-1878. Apart from that poems and novels of the most famous Serbian authors were published in this journal, like those of Djura Jakšić, Stjepan Mitrov Ljubiša, Jakov Ignjatović, Milorad Šapčanin, Jovan Jovanović Zmaj, Prince Nikola Petrović of Montenegro, Laza Kostić, Laza Lazarević and many others. In 1877 the journal had 1,000 subscribers, and since 1878 novels of European authors like Turgenjev, Keller, Sacher-Masoch etc. were published in translation in every issue. The journal was printed in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation and later in the printing house of Janko Kovačev.

name: Obrenović Mihailo Prince (1823-1868)
entity_description:
Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was born on 16 September 1823 in Kragujevac (today Serbia). He was Prince of Serbia from 1838 to 1842, and after his exile from 1860 to his assassination on 10 June 1868 in Belgrade. His second rule was characterised by the liberation of Serbian cities from Ottoman garrisons, which was a great diplomatic effort and success. It was also his idea to create a Balkan Federation against the Ottoman Empire. Mihailo Obrenović was an enlightened ruler who travelled through Europe during his period of exile (1844-1850). He wanted to incorporate many of the Western European achievements into Serbian society. Mihailo Obrenović died childless in 1868. He was succeeded by his cousin, Milan Obrenović (1854-1901), whose grandfather was Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), a brother of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Prince Mihailo's uncle.
Prince Mihailo Obrenović lived in Vienna with some interruptions between 1843 and 1860. He was the friend and supporter of many Serbian poets and writers in Vienna, starting with Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), on whose recommendation the Prince travelled through the German states and met Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886) and Jacob Grimm (1785-1863), then Anastas Jovanović (1817-1899), Djura Daničić (1825-1882), Branko Radičević (1824-1853), etc. In July 1853 Djura Daničić returned to Vienna on the Prince's invitation to be a teacher of the Serbian language for the Princess Julie Obrenović (1831-1919).
Prince Mihailo Obrenović was also best man and godfather of the family of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in Vienna. On 10 May 1854 the Prince was best man at the wedding of Djordje Stratimirović in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, and then he and later the Prince and King Milan Obrenović were godfathers of the Stratimirović children. There are also several compositions of famous Austrian composers, which were dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović: Johann Strauss Son op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" from 1846; Phillip Fahrbach Senior op. 151 "Serben Polka" from 1853  and Johann Dubez Op. 17 "Divertissement sur des motifs de l'Opéra: Ernani pour la Zither". He married Countess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919) in the Russian Orthodox chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna on 1 August 1853. His best man was the Russian diplomat Peter von Meyendorff (1796-1863). The Austrian newspapers wrote that the Prince was dressed in national costume and had a sabre with diamonds worth 80,000 florins. On the other side the Princess wore a diamond diadem. They lived in the "Obrenovic-Palais" in Vienna and the Castle of "Ivanka" near Bratislava (Ivanka pri Dunaji, today Slovakia). They separated by a signed agreement on 18 November 1865. The house in Vienna (estimated to be worth 100,000 ducats) and also the Castle of "Ivanka" became a property of the Princess and she received a yearly allocation of 5,500 ducats.
location_description: Here stood the famous guesthouse "Fetzer" until 1956. Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) lived here in the 1840s with his family. In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Obrenović Milan King (1854-1901)
entity_description: Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) was a ruling Prince (1868-1882) and King of Serbia (1882-1889). He was born in Mărășești (today Romania) on 22 August 1854. He succeeded his cousin Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) in 1868. During his rule Serbia became an independent state after two Serbian-Ottoman Wars (1876-1878) and was internationally recognised by the Treaty of Berlin (1878). His reign was also a period of modernisation. Milan Obrenović abdicated in 1889, and his 13 year old son Aleksandar Obrenović (1876-1903) became King. After the abdication Milan Obrenović lived in Paris and in 1897 returned to Serbia, where he was installed as the commander-in-chief of the Serbian army. After a disagreement regarding his son's wedding with Draga Mašin (1864-1903) he left Serbia. Milan Obrenović settled in Vienna. From autumn 1900 he lived firstly in the Hotel Imperial and then in an apartment in Johannesgasse 16 (1010 Vienna). Here died Milan Obrenović on 11 February 1901. He was a close friend of the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916), who awarded to him the Grand Cross of the Austrian Imperial Order of Leopold ("Großkreuz des Leopoldordens") on 7 January 1870. The 97th Infantry Regiment of the Austro-Hungarian Army (Küstenländisch-krainerisches Infanterieregiment Nr. 97) was named after him in 1883 (until 1892). There are several compositions of Austrian composers, which were dedicated to King Milan Obrenović: two compositions to King Milan and Queen Natalija by Philipp Fahrbach Junior (1884), the "King Milan March" by Anton Riedl (1885) and three songs by Carl Streitmann (1887).
location_description: The betrothal of Prince Milan and Princess Natalija was on 7 August 1875 in Grand Hotel. Among the guests were: Prince Milan´s mother, Maria, Princess Julie, the Serbian Prime Minister Marinković and diplomatic representative in Vienna Cukić.

name: Karadžić Stefanović Vuk (1787-1864)
entity_description:
Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) was a Serbian philologist and linguist and greatest reformer of the Serbian language. He became also well known for his collection of Serbian folk songs, fairy tailes and riddles. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić lived and worked in Vienna for more than 50 years. He moved there in 1813 after the end of the First Serbian Uprising (1804-1813) against the Ottoman Empire. In Vienna Vuk Stefanović Karadžić met Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), a Slovenian philologist and censor at the Imperial Library, who encouraged Vuk in his collection of folk material. Vuk met Dimitrije Davidović, Dimitrije Frušić and Sava Mrkalj in Pest and stayed in contact with them also in Vienna. Vuk printed his first book entitled "Pesnarica" (a collection of Serbian folk songs) in Vienna in the Schnierer publishing house in 1,500 copies. In the same year Vuk printed the book "Pismenica"  ("Pismenica serbskoga jezika"), the first grammar of the reformed Serbian language. Vuk published a new edition in 1818, which was translated by the famous German philologist Jacob Grimm (1785-1863) into the German language in 1824 (entitled "Kleine serbische Grammatik"). Grimm was impressed by the Serbian cultural heritage in the form of folk poems and songs. Vuk met Jacob Grimm in 1823 and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832) in his house in Weimar in 1824. Goethe was interested in Serbian folk poetry since the year 1778, when he translated "Hasanaginica", a South Slavic folk ballad. From 1823 to 1827 Goethe translated folk songs from Vuk's books in the journal "Über Kunst und Alterthum", the first one was "Dioba Jakšića" ("Erbschaftsteilung"). Apart from Goethe and Grimm Vuk's folk songs were translated into Czech ("Prostonárodní srbská muza, do Cech převedená", 1817), English ("Servian popular poetry", 1827), Swedish ("Serbiska folksänger", 1830), Hungarian ("Szerb népdalok hősregék", 1836) and into Polish ("Narodowe piesni serbskie", 1853). Kopitar introduced Vuk to Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886), one of the greatest German historians, in 1827. On the basis of Vuk's knowledge of the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire, Ranke published his book on the "Serbian revolution" in 1828.
Vuk's Serbian-German Dictionary, printed in 1818 in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery (Mechitaristengasse 4, 1070 Vienna), was the first book ever printed in the newly reformed Serbian language. Vuk standardised the Serbian Cyrillic alphabet based on the phonemic principle of Johann Christoph Adellung (1732-1806), a great German philologist. His motto was: "Write as you speak, and read as it is written". This book was printed from donations, firstly by Theodor Demeter Tirka (1764-1839), a Greek merchant and banker from Vienna, who was also godfather of Vuk's children.
Vuk married Anna Kraus (1788-1876) in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54-56, 1030 Vienna) on 28 January 1818. His best man was Jernej Kopitar. Vuk's first rented apartment was that of Anna's father, where they met. During his life in Vienna Vuk changed address more than 20 times. The couple had 12 children, but only two of them overlived Vuk: his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina (1828-1894) and his son Dimitrije (1836-1883).
Vuk was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was a friend of Prince Miloš Obrenović and Prince Mihailo Obrenović, Petar Petrović Njegoš, Djura Daničić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, etc. Vuk was also very reputable among all Slavs, his friends and associates were the Russian priest Michail Fjodorowitsch Rajewski (1811-1844), Jernej Kopitar, Josef Dobrovský (1753-1829), František Palacký (1798-1876), Pavel Jozef Šafárik (1795-1861), Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891), etc. Vuk was often guest in the so-called "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich"), also "Zum Weissen Wolfen" (Fleischmarkt 20/Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna), and other places where the Slavs gathered in Vienna.
In 1823 Vuk became honorary Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Jena. In 1826 Vuk received a Russian and in 1835 a Serbian pension. He was very reputable in the Russian Empire. Apart from the pension the Russian Emperor Nikolaj I Pavlovič (1796-1855) honored him with the Gold medal in 1841 and in 1862 he was awarded with the Order of St. Anna 2nd class with crown. Vuk became a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna on 14 January 1848. Three days before he had received a ring with brilliants as a gift of the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I (1793-1875), who thanked him for his book of Serbian folk songs entitled "Srpske Narodne pjesme". In 1850 the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) honored Vuk with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order 3rd class and in 1851 with the Gold Medal for Science. Vuk was also awarded the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle 3rd class in 1852.
Vuk died in his appartment, where he spent his last 15 years of life, in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) on 7 February 1864. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Griechengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) he was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His mortal remains were transferred to Belgrade in 1897, while the tombstone still stands in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery. On the house in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) a memorial plaque was placed in the 1950s, and Vuk’s monument was erected in Rasumofskygasse 22 (1030 Vienna) in 1987.
location_description: The third Slavic Ball took place in the Graziensäle ("Zur goldenen Birne") on 2 February 1846. Among the guests were more than twenty Austrian Counts and Barons (the Prince Schwarzenberg, Thun, Kinsky, etc.). On this occasion Johann Strauss Junior ("Son", 1825-1899) performed his composition op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" for the first time. The composition was dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) and was printed in Vienna in 4,000 pieces. The Graziensäle were demolished in 1876.

name: Obrenović Miloš Prince (1780-1860)
entity_description:
Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) was the leader of the Second Serbian Uprising (1815-1817) against the Ottoman Empire, ruler of Serbia (1815-1839 and 1858-1860) and founder of the Obrenović Dynasty. Under his rule Serbia became an autonomous principality within the Ottoman Empire. During his reign the modernisation of Serbia had begun through numerous reforms (first schools, courts, administration, publishing houses, the first Constitution in 1835, church reforms etc.).
Miloš Obrenović lived in Vienna with interruption from 1841 to 1858. In this period he had contact not only with many renowned Viennese Serbs (e.g. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, Djura Daničić...), but also with other important Slavs and Orthodox personalities in Vienna as well – especially with the Greek families Sina, Dumba and Tirka and with the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884).
picture_description:
Painting of Prince Miloš Obrenović from 1848.

Cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MilosObrenovic_1848.jpg
location_description: The third Slavic Ball took place in the Graziensäle ("Zur goldenen Birne") on 2 February 1846. Among the guests were more than twenty Austrian Counts and Barons (the Prince Schwarzenberg, Thun, Kinsky, etc.). On this occasion Johann Strauss Junior ("Son", 1825-1899) performed his composition op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" for the first time. The composition was dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) and was printed in Vienna in 4,000 pieces. The Graziensäle were demolished in 1876.

name: Obrenović Miloš Prince (1780-1860)
entity_description:
Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) was the leader of the Second Serbian Uprising (1815-1817) against the Ottoman Empire, ruler of Serbia (1815-1839 and 1858-1860) and founder of the Obrenović Dynasty. Under his rule Serbia became an autonomous principality within the Ottoman Empire. During his reign the modernisation of Serbia had begun through numerous reforms (first schools, courts, administration, publishing houses, the first Constitution in 1835, church reforms etc.).
Miloš Obrenović lived in Vienna with interruption from 1841 to 1858. In this period he had contact not only with many renowned Viennese Serbs (e.g. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, Djura Daničić...), but also with other important Slavs and Orthodox personalities in Vienna as well – especially with the Greek families Sina, Dumba and Tirka and with the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884).
picture_description:
Painting of Prince Miloš Obrenović from 1848.

Cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MilosObrenovic_1848.jpg
location_description: Imperial Armory collection of the Kunsthistorisches Museum (Hofjagd- und Rüstkammer). This collection keeps a sword, which was Prince Miloš´s gift to the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I in 1841. The sword is part of the permanent exhibition and it is preserved under the signature HJRK_C_206.

name: Karadžić Stefanović Vuk (1787-1864)
entity_description:
Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) was a Serbian philologist and linguist and greatest reformer of the Serbian language. He became also well known for his collection of Serbian folk songs, fairy tailes and riddles. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić lived and worked in Vienna for more than 50 years. He moved there in 1813 after the end of the First Serbian Uprising (1804-1813) against the Ottoman Empire. In Vienna Vuk Stefanović Karadžić met Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), a Slovenian philologist and censor at the Imperial Library, who encouraged Vuk in his collection of folk material. Vuk met Dimitrije Davidović, Dimitrije Frušić and Sava Mrkalj in Pest and stayed in contact with them also in Vienna. Vuk printed his first book entitled "Pesnarica" (a collection of Serbian folk songs) in Vienna in the Schnierer publishing house in 1,500 copies. In the same year Vuk printed the book "Pismenica"  ("Pismenica serbskoga jezika"), the first grammar of the reformed Serbian language. Vuk published a new edition in 1818, which was translated by the famous German philologist Jacob Grimm (1785-1863) into the German language in 1824 (entitled "Kleine serbische Grammatik"). Grimm was impressed by the Serbian cultural heritage in the form of folk poems and songs. Vuk met Jacob Grimm in 1823 and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832) in his house in Weimar in 1824. Goethe was interested in Serbian folk poetry since the year 1778, when he translated "Hasanaginica", a South Slavic folk ballad. From 1823 to 1827 Goethe translated folk songs from Vuk's books in the journal "Über Kunst und Alterthum", the first one was "Dioba Jakšića" ("Erbschaftsteilung"). Apart from Goethe and Grimm Vuk's folk songs were translated into Czech ("Prostonárodní srbská muza, do Cech převedená", 1817), English ("Servian popular poetry", 1827), Swedish ("Serbiska folksänger", 1830), Hungarian ("Szerb népdalok hősregék", 1836) and into Polish ("Narodowe piesni serbskie", 1853). Kopitar introduced Vuk to Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886), one of the greatest German historians, in 1827. On the basis of Vuk's knowledge of the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire, Ranke published his book on the "Serbian revolution" in 1828.
Vuk's Serbian-German Dictionary, printed in 1818 in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery (Mechitaristengasse 4, 1070 Vienna), was the first book ever printed in the newly reformed Serbian language. Vuk standardised the Serbian Cyrillic alphabet based on the phonemic principle of Johann Christoph Adellung (1732-1806), a great German philologist. His motto was: "Write as you speak, and read as it is written". This book was printed from donations, firstly by Theodor Demeter Tirka (1764-1839), a Greek merchant and banker from Vienna, who was also godfather of Vuk's children.
Vuk married Anna Kraus (1788-1876) in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54-56, 1030 Vienna) on 28 January 1818. His best man was Jernej Kopitar. Vuk's first rented apartment was that of Anna's father, where they met. During his life in Vienna Vuk changed address more than 20 times. The couple had 12 children, but only two of them overlived Vuk: his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina (1828-1894) and his son Dimitrije (1836-1883).
Vuk was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was a friend of Prince Miloš Obrenović and Prince Mihailo Obrenović, Petar Petrović Njegoš, Djura Daničić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, etc. Vuk was also very reputable among all Slavs, his friends and associates were the Russian priest Michail Fjodorowitsch Rajewski (1811-1844), Jernej Kopitar, Josef Dobrovský (1753-1829), František Palacký (1798-1876), Pavel Jozef Šafárik (1795-1861), Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891), etc. Vuk was often guest in the so-called "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich"), also "Zum Weissen Wolfen" (Fleischmarkt 20/Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna), and other places where the Slavs gathered in Vienna.
In 1823 Vuk became honorary Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Jena. In 1826 Vuk received a Russian and in 1835 a Serbian pension. He was very reputable in the Russian Empire. Apart from the pension the Russian Emperor Nikolaj I Pavlovič (1796-1855) honored him with the Gold medal in 1841 and in 1862 he was awarded with the Order of St. Anna 2nd class with crown. Vuk became a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna on 14 January 1848. Three days before he had received a ring with brilliants as a gift of the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I (1793-1875), who thanked him for his book of Serbian folk songs entitled "Srpske Narodne pjesme". In 1850 the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) honored Vuk with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order 3rd class and in 1851 with the Gold Medal for Science. Vuk was also awarded the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle 3rd class in 1852.
Vuk died in his appartment, where he spent his last 15 years of life, in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) on 7 February 1864. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Griechengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) he was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His mortal remains were transferred to Belgrade in 1897, while the tombstone still stands in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery. On the house in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) a memorial plaque was placed in the 1950s, and Vuk’s monument was erected in Rasumofskygasse 22 (1030 Vienna) in 1987.
location_description: Johann Schnierer was a Viennese printer from 1813 to 1818. Amongst others, he printed many Serbian books,for example Vuk Karadzić´s first books in Vienna in 1814, called “Pjesmarica” (Mala prostonarodna slaveno-serbska pjesmarica) and “Pismenica”. His printing house was on in Landstrasse 248. Today it is the address Landstraßer Hauptstraße 92, but the building does not exist anymore.

name: Jeftanović Petar (1832-1855)
entity_description: Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855) was a Serbian merchant who was born in Sarajevo (today Bosnia and Herzegovina). He was the owner of the Company "P. M. Eftanovits" for the trade with Turkish goods in grosso. He died on 26 October 1855 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Tombstone of Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855) in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
Photograph by Zlatan Stojadinović (2019).
location_name: Apartment and Store of Petar Jeftanović
location_description: Here lived, traded and died Petar Jeftanović (1832-1855), a Serbian merchant. (today Lichtensteg 2, Rotgasse 2, Rotenturmstraße 15). The building does not exist anymore.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Wilhelmine (1847-1918)
entity_description: Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna (né Hirsch) (1847-1918) was an opera singer. She married Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna in Vienna on 18 May 1869. After her husband’s death she lived mostly in Baden near Vienna. Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna died in Vienna on 25 March 1918 in the Sanatorium Svetlin (Leonhardgase 3-5, 1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here in the Sanatorium Svetlin died Wilhelmine Nikolić de Rudna (1847-1918) on 25 March 1918.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Melanie (1872-1942)
entity_description: Melanie Nikolić de Rudna (né Eisner, 1872-1942) married Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) in in the Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava in Vienna on 6 October 1907. She lived from 1919 until her death in 1942 in Thersianumgasse 5 (1040 Vienna).
picture_description: Grave stone of Melanie Nikolić de Rudna in Central cemetery, Vienna.
location_name: Apartment of Baron Teodor Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?)
location_description: Here lived Baron Teodor (Fedor) Nikolić de Rudna (1871-?) together with his wife Melanie Nikolić de Rudna (né Eisner, 1872-1942) from 1919 to 1925. After that Melanie Nikolić de Rudna stayed in the same apartment until her death in 1942. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Obrenović Julie Princess (1831-1919)
entity_description: Princess Julie Obrenović (né Hunyady de Kéthely, 1831-1919) was born in the famous Hungarian noble family of Hunyady on 16 August 1831 in Vienna. She was married to the Serbian Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) from 1853 until they separated in 1865. However, they stayed formally in marriage because of the canon law. After Prince Mihailo Obrenović died in 1868, Princess Julie Obrenović married Karl Maria Herzog von Arenberg (1831-1896) in 1876. She lived most of the time between Vienna, the Castle of "Ivanka" near Bratislava (Ivanka pri Dunaji, today Slovakia) and their property in Belgium. Julie Obrenović was the owner of The Order of the Starry Cross ("Sternkreuzordensdame") since 1895. She spent the last years of her life in Vienna, where she died on 19 February 1919.
picture_description:
Painting of Princess Julie Obrenović (né Hunyady de Kéthely, 1831-1919)

Cf. https://sr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0:Hunyady_J%C3%BAlia_szerb_fejedelemn%C3%A9.jpg
location_description: This palace was a gift to Prince Mihailo Obrenović by his father Prince Miloš Obrenović. The house was in possession of the Obrenović family from 1855, and after Prince Mihailo's divorce from Princess Julie in 1865, she received this house with an estimated value of 100,000 ducats. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Obrenović Mihailo Prince (1823-1868)
entity_description:
Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was born on 16 September 1823 in Kragujevac (today Serbia). He was Prince of Serbia from 1838 to 1842, and after his exile from 1860 to his assassination on 10 June 1868 in Belgrade. His second rule was characterised by the liberation of Serbian cities from Ottoman garrisons, which was a great diplomatic effort and success. It was also his idea to create a Balkan Federation against the Ottoman Empire. Mihailo Obrenović was an enlightened ruler who travelled through Europe during his period of exile (1844-1850). He wanted to incorporate many of the Western European achievements into Serbian society. Mihailo Obrenović died childless in 1868. He was succeeded by his cousin, Milan Obrenović (1854-1901), whose grandfather was Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), a brother of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Prince Mihailo's uncle.
Prince Mihailo Obrenović lived in Vienna with some interruptions between 1843 and 1860. He was the friend and supporter of many Serbian poets and writers in Vienna, starting with Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), on whose recommendation the Prince travelled through the German states and met Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886) and Jacob Grimm (1785-1863), then Anastas Jovanović (1817-1899), Djura Daničić (1825-1882), Branko Radičević (1824-1853), etc. In July 1853 Djura Daničić returned to Vienna on the Prince's invitation to be a teacher of the Serbian language for the Princess Julie Obrenović (1831-1919).
Prince Mihailo Obrenović was also best man and godfather of the family of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in Vienna. On 10 May 1854 the Prince was best man at the wedding of Djordje Stratimirović in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, and then he and later the Prince and King Milan Obrenović were godfathers of the Stratimirović children. There are also several compositions of famous Austrian composers, which were dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović: Johann Strauss Son op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" from 1846; Phillip Fahrbach Senior op. 151 "Serben Polka" from 1853  and Johann Dubez Op. 17 "Divertissement sur des motifs de l'Opéra: Ernani pour la Zither". He married Countess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919) in the Russian Orthodox chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna on 1 August 1853. His best man was the Russian diplomat Peter von Meyendorff (1796-1863). The Austrian newspapers wrote that the Prince was dressed in national costume and had a sabre with diamonds worth 80,000 florins. On the other side the Princess wore a diamond diadem. They lived in the "Obrenovic-Palais" in Vienna and the Castle of "Ivanka" near Bratislava (Ivanka pri Dunaji, today Slovakia). They separated by a signed agreement on 18 November 1865. The house in Vienna (estimated to be worth 100,000 ducats) and also the Castle of "Ivanka" became a property of the Princess and she received a yearly allocation of 5,500 ducats.
location_description: This palace was a gift to Prince Mihailo Obrenović by his father Prince Miloš Obrenović. The house was in possession of the Obrenović family from 1855, and after Prince Mihailo's divorce from Princess Julie in 1865, she received this house with an estimated value of 100,000 ducats. The building does not exist anymore.

location_description: The fourth Slavic Ball took place in the Sofiensäle on 27 January 1847. The music was performed by Johann Strauss Senior (1804-1849) and his orchestra. Among the 2,000 guests were the Prince-Bishop Petar II Petrović Njegoš of Montenegro (1813-1851), Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) and his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina Karadžić (1828-1894).

name: Petrović Njegoš Petar II (1813-1851)
entity_description: Petar II Petrović Njegoš (1813-1851) was a bishop and ruler of Montenegro (Prince-Bishop) from 1830 to his death in 1851. He is one of the greatest Southern Slavic poets and philosophers. His "Mountain Wreath" ("Gorski vijenac") is one of the best known and most popular masterpieces of Serbian and Montenegrin literature. In the period from 1833 to 1847 he stayed several times in Vienna, during which he met amongst others the famous Austrian statesman Prince Klemens Wenzel Lothar von Metternich (1773-1859). Petar II Petrović Njegoš even wrote a poem in honour of the Prince and his wife in 1837. In 1833 Petar II Petrović Njegoš had already met Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), and since then they had remained very close friends. Many important portraits of Petar II Petrović Njegoš were made in Vienna, one of them by Uroš Knežević (1811-1876) and one by Johannes Bes (both in 1847). Anastas Jovanović (1817-1899) also painted several portraits and made one photography of Petar II Petrović Njegoš. In 1842 Petar II Petrović Njegoš received a cross richly decorated with brilliants as personal gift by the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I (1793-1875). During his stay in Vienna in 1847, Petar II Petrović Njegoš lived in the guesthouse above the "Café Stierböck" (Praterstraße 6, 1020 Vienna). Here he wrote the final part of his aforesaid "Mountain Wreath" ("Gorski vijenac"), which was printed in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation in Vienna in the same year. Apart from this he also published his works "Tri dana u Trijestu" (1844) and "Kula Djurišića i Čardak Aleksića" (1850) in the same publishing house.
picture_description:
Prince-Bishop Petar II Petrović Njegoš (1813-1851), Lithograph by Anastas Jovanović (Vienna 1852).

Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.
location_description: The fourth Slavic Ball took place in the Sofiensäle on 27 January 1847. The music was performed by Johann Strauss Senior (1804-1849) and his orchestra. Among the 2,000 guests were the Prince-Bishop Petar II Petrović Njegoš of Montenegro (1813-1851), Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) and his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina Karadžić (1828-1894).

name: Novaković Stefan von  (1760-1823)
entity_description: Stefan von Novaković (1760-1823) was born in Osijek (today Croatia) and was a Hofagent at the Hungarian Court Chancellery ("Ungarische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. In 1792 he bought a printing house from Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) and became a privileged imperial Cyrillic printer in the Habsburg Empire. He sold the printing house to Pest University in 1795 and returned to Osijek. There he worked at the court in the Counties of Bačka and Virovitica. He wrote anonymously the "Dissertatio brevis ac sincera Hungari Auctoris de Gente Serbica perperam Rasciana dicta ejusque Meritis ac fatis in Hungaria cum Appendice Privilegiorum" (sine loco, 1790) and in German "Kurzgefasste Abhandlung über die Verdienste und Schicksale der serbischen oder rascischen Nation in Hungarn, mit einem Anhange der derselben verliehenen Privilegien" (Neusatz und Belgrad bei Janković 1791). Stefan von Novaković received a privilege by the Emperor Franz II (1768-1835) on 18 April 1793 for printing  in the next 15 years, but after 1796 he had some financial obligations to the Illyric National fund.
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/index/pubid:2822/id:0/searchPublishedSince:1793
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Rajić Jovan (1726-1801)
entity_description: Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) was a Serbian historian, pedagogue, writer and Archimandrite of the Monastery of Kovilj (today Serbia). He was educated in the Kyiv-Mohyla Academy in Kiev. Jovan Rajić was one of the best educated Serbs of his time. He wrote in Serbian, Russian, Latin, German and Hungarian and published a Serbian catechesis for children, which was printed in Vienna in 1774. His most important work was his "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"), which was published in the printing house of Stefan Novaković in Vienna between 1794 and 1795. This history was one of the first written by a Serb and had an enormous influence on the subsequent generations of historians. Jovan Rajić collected sources in the Russian Empire and on the Holy Mount Athos. He also used parts of the manuscript of Count Djordje Branković (1645-1711). Apart from its scholarly character, Jovan Rajić's "History" was the first Serbian book, which was printed by subscription. Namely, the advertisement for the book was published in Novaković's daily newspaper in Vienna, called "Slaveno-Serbskija Vjedomosti", in 1794 and the readers assembled the money for this book. Jovan Rajić died in the Monastery of Kovilj in 1801.
picture_description:
A lithograph of Jovan Rajić by Anastas Jovanović from 1852.

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jovan_Rajic.jpg
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Obrenović Miloš  (1829-1861)
entity_description: Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861) was a son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother. He studied  from 1841 to 1842 at the k.u.k. Ingenieurakademie in Vienna. Miloš Obrenović was an officer in the Prussian and Romanian armies. He married Elena Maria Catargiu (Marija Obrenović, 1831-1876) and their son was the Prince and King of Serbia Milan Obrenović (1854-1901).
location_description: Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861), son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother, studied here from 1841 to 1842 at the k.u.k. Ingenieurakademie.

name: Karadžić Stefanović Vuk (1787-1864)
entity_description:
Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) was a Serbian philologist and linguist and greatest reformer of the Serbian language. He became also well known for his collection of Serbian folk songs, fairy tailes and riddles. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić lived and worked in Vienna for more than 50 years. He moved there in 1813 after the end of the First Serbian Uprising (1804-1813) against the Ottoman Empire. In Vienna Vuk Stefanović Karadžić met Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), a Slovenian philologist and censor at the Imperial Library, who encouraged Vuk in his collection of folk material. Vuk met Dimitrije Davidović, Dimitrije Frušić and Sava Mrkalj in Pest and stayed in contact with them also in Vienna. Vuk printed his first book entitled "Pesnarica" (a collection of Serbian folk songs) in Vienna in the Schnierer publishing house in 1,500 copies. In the same year Vuk printed the book "Pismenica"  ("Pismenica serbskoga jezika"), the first grammar of the reformed Serbian language. Vuk published a new edition in 1818, which was translated by the famous German philologist Jacob Grimm (1785-1863) into the German language in 1824 (entitled "Kleine serbische Grammatik"). Grimm was impressed by the Serbian cultural heritage in the form of folk poems and songs. Vuk met Jacob Grimm in 1823 and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832) in his house in Weimar in 1824. Goethe was interested in Serbian folk poetry since the year 1778, when he translated "Hasanaginica", a South Slavic folk ballad. From 1823 to 1827 Goethe translated folk songs from Vuk's books in the journal "Über Kunst und Alterthum", the first one was "Dioba Jakšića" ("Erbschaftsteilung"). Apart from Goethe and Grimm Vuk's folk songs were translated into Czech ("Prostonárodní srbská muza, do Cech převedená", 1817), English ("Servian popular poetry", 1827), Swedish ("Serbiska folksänger", 1830), Hungarian ("Szerb népdalok hősregék", 1836) and into Polish ("Narodowe piesni serbskie", 1853). Kopitar introduced Vuk to Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886), one of the greatest German historians, in 1827. On the basis of Vuk's knowledge of the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire, Ranke published his book on the "Serbian revolution" in 1828.
Vuk's Serbian-German Dictionary, printed in 1818 in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery (Mechitaristengasse 4, 1070 Vienna), was the first book ever printed in the newly reformed Serbian language. Vuk standardised the Serbian Cyrillic alphabet based on the phonemic principle of Johann Christoph Adellung (1732-1806), a great German philologist. His motto was: "Write as you speak, and read as it is written". This book was printed from donations, firstly by Theodor Demeter Tirka (1764-1839), a Greek merchant and banker from Vienna, who was also godfather of Vuk's children.
Vuk married Anna Kraus (1788-1876) in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54-56, 1030 Vienna) on 28 January 1818. His best man was Jernej Kopitar. Vuk's first rented apartment was that of Anna's father, where they met. During his life in Vienna Vuk changed address more than 20 times. The couple had 12 children, but only two of them overlived Vuk: his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina (1828-1894) and his son Dimitrije (1836-1883).
Vuk was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was a friend of Prince Miloš Obrenović and Prince Mihailo Obrenović, Petar Petrović Njegoš, Djura Daničić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, etc. Vuk was also very reputable among all Slavs, his friends and associates were the Russian priest Michail Fjodorowitsch Rajewski (1811-1844), Jernej Kopitar, Josef Dobrovský (1753-1829), František Palacký (1798-1876), Pavel Jozef Šafárik (1795-1861), Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891), etc. Vuk was often guest in the so-called "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich"), also "Zum Weissen Wolfen" (Fleischmarkt 20/Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna), and other places where the Slavs gathered in Vienna.
In 1823 Vuk became honorary Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Jena. In 1826 Vuk received a Russian and in 1835 a Serbian pension. He was very reputable in the Russian Empire. Apart from the pension the Russian Emperor Nikolaj I Pavlovič (1796-1855) honored him with the Gold medal in 1841 and in 1862 he was awarded with the Order of St. Anna 2nd class with crown. Vuk became a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna on 14 January 1848. Three days before he had received a ring with brilliants as a gift of the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I (1793-1875), who thanked him for his book of Serbian folk songs entitled "Srpske Narodne pjesme". In 1850 the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) honored Vuk with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order 3rd class and in 1851 with the Gold Medal for Science. Vuk was also awarded the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle 3rd class in 1852.
Vuk died in his appartment, where he spent his last 15 years of life, in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) on 7 February 1864. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Griechengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) he was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His mortal remains were transferred to Belgrade in 1897, while the tombstone still stands in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery. On the house in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) a memorial plaque was placed in the 1950s, and Vuk’s monument was erected in Rasumofskygasse 22 (1030 Vienna) in 1987.
location_description: The first Slavic Ball took place in the Theater in der Josefstadt (Sträußelsäle) in Vienna on 4 February 1844. It (and also the subsequent Slavic Balls) was organised by students with the financial support of Princes Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868). Among the 300 guests was also Vuk  Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864).

name: Obrenović Mihailo Prince (1823-1868)
entity_description:
Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868) was born on 16 September 1823 in Kragujevac (today Serbia). He was Prince of Serbia from 1838 to 1842, and after his exile from 1860 to his assassination on 10 June 1868 in Belgrade. His second rule was characterised by the liberation of Serbian cities from Ottoman garrisons, which was a great diplomatic effort and success. It was also his idea to create a Balkan Federation against the Ottoman Empire. Mihailo Obrenović was an enlightened ruler who travelled through Europe during his period of exile (1844-1850). He wanted to incorporate many of the Western European achievements into Serbian society. Mihailo Obrenović died childless in 1868. He was succeeded by his cousin, Milan Obrenović (1854-1901), whose grandfather was Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), a brother of Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and Prince Mihailo's uncle.
Prince Mihailo Obrenović lived in Vienna with some interruptions between 1843 and 1860. He was the friend and supporter of many Serbian poets and writers in Vienna, starting with Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864), on whose recommendation the Prince travelled through the German states and met Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886) and Jacob Grimm (1785-1863), then Anastas Jovanović (1817-1899), Djura Daničić (1825-1882), Branko Radičević (1824-1853), etc. In July 1853 Djura Daničić returned to Vienna on the Prince's invitation to be a teacher of the Serbian language for the Princess Julie Obrenović (1831-1919).
Prince Mihailo Obrenović was also best man and godfather of the family of Major General Djordje Stratimirović (1822-1908) in Vienna. On 10 May 1854 the Prince was best man at the wedding of Djordje Stratimirović in the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity, and then he and later the Prince and King Milan Obrenović were godfathers of the Stratimirović children. There are also several compositions of famous Austrian composers, which were dedicated to Prince Mihailo Obrenović: Johann Strauss Son op. 14 "Serben Quadrille" from 1846; Phillip Fahrbach Senior op. 151 "Serben Polka" from 1853  and Johann Dubez Op. 17 "Divertissement sur des motifs de l'Opéra: Ernani pour la Zither". He married Countess Julie Hunyady de Kéthely (1831-1919) in the Russian Orthodox chapel of the Russian Legation in Vienna on 1 August 1853. His best man was the Russian diplomat Peter von Meyendorff (1796-1863). The Austrian newspapers wrote that the Prince was dressed in national costume and had a sabre with diamonds worth 80,000 florins. On the other side the Princess wore a diamond diadem. They lived in the "Obrenovic-Palais" in Vienna and the Castle of "Ivanka" near Bratislava (Ivanka pri Dunaji, today Slovakia). They separated by a signed agreement on 18 November 1865. The house in Vienna (estimated to be worth 100,000 ducats) and also the Castle of "Ivanka" became a property of the Princess and she received a yearly allocation of 5,500 ducats.

name: Obrenović Miloš Prince (1780-1860)
entity_description:
Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) was the leader of the Second Serbian Uprising (1815-1817) against the Ottoman Empire, ruler of Serbia (1815-1839 and 1858-1860) and founder of the Obrenović Dynasty. Under his rule Serbia became an autonomous principality within the Ottoman Empire. During his reign the modernisation of Serbia had begun through numerous reforms (first schools, courts, administration, publishing houses, the first Constitution in 1835, church reforms etc.).
Miloš Obrenović lived in Vienna with interruption from 1841 to 1858. In this period he had contact not only with many renowned Viennese Serbs (e.g. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, Djura Daničić...), but also with other important Slavs and Orthodox personalities in Vienna as well – especially with the Greek families Sina, Dumba and Tirka and with the Russian Orthodox priest Mihail Fjodorovič Rajevski (1811-1884).

Painting of Prince Miloš Obrenović from 1848.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Jelisaveta-Savka  (1814-1848)
entity_description: Jelisaveta-Savka Nikolić de Rudna (né Obrenović, 1814-1848) was the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). She married Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) on 16 October 1831. Jelisaveta-Savka died on 23 September 1848 in the house Leopoldstadt No. 579 (today Praterstraße 8, 1020 Vienna) and was buried on 30 September in Tomb No. 4 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In the same cemetery were buried her two sons. The first died after birth on 14 January 1847 and the second, Mladen, on 12 February 1849. Then they were transferred to Vöslau on 4 August 1881 and after that to the landed property of Rudna (today Romania).
picture_description:
Savka Obrenović, painted by Miklós Barabás (1810-1898)
Residence of Princess Ljubica
Belgrade, Serbia

Description:
"This Biedermeier portrait, painted in Vienna, shows Jelisaveta Savka Obrenović, the third child and the youngest daughter of Prince Miloš and Princess Ljubica. She is depicted in a silk dress and a libade trimmed with fur, also known as škurteljka. This is the only traditional element in her dress. The medallion with a portrait of prince Miloš supported by her hand alludes to her ancestors. According to tradition, Prince Miloš was particularly closely related to Savka, who was his favourite child. At the age of seventeen she got married to Baron Jovan Nikolić of Rudna, with whom she had five sons."
https://izi.travel/en/286d-miklos-barabas-savka-obrenovic/en
location_name: Tomb of Nikolić de Rudna family on St. Marx Cemetery
location_description: Tomb no. 4 in the first row at the Orthodox part of the cemetery. Here were buried Jelisaveta- Savka Nikolić de Rudna and her son Mladen before they were transferred to Rudna (nowedays Romania). Jelisaveta died in Vienna at the age of 35, and was buried here on 13 September 1848. In the same tomb was buried on 15 January 1849 her son Mladen, who died at the age of 5.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Mladen (1845-1849)
entity_description: Mladen Nikolić (1845-1849) was the son of Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) and Jelisaveta-Savka Nikolić de Rudna (né Obrenović, 1814-1848). He died on 12 February 1849 at the age of 4 in the house Leopoldstadt No. 579 (today Praterstraße 8, 1020 Vienna) and was buried on 14 February 1849 in Tomb No. 4 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). In the same tomb was buried his mother Jelisaveta-Savka. They were both transferred to Vöslau on 4 August 1881 and after that to the landed property of Rudna (today Romania).

In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Obrenović Jekatarina- Katica  (1826-1848)
entity_description: Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848) was the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother, Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856). She died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 27 July 1848.
location_name: Tomb of Jekatarina Obrenović in the St. Marx Cemetery
location_description: Jekatarina-Katica Obrenović (1826-1848), the daughter of Prince Miloš's youngest brother Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), died in Vienna on 25 July 1848 and, after a memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George, was buried in tomb No. 3 in the first row of the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 27 July 1848.

name: Jovanović Zaharije (1810-1850)
entity_description: Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča, was one of the Serbian leaders in the war against the Hungarians in 1848/49 with the rank of Colonel. He arrived in Vienna in 1850 in order to get a pension, but he fell ill and died. Zaharije Jovanović died in the House No. 8 auf der Wieden (today Wiedner Hauptstraße 14, 1040 Vienna) on 18 November 1850 at the age of 40. He was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča; lithograph by Anastas Jovanović, 1851.
Muzej Grada Beograda, AJ 133.
location_description: Here died Zaharije Jovanović (1810-1850), called Čiča,  Colonel of the Serbian troops, which were loyal to the Habsburg dynasty in the war against the Hungarians in 1848/49, on 18 November 1850 at the age of 40. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Duka de Kadar Petar (1756-1822)
entity_description: Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822) was a General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugmeister"), commanding General in the region of Banat, nobleman ("Baron"), "k. k.Geheimer Rat" and Knight of the Military Order of Maria Theresia. He was born in Osijek (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in a merchant's family of Serbian origin in 1756. Duka began a very long military career in 1776. After the victorious Battle of Famars (1793) against the French Revolutionary Army he became Knight of the Maria Theresia Order. In 1800 Duka was promoted to Major General. He became commander of the fortress in Timișoara (today Romania) and in 1813 General of the Artillery ("Feldzeugsmeister"). In 1815 Duka was honored with the title of "k. k. Geheimer Rat" by the Austrian Emperor Franz I (1768-1835). The Infantry Regiment No. 39 carried his name since 1803. Apart from the Large Cross of the Leopold Order he was also the holder of many Russian, Prussian, Bavarian, French and Sicilian decorations. Duka received Hungarian nobility with the rank of "Baron" and became the owner of the landed property Kadar in Banat (today Romania). Therefore, his title was "de Kadar" or "von Kadar". From 1815 he was a member of the State Council ("Staatsrat") and because of that he settled in Vienna. Petar Duka de Kadar died on 29 December 1822 in the house in Renngasse 10 (1010 Vienna). He was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) and in 1907 his mortal remains were exhumed and buried in Kadar.
picture_description:
Lithograph by Josef Lanzedelly the Elder, ca. 1820.

https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Peter_von_Duka_Litho.jpg
location_name: Apartment of Baron Petar Duka de Kadar
location_description: Here was the last living place of the General of the Artillery and Baron Petar Duka de Kadar (1756-1822). He died here on 29 December 1822. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Aleksić von Maina Jovan (1783-1861)
entity_description: Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861) was an Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman of Serbian origin. Aleksić was born in Kotor (today Montenegro, in Italian Cattaro) in a noble family, whose ancestors had moved from the Montenegrin mountains to the Boka Kotorska in 1621. The family of Aleksić von Maina bore five captains, two majors, two colonels and two generals. They served in the armed forces of Venice, France and Austria. Jovan's uncle Rade Maina was promoted to the rank of General in the Republic of the Venice in 1779. Jovan Aleksić von Maina was, following the service in the Venetian army, also in the French army under Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821). From 1815 he joined the Austrian army, where he was promoted to the rank of General in Sremska Mitrovica in 1835. He was awarded the Order of the Iron Crown 3rd grade. He was ennobled and elevated to knighthood (Ritterstand) in 1840. After his retirement in 1844, when he was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant, he moved to Vienna, where he stayed for the next eleven years. He lived at first (already before 1853) in Johannesgasse 969 (the so-called "Fleischhof", today Johannesgasse 1, 1010 Vienna).  His wife Marija Aleksić von Maina (born Klaić) died in this house on 21 December 1857 at the age of 54. She was buried on the St. Marx cemetery, then exhumated and transferred to Hietzing cemetery in 1899. Jovan Aleksić von Maina died on 19 February 1861 in the house No. 618 ("Trattnerhof", Graben 29-29a / Trattnerhof 1/2, 1010 Vienna) and was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna) on 22 February 1861.
location_description: Here lived and died Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman of Serbian origin Jovan Aleksić von Maina (1783-1861) on 19 February 1861. The building was demolished in 1911 and a new one was erected.

name: Zavišić Severin (1817-1885)
entity_description: Severin Zavišić (1817-1885) was a medical doctor, surgeon and President of Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council in Vienna from 1876 to 1884. He was the owner of several patents for the invention of different instruments in the field of medicine and hygiene. In 1856 Severin Zavišić lived in Fleischmarkt 700/728 (today Fleischmarkt 1, the original building does not exist anymore). He was head physician in the Viennese "Garnisons-Spittal" and archducal Court Physician ("erzherzoglicher Hofarzt") as well as the personal physician of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860). Severin Zavišić was honored with the Serbian Takovo Order (1882) and was also a honorary member of the Belgian Life Saving Society. He died in his apartment in Seitenstettengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) on 15 June 1885 at the age of 68. Severin Zavišić was buried on 17 June 1885 in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Severin Zavišić (1817-1885), a medical doctor, surgeon and President of Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council in Vienna from 1876 to 1884, on 15 June 1885.

name: Stojić Petar (1838 -1907)
entity_description: Petar Stojić (1838-1907) was a Major General of the Austro-Hungarian Army and Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. He donated 300 florins for the building of the Church of St. Sava in Vienna in 1891. Petar Stojić collected money for the building of the Church of St. Sava among the Serbs in Banat, Bačka, Dalmatia, Croatia, Slavonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Until April 1892 he and Aleksandar Štova (1836-1898) had amassed more than 20,000 florins. Because of his merits in the building of the church he was declared Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava at its annual meeting in 1893. Together with Aleksandar Štova he was also a member of the delegation which was in audience to Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) in November 1893. This delegation thanked the Emperor for his donation for the church building and also for his presence at the inauguration ceremony. Petar Stojić retired as commander of the 4th Ulan Regiment in 1894, when he received the honorary rank of Major General.
location_description: Here lived Petar Stojić (1838-1907), Major General of the Austro-Hungarian Army and Honorary President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna, in 1888.

name: Nikolić von Serbograd Isidor (1805-1862)
entity_description: Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd (1805-1862) was a politician and writer. In 1837 and 1842 he was member of the Serbian National Congresses. From 1849 to 1852 he was head  ("Obergespan") of the Counties of Bačka and Banat. Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd donated 10 ducats for the building of the Votivkirche in Vienna in 1853. In 1849 he printed a monograph on his political views on Serbian autonomy within the Hungarian part of the Austrian Empire entitled "Vojvodstvo Serba Austriski" in the publishing house of the Mekhitarist Congregation in Vienna.
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske, Novi Sad.

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/2930
location_description:
The Votivkirche (Votive Church) is a neo-Gothic church in the city centre of Vienna. It was built following the attempted and failed assassination of Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) in 1853. The Emperor's brother Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian (1832-1867) inaugurated a campaign to create a church to thank God for saving the Emperor's life. Funds for the construction were collected throughout the Empire.
Isidor Nikolić von Serbograd (1805-1862), politician and writer, donated 10 ducats for the building of the Votivkirche in Vienna in 1853.

name: Petrović Ladislav Eugen (1839-1907)
entity_description: Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907) was born on 25 January 1839 in Vienna and was the son of the famous sculptor Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854). He was a landscape painter, illustrator, and caricaturist. From 1857 to 1861 Ladislav Eugen Petrović was a student at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste"), where he devoted himself to landscape and architectural painting. He was drawing for newspapers ("Illustrierte Zeitung" in Leipzig, "L'Illustration" in Paris) and was illustrating books. Ladislav Eugen Petrović created a series of Viennese topographical oil paintings and from 1887 he was painting watercolors (reproduced in full color, including the series "Wiener Ansichten", "Wiener Bilderbögen", "Erinnerung an Wien" and "Wiener Typen"). Ladislav Eugen Petrović died on 1 April 1907 in his apartment in Landstraßer Hauptstraße 21 (1030 Vienna). He had lived there since 3 December 1894 with his wife Mathilde (né Nowotny). Before this last place of living he had lived in Erdbergstraße 3 (1030 Vienna). Ladislav Eugen Petrović was born as an Orthodox and converted to Catholicism on 1 December 1894.
picture_description:
Ladislav Eugen Petrović, Monumental-Plan der Haupt- und Residenzstadt Wien (1887).

https://www.digital.wienbibliothek.at/wbrobv/content/titleinfo/1476426
location_description: Here died the Viennese painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907) on 1 April 1907. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Petrović Dimitrije (1799-1854)
entity_description:
Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854) was a sculptor in Vienna. He was born in Baja (today Hungary) and came to Vienna in 1819. He studied first with Josef Klieber (1773-1850) and continued his studies in 1821 at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts. Here Dimitrije Petrović received two awards in 1823. After that he worked together with the sculptor Johann Nepomuk Schaller (1777-1842), and his most important work was a statue of Count Kinsky from 1830, which was presented to the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt ("Wiener Neustadt – Theresianische Militärakademie. Franz Graf Kinsky. Büste 1829 beauftragt und 1830 von Johann Nepomuk Schaller geschaffen, gegossen von Demeter Petrowitsch"). From 1831 he worked alone and created many sculptures, among them two of Jesus Christ for Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860) and one for the Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci. He also designed altars in chapels for the Count Schwarzenberg.
Dimitrije Petrović died at the age of 55 on 25 December 1854 in his apartment in Leopoldstadt No. 378. He was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His son was the famous painter Ladislav Eugen Petrović (1839-1907).
picture_description:
Wiener Neustadt – Theresianische Militärakademie. Franz Graf Kinsky. Büste 1829 beauftragt und 1830 von Johann Nepomuk Schaller geschaffen, gegossen von Demeter Petrowitsch.


https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Theresianische_Milit%C3%A4rakademie,_Wiener_Neustadt_2.jpg
location_description: Here died the Viennese sculptor Dimitrije Petrović (1799-1854) on 25 December 1854.

name: Maksimović Mihailo (?-1819)
entity_description: Mihailo Maksimović (?-1819) was the first Serbian satirist. Initially he was an official in Zemun and Petrovaradin, and in 1791/92 he worked at the Illyrian Court Office ("Illyrische Hofkanzlei") in Vienna. Mihailo Maksimović translated Joseph Valentin Eybel's (1741-1805) critique of the Pope entitled "Was ist der Papst?" (Vienna 1784) into Serbian. He wrote his first satiric book in Serbian language entitled "Мали буквар за велику децу" ("Small Spelling Book for Big Children") with 117 satiric stories and published it at the printing house of Stefan Novaković (1760-1823) in Vienna in 1792. In the same year Mihailo Мaksimović released also in Vienna his work "Илирически народ в памјат Леополда II Миротворца" ("The Illyrian People in the Memory of Leopold II").
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/index/string:%D0%9C%D0%90%D0%9A%D0%A1%D0%98%D0%9C%D0%9E%D0%92%D0%98%D0%8B%2C+%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE/tags:author
location_description: In the year 1792 Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) sold his printing house to Stefan von Novaković for 25,000 forints. Although Novaković was only owner for three years (from 1792 to 1795), his contribution to the history of Serbian publishing was enormous. Among other books, he printed one of the first Serbian history books of the historian and Archimandrite Jovan Rajić (1726-1801) in 1794/95 entitled "History of the Bulgarian, Serbian and Croatian Peoples" ("Историја разних славенских народов, наипаче Болгар, Хорватов и Сербов"). In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house. Stefan von Novaković sold his printing house to Pest University in 1795. His printing house was in Salvatorgasse 456 (1010 Vienna), which was after renumeration house No. 6. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Vezilić Aleksije (1753-1792)
entity_description: Aleksije Vezilić (1753-1792) was a Serbian poet, who introduced the German Enlightenment to the Serbian people. He attended a teacher's course of Stefan Vujanovski (1743-1829) in 1780. Before that he had learned German and Latin in Budapest (today Hungary). Aleksije Vezilić studied Law in Vienna in 1785. He was teaching German and Latin in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) until 1790. After that he was appointed as school inspector. Aleksije Vezilić published the "Краткоје сочиненије о приватних и публичних делах" (Vienna 1785 and 1792) and the "Краткоје написаније о спокојној жизни" (Vienna 1788 and Buda 1813), which represents the first collection of verses in modern Serbian literature, in the printing house of Josef von Kurzböck (1736-1792) and Stefan von Novaković. Aleksije Vezilić also wrote a Serbian-German Dictionary entitled "Речник мали Немецко-Сербски" (Vienna 1793), which was published posthumously.

Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.

name: Ljuština Vikentije (1761-1805)
entity_description: Vikentije Ljuština (1761-1805) was born in Medak (in Lika, today Croatia) and was educated in the Monastery of Gomirje (today Croatia), where he became a monk. He served as a deacon in Trieste, Vienna, Sopron and Vršac. Apart from his knowledge of classical language Vikentije Ljuština spoke German, French, Italian, Romanian and Hungarian. In 1794 he published his Grammar of Italian at the printing house of Stefan Novaković. In 1798 he edited two monographs on the Monasteries of Mesić and Zlatica.

name: Muškatirović Jovan (1743-1809)
entity_description: Jovan Muškatirović (1743-1809) was a Serbian writer and representative of Rationalism. He was born in Senta (today Serbia) in 1743. After completing Law Studies in Pest in 1773, he became the first lawyer among the Serbs. He was a senator in Pest's city council. Jovan Muškatirović was a rationalist and critic of church institutions. He was the first to document folk traditions among Orthodox Serbs. In 1786 he published a treatise entitled "Краткое размишленије о праздници" ("A Short Deliberation on Holidays"), advocating a reduction in the number of religious holidays. The most important work of Jovan Muškatirović was his collection of Serbian proverbs entitled "Причте илити по простому пословице тјемже сентенције илити рјеченија", published in Vienna in 1787. In 1794 Jovan Muškatirović published a critique of some practices in the Orthodox Church entitled "Разсуждение о постах восточное церкве" in Novaković's printing house in Vienna. Jovan Muškatirović was a close friend of Dositej Obradović (1739-1811), by whose enlightened ideas he was influenced.
