name: Čokor Jovan (1849-1911)
entity_description:
Jovan Čokor (1849-1911) was born as Johann Nepomuk Csokor on 4 April 1849 and was baptised on 6 April in the Roman Catholic church of St. Leopold (1020 Vienna). He was born in the house No. 371 in Leopoldstadt (today Große Stadtgutgasse 11, 1020 Vienna). His father was Aleksandar Čokor (1815-1884) and his mother Anna Schindler (1818-1856). He started his education at Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) at his uncle the Archimandrite Julijan Čokor and stayed there from 1854 to 1864. After that he finished the grammar school in Pest in 1866 and continued to study medicine in Vienna. Jovan Čokor was promoted to Dr. of Medicine in 1873. In 1875 he graduated in Veterinary Science and gained a position as assistant at the Department of Anatomy and Physiology in Vienna. He gave lectures on Histology and Parasitology and introduced histological-microscopic teaching at the University.

Jovan Čokor married Emilie Müller on 28 July 1877 in Vienna. They had five children:
Emilie Sofia Maria Čokor (6 June 1878),
Franz Theodor Čokor (8 September 1885 - 5 January 1969),
Johann Čokor (22 October 1886 - 1915),
Eugenie Čokor (24 November 1887 - 1979),
Sofie Čokor (6 July 1891 - 1967).

From 1876 as a temporary and from 1879 as a permanent Lecturer at the Chair of Zoology, Čokor was appointed as Professor of General Pathology and Forensic Veterinary Medicine in Vienna in 1880. In 1884 he deepened his knowledge by working together with Robert Koch (1843-1910) in Berlin. Already from 1889 he was also an eminent Professor of Infectious and Parasitic Diseases and turned more to parasitology. In 1906 a chair was established for this discipline. Čokor also founded and widely publicised diagnostic vaccine stations. In addition, he taught as a Privatdozent from 1890 and as a Professor of Veterinary Medicine from 1895 at the University of Vienna. In 1909 he retired as Professor.
Jovan Čokor published regularly in several scientific journals, namely the "Österreichische Vierteljahresschrift für wissenschaftliche Veterinärkunde", "Allgemeine Wiener Medizinische Zeitung" and "Wiener Wochenschrift". He published a "Lehrbuch der gerichtlichen Thierheilkunde" (1898, 2nd ed. 1902). He received the Knight's Cross in 1898 and the Officer's Cross of the Franz Josef Order in 1909. He was Knight of the Serbian Order of Saint Sava and a member of the Society of Doctors as well as honorary member of the Serbian Society of Doctors in Belgrade. Finally, he bore the title of "Hofrat". Jovan Čokor died on 7 January 1911 in his apartment in Mödling (Jasomirgottgasse 8) and was buried on the local cemetery.
location_description: Here was born Jovan Čokor, Professor at the University of Vienna, on 4 April 1849. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Radonić Jovan (1873-1956)
entity_description: Jovan Radonić (1873-1956) was a Serbian historian, Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade. He was born in Mol (today Hungary) on 28 January 1873. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, Jovan Radonić studied History at the University of Vienna from 1891 to 1896. During this period he lived in Lederergasse 26 (1080 Vienna). His Professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). Jovan Radonić received his title of Dr on 16 July 1896. His dissertation was entitled "Der Grossvojvode von Bosnien Sandalj Hranić-Kosača". Since 1919 he was Professor at the University of Belgrade. Jovan Radonić was also a member of the Serbian Royal Academy as well as of many other scholarly societies and academies. He participated in political life and from 1923 he was a deputy in the Parliament of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes. Jovan Radonić died in Belgrade on 25 November 1956.
location_description: Here lived Jovan Radonić (1873-1956), Serbian historian and Professor at University, during his studies at the University of Vienna from 1891 to 1892.

name: Danilović Toma (1871-1905)
entity_description: Toma Danilović (1871-1905) was a Serbian merchant and owner of a restaurant in Vienna, who was born in Serbia in 1871. He was the owner of the famous Viennese restaurant "Zum weißen Wolf" (Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna) in 1897. He died in his apartment in Dominikanerbastei 21 (1010 Vienna) on 26 May 1905.
location_description: Toma Danilović (1871-1905) was a Serbian merchant and the owner of the famous Viennese restaurant "Zum weißen Wolf" in 1897. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Karadjordjević Petar King (1844-1921)
entity_description: King Petar I Karadjordjević (1844-1921) was King of Serbia (1904-1918) and first King of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (1918-1921). After his father's (Prince Aleksandar Karadjordjević) abdication in 1858 he spent 45 years in exile. He moved from Switzerland to France, where he graduated at the renowned Military Academy of Saint-Cyr (École spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr) in 1864. During the war between France and Prussia in the years 1870/71 he fought in the French Foreign Legion. He was one of the leaders against the Ottomans in Herzegovina in 1875. Petar Karadjordjević joined the uprising under the name Petar Mrkonjić. Later he lived in exile in Montenegro, where he married Zorka (1864-1890), the daughter of the Montenegrin Prince Nikola Petrović (1841-1921). After May 1903, when King Aleksandar Obrenović (1876-1903), the last ruler from the Obrenović dynasty, was mudered in Belgrade, Petar Karadjordjević was elected to King of Serbia. He was ruling during the two Balkan Wars (1912-1913) and the First World War (1914-1918). Although a monarch, he was a strong supporter of Parliamentarism, Liberalism and Democracy. His reign was seen as the "golden time of Serbian democracy". Petar Karadjordjević was a follower of John Stuart Mill's ideas of Utilitarianism, freedom of speech, freedom of press etc. He translated Mill's work "On Liberty" into Serbian in 1867, and it was printed in Vienna in 1868.
location_description: Here in the Hotel “Zur Kaiserin Elisabeth” lived Prince Petar Karadjordjević in 1858.

name: Stanojević Stanoje (1874-1937)
entity_description: Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937) was a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade. He was born in Novi Sad (today Serbia) on 13 August 1874. After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, Stanoje Stanojević studied History at the University of Vienna from 1892 to 1896. He lived in Neustiftgasse 97 (1080 Vienna). His professors at University were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). Stanoje Stanojević received his titel of Dr on 16 July 1896. His dissertation is entitled "Die Biographie Stefan Lazarević's von Konstantin dem Philosophen als Geschichtsquelle". From 1903 until his death in 1937 Stanoje Stanojević was Professor at the University of Belgrade. His main field of research was the Serbian medieval history. During the First World War (1914-1918) he was in exile and lectured as a visiting Professor at the Sorbonne in Paris and at London University. At the Paris Peace Conference in the years 1919 and 1920 he was a member of the Serbian delegation in the historical-ethnographic section. Stanoje Stanojević died in the Viennese Sanatorium Löw on 30 July 1937.
location_description: Here lived during his studies at the University of Vienna Stanoje Stanojević (1874-1937), a Serbian historian, a Professor at University and a member of the Serbian Royal Academy in Belgrade, from 1892 to 1896.

name: Obrenović Marija (1831-1876)
entity_description: Marija Obrenović (1831-1876) was born in the Romanian noble family of Catargiu in 1831. She married Miloš Obrenović (1829-1861), the son of Jevrem Obrenović (1790-1856), Prince Miloš's brother. Their son Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) was Prince and King (from 1882) of Serbia. As a young boy Milan lived in Vienna with his mother. In their neighborhood was Arthur Schnitzler (1862-1931), who wrote in his autobiography about the childhood of the young Milan. Milan's mother Marija was the owner of the house in Hirschengasse 29 (today Billrothstraße 29, 1190 Vienna). This house does not exist anymore. Marija Obrenović died in Paris in 1876.
location_description: As a young boy Milan Obrenović (1854-1901) lived in Vienna with his mother Marija Obrenović (1831-1876). In their neighborhood was Arthur Schnitzler (1862-1931), who wrote in his autobiography about the childhood of the young Milan. Milan's mother Marija was the owner of the house in Hirschengasse 29 (today Billrothstraße 29, 1190 Vienna). This house does not exist anymore.

name: Mikašinović Mihailo (1715-1775)
entity_description: Mihailo Mikašinović (1715-1775) was a Field marshal-lieutenant and nobleman, born in Plavšinac near Koprivnica (Military Frontier, today Croatia) in an officer's family in 1715. He was the first Serb in the Habsburg Army, who reached the rank of General in 1763. He was ennobled to Baron on 28 June 1760 with the title "von Schlangenfeld". Mihailo Mikašinović was promoted to the rank of Field marshal-lieutenant two years later (1765). He fought in the War of the Austrian Succession ("Österreichischer Erbfolgekrieg", 1740-1748) and in the Seven Years War ("Siebenjähriger Krieg", 1756-1763). He was also a deputy at the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) in 1769. Mihailo Mikašinović was a benefactor of many Serbian churches and monasteries, to which he gave substantial donations. In his memoirs Dositej Obradović (1739-1811) mentioned his friendship with General Mikašinović, calling him "our national hero". In 1771 Mihailo Mikašinović retired from military service. In 1774 he fell ill and moved to Vienna for medical treatment. Here he died on 5 November 1775.
picture_description: Ivan Bojničić von Knin und Plavno, Der Adel von Kroatien und Slavonien (Nürnberg 1899), Tafel 85.
location_name: Place of Death of Mihailo Mikašinović
location_description: Here died Mihailo Mikašinović, Field marshal-lieutenant, nobleman and the first Serb in the Habsburg Army, who reached the rank of General, on 5 November 1775. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Ljubibratić Jeftimije (1716-1779)
entity_description: Jeftimije Ljubibratić (1716-1779) was born in a Serbian noble family in Dubrovnik (today Croatia) in 1716. The family of Ljubibratić was mentioned for the first time in the medieval period. At the age of 14 he joined the Habsburg army as a cadet. Because of his braveness and merits he was ennobled becoming a Baron and received the title "von Trebinya" on 26 January 1760. Two years later, on 30 April 1762, he was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Maria Theresia Order. Jeftimije Ljubibratić was promoted to the rank of Major General in 1770 and to Field marshal-lieutenant in 1773. He died in an apartment in Krugerstraße 10 (1010 Vienna) on 4 November 1779 and was buried in the Monastery of Savina (in Herceg Novi, today Montenegro), where his brother was Archimandrite.
picture_description:
Dimitrije Avramović, Portrait of General Jeftimije Ljubibratić, 1834. Property of: Галерија Матице Српске
http://www.galerijamaticesrpske.rs/portret-18-veka.html
location_description: Here died Jeftimije Ljubibratić (1716-1779), Austrian Field marshal-lieutenant, Knight of the Maria Theresia Order and Baron, on 4 November 1779. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Kočić Petar (1877-1916)
entity_description: Petar Kočić (1877-1916) was a Serbian writer and politician from Bosnia and Herzegovina. After showing his national attidudes, he was expelled from school in Sarajevo and continued his education in a grammar school in Belgrade, where he graduated in 1899. After that Petar Kočić studied Slavonic Studies at the University of Vienna from 1899 to 1904. His professors were amongst others Vatroslav Jagić (1838-1923), Milan von Rešetar (1860-1942) and Konstantin Josef Jireček (1854-1918). For a short time he was Professor in the Serbian grammar school in Skoplje and later he moved to Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1910 Petar Kočić was elected as parliamentarian of the Agrarian Party to the newly established Parliament ("Sabor") of Bosnia and Herzegovina. He advocated an agrarian reform and the freedom of press. Petar Kočić stayed in the "Sabor" until 1913, when he resigned because of a mental illness. He died in Belgrade in a hospital during the Austro-Hungarian occupation on 27 August 1916.
location_description: Here lived from 1903 to 1904 Petar Kočić, a Serbian writer and politician, during his studies at the University of Vienna from 1899 to 1904.

name: Nikolić de Rudna Jovan (1810-1880)
entity_description: Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) married Jelisaveta-Savka Obrenović (1814-1848), the daughter of the Serbian Prince Miloš Obrenović (1780-1860), on 16 October 1831. In 1832 he donated 250 forints to the Matica Srpska. He received the title of Austrian Baron in 1854. The private teacher of his sons Teodor (Fedor) and Mihajlo in Vienna was Svetozar Miletić (1826-1901), a student of Law in Vienna. The family Nikolić de Rudna was an old Serbian noble familly. Miroslav Nikolić was knighted in 1693, which was confirmed in 1778 and again in 1783. Jovan Nikolić from Osijek bought together with Teodor Jovanović Mirijevski landed property in Rudna in 1781.
location_description: Here stood the famous guesthouse "Fetzer" until 1956. Baron Jovan Nikolić de Rudna (1810-1880) lived here in the 1840s with his family. In this house died his wife Jelisaveta-Savka on 23 September 1848 and his son Mladen on 12 February 1849. Here lived in the same time also Jelisaveta's brother, Prince Mihailo Obrenović (1823-1868).

name: Veljović Nikola (1796-1848)
entity_description: Nikola Veljović (1796-1848) was a Serbian merchant and managing director, who was born in Vienna in 1796. His father was Jovan Veljović (1755-1803). He died in Leopoldstadt 661 (Ferdinandstraße 30, 1020 Vienna) at the age of 52 on 8 May 1848 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Nikola Veljović (1796-1848), a Viennese merchant and managing director of Serbian origin, at the age of 52 on 8 May 1848. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Veljović Djordje (1789-1838)
entity_description: Djordje Veljović (1789-1838) was a Serbian merchant in Vienna and Ottoman citizen. His father was Jovan Veljović (1755-1803). He died in Fleischmarkt 14 (1010 Vienna; the original building does not exist anymore) at the age of 49 on 27 December 1838 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His wife Anastasia was born in Zemun in the family Karamata. She died at the age of 38 in Vienna on 8 July 1831.
location_description: Here died Djordje Veljović (1789-1838), Serbian merchant from Vienna and Ottoman citizen, at the age of 49 on 27 December 1838. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Veljović Jovan (1755-1803)
entity_description: Jovan Veljović (1755-1803) was a Serbian merchant, who was born in Vidin (today Bulgaria) in 1755. He lived and worked in Vienna since the 1790s in the house No. 747 (today Fleischmarkt 7, 1010 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore). He died in this house on 14 December 1803 and was buried a few days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Jovan Veljović (1755-1803), a Serbian merchant from Vidin, at the age of 48 on 14 December 1803. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Stanišić Aleksandar (1849-1899)
entity_description: Aleksandar Stanišić (1849-1899) was a Viennese merchant of Serbian origin. In 1869 he published an advertising in "Zastava", in which he appears as "Wäschwar-Fabrikant" with his store in Wollzeile 9 (1010 Vienna). He died in his apartment in Leonhardgasse 22 (1030 Vienna) on 4 April 1899.
picture_description:
Zastava, 14.12.1869.

Property of the Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske.
location_description: Here the Serbian merchant Aleksandar Stanišić (1849-1899) had his store ("Wäschwar-Fabrikant") since 1869.

name: Žefarović Georgije (1722-1752)
entity_description: Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752) was a Serbian painter, engraver and coppersmith. He was the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), who had appointed him as his successor. Georgije Žefarović came on his invitation to Vienna in 1740s and begun his studies at the Viennese Academy of Fine Arts on 5 October 1744. Some authors are pointing out that Georgije Žefarović was the first Serbian educated painter. Only three of his coppersmith works are known, which were all made in Vienna. Georgije Žefarović died in Vienna a the age of 30 in Salzgries 9 (1010 Vienna) on 24 December 1752.
location_description: Here died Georgije Žefarović (1722-1752), a Serbian painter and coppersmith, the nephew of Hristofor Žefarović (1690-1753), on 24 December 1752. The original building does not exist anymore.

name: Putnik Mojsije (1728-1790)
entity_description: Mojsije Putnik (1728-1790) was Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia) from 1782 to his death in 1790. He had the title of Privy Councillor ("Geheimrat") and was also awarded the Order of Saint Stephen. He died in Kohlmarkt 144 (today Kohlmarkt 8, 1010 Vienna, the original building does not exist anymore) on 9 July 1790.
location_name: Place of Death of Mojsije Putnik
location_description: Here died Mojsije Putnik (1728-1790), Metropolitan of Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia), on 9 July 1790. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Julinac Pavle (1737-1785)
entity_description: Pavle Julinac (1737-1785) was a historian, translator and one of the first novel writers among the Serbs. He was born in Szeged (today Hungary) in 1737. Following his studies in Bratislava (today Slovakia), he moved to the Russian Empire in 1753, where he joined the diplomatic service. From 1781 Pavle Julinac was Russian consul in Naples. He was the author of the first printed history of the Serbs entitled "Kratkoje v'vedenije v istoriju proishoždenija slaveno-serbskago naroda" ("A Short Introduction to the History of the Slavo-Serbian People"), which was published in Venice in the year 1765. This history was written under the influence of his Professor from Bratislava Ján Tomka-Sásky (1692-1762). In 1776 Julinac's translation of Jean-François Marmontel's "Bélisaire" became one of the most prominent works of Enlightenment in the Serbian literature. Pavle Julinac published in Vienna, where he died as Russian diplomat on 25 February 1785. He died in house Wollzeile 9 and was buried next day in St. Marx cemetery.
location_description: Here died Pavle Julinac (1737-1785), a historian, translator and one of the first novel writers among the Serbs, on 25 February 1785. The current building does not date to the 18th, but to the 19th century.

name: Milanković Uroš (1800-1849)
entity_description: Uroš Milanković (1800-1849) was born in Dalj (today Croatia) in 1800. He was the brother of Milutin Milanković's grandfather. Uroš Milanković studied Philosophy in Szeged (today Hungary) and later he studied Law at the University of Vienna. He worked for the duration of one year as a lawyer at the court in Vienna and later as a lawyer in the Military Frontier. He published several books in German and Serbian in Vienna, e.g. "Weltorganismus und System des gesammten Lebens: dargestellt in einzelnen Geschöpfen und in einzelnen Wirkungen, als allgemeine Thätigkeit der gesammten nichtsinnlichen, sinnlichen und geistigen Natur, in ihrem Zusammenhange mit der Kritik der Einheit über das Unvereinbare" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1843), "Organismus des Weltalls und System des gesammten Lebens, oder Polarsystem der physischen und geistigen Natur" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1845) and "Просвјета човека" (in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery 1847). After his retirement in 1835 he lived in Trieste and Vienna. Uroš Milanković died in Vienna in Stiegengasse 12 (1060 Vienna) on 27 December 1849 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description:
Property of Digitalna Biblioteka Matice Srpske

http://digital.bms.rs/ebiblioteka/publications/view/3359
location_description: Uroš Milanković died here on 27 December 1849 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). The building does not exist anymore.

name: Teodorović Vasa (1851-1919)
entity_description:
Vasa Teodorović (1851-1919) was born in Stari Sivac (today Serbia) on 24 April 1851. He was an engineer, inventor, merchant and the President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna from 1907 to 1913. Since 1 July 1889 he and Max Mylius had the joint Company "Theodorović & Cie" (Stephansplatz 7, 1010 Vienna). Vasa Teodorović was the owner of several patents. Amongst others he patented and produced, together with the industrialist Georg Roth (1834-1903), the Roth-Theodorovic pistol in 1895. It was a long-recoil, locked-breech, single or double-action semi-automatic pistol.
Vasa Teodorović married Anna Wilhelmine Hlouvitschka on 4 November 1880. They had two sons, Teodor (1893) and Milan (1887), and a daughter Olga (1888). Vasa Teodorović died in Mariahilferstraße 27 (1060 Vienna) on 15 March 1919 and was buried two days later in the Viennese Central Cemetery (Wiener Zentralfriedhof, 1110 Vienna).
location_description: Here died Vasa Teodorović (1851-1919), an engineer, inventor, merchant and the President of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community Council of St. Sava in Vienna, on 15 March 1919.

name: Preradović Petar von (1818-1872)
entity_description: Petar von Preradović (1818-1872) was born in Grabovnica (Military Frontier, today Croatia) on 19 March 1818 in the Orthodox Serbian family of Jovan and Pelagija Preradović and was baptised in the Serbian Orthodox Church in Mala Trešnjevica (Military Frontier, today Croatia) three days later. Next to this church were buried Preradović's parents. However, Petar von Preradović himself converted later to Roman Catholicism and declared himself as a Croat. Therefore, we still encounter an ongoing discussion in Serbian and Croatian historiography on his identity. Petar von Preradović started his military education at the Theresian Military Academy ("Theresianische Militärakademie") in Wiener Neustadt from 1830 to 1838. He was ennobled in 1864 and was promoted to Major General in 1866. Petar von Preradović was also a poet, who was very popular at this time. He married twice: Pauline de Ponte (died on 4 May 1855) on 11 October 1848 and Emma Regen von Bleyleben on 17 April 1865. His granddaughter was Paula Preradović Molden (1887-1951), also poet and writer, and author of the text of the Austrian National Anthem ("Land der Berge"). Petar von Preradović lived in Ungargasse 39 (1030 Vienna) from 1870 to 1872. The Yugoslav Academy of Sciences and Arts (Jugoslavenska akademija znanosti i umjetnosti / JAZU) in Zagreb put on the front of the building in Ungargasse a commemorative plaque for Petar von Preradović in 1968. Petar von Preradović died in Fahrafeld (today Austria) on 18 August 1872 in the house Nr. 17 (today Hainfelderstraße 66). He was buried three days later in the Viennese Matzleinsdorfer Cemetery (today Waldmüllerpark, 1100 Vienna). After the closing of this cemetery in 1874 Preradović's remains were transferred to Zagreb to the Mirogoj Cemetery in 1879.
location_description: Petar von Preradović (1818-1872), Austrian officer and poet, lived here from 1870 to 1872. The Yugoslav Academy of Sciences and Arts (Jugoslavenska akademija znanosti i umjetnosti / JAZU) in Zagreb put on the front of the building in Ungargasse a commemorative plaque for Petar von Preradović in 1968.

name: Romanić Bogdan (1852-1924)
entity_description: Bogdan Romanić (1852-1924) was a Major General in the Austro-Hungarian Army. He was of Serbian origin and was born in Mali Gradac (Military Frontier, today Croatia) on 11 January 1852. He studied at the k.u.k. Technische Militärakademie in Vienna from 1869 to 1871. Bogdan Romanić retired in 1905 and received the title of Major General in 1907. He was an active member of the Serbian Orthodox Church Community of St. Sava in Vienna. Bogdan Romanić died in Dubrovnik (today Croatia) on 12 January 1924.
location_description: Here lived Bogdan Romanić (1852-1924), a Major General in the Austro-Hungarian Army, between 1905 and 1910.

name: Ostojić Tihomir (1865-1921)
entity_description: Tihomir Ostojić (1865-1921), a Serbian scholar in Literary Studies and Professor at University, was born in Potiski Sveti Nikola(today Ostojićevo, Serbia). After attending grammar school in Novi Sad, he studied Philosophy at the University of Budapest. In the years 1888 and 1889 he studied for two semesters Philology at the University of Vienna as a scholarship holder of the Serbian Church-People's Assembly in Sremski Karlovci (today Serbia). Tihomir Ostojić was an active member of many Serbian organisations in Novi Sad, where he worked as a teacher of Philosophy and the Serbian, German and Hungarian languages in grammar schools from 1889 to 1911. Later he was secretary of the Matica Srpska in Novi Sad. Tihomir Ostojić received his title of Dr at the University of Vienna on 16 July 1907, where he wrote a dissertation entitled "Dositheus Obradovic's Klosterjahre". In 1920 he was elected Professor and Dean of the newly established University of Skoplje. Tihomir Ostojić fulfilled this position only for a short time and already in 1921 he mved to Vienna because of an illness, where he died on 18 October 1921. Tihomir Ostojić was a corresponding member of the Serbian Royal Academy since 1910. In 1947 his place of birth was renamed Ostojićevo in his honor.
location_description: Her lived Tihomir Ostojić, a Serbian scholar in Literary Studies and Professor at University, during his studies at the University of Vienna in the years 1888 and 1889. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Tekelija von Kevermes Petar (1784-1844)
entity_description: Petar Tekelija (1784-1844) was a nephew of Sava Tekelija (1761-1842), one of the most educated Serbs and famous benefactor, who bequeathed his entire property to the cultural and educational enlightenment of the Serbian people. Petar Tekelija was born in Kevermes (today Hungary) in 1784 as a son of Petar, Sava Tekelija's brother. Petar Tekelija had a brother Djordje and three sisters. Like his uncle Sava Tekelija, he was a great Serbian patriot and visited Serbia during the First Serbian Uprising in 1812. Before that he travelled, together with his uncle, to their cousins in the Russian Empire. Petar Tekelija was high ranking official in the Austrian Empire. He had the title of a Hungarian Court Councillor ("königl. ungarischer Rat") and was the head ("comes") of the Csanád County (today divided between Hungary and Romania). He married Marija Tekelija von Kevermes (1821-1870). After his father's death in 1820 he inherited great landed property. Petar Tekelija was also Knight of the Golden Spur ("Ritter vom goldenen Sporn"), which is a Papal Order of Knighthood. He died in Vienna in the house Leopoldstadt 522 (Praterstraße 9, 1020 Vienna) on 31 July 1844 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). Petar Tekelija was the last male descendant of the noble family Tekelija.
picture_description: Csergheö de N.-Tacskand, Wappenbuch des Adels von Ungarn sammt den Nebenländern der St. Stephans-Krone (Nürnberg 1885-87), Tafel 468.
location_description: Here died Petar Tekelija (1784-1844), a nobleman, landowner and the head ("comes") of the Csanád County, on 31 July 1844. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Tekelija von Kevermes Tereza (1809-1873)
entity_description: Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes (1809-1873) was born in the Serbian noble family Kojić von Fereghyhaz in Timișoara (today Romania) in 1809. She married Djordje Tekelija, the brother of Petar Tekelija (1784-1844) and nephew of Sava Tekelija (1761-1842), in 1825, with whom she had a daughter. Djordje Tekelija died two years later. Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes died in Kärntner Straße 17 (1010 Vienna) on 26 October 1873 and was buried two days later in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna).
picture_description: Csergheö de N.-Tacskand, Wappenbuch des Adels von Ungarn sammt den Nebenländern der St. Stephans-Krone (Nürnberg 1885-87), Tafel 468.
location_name: Apartment of Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes
location_description: Here died Tereza Tekelija von Kevermes (1809-1873), the widow of Djordje Tekelija, on 26 October 1873. The building does not exist anymore.

name: Živanović Dušan (1853-1937)
entity_description: Dušan Živanović (1853-1937) was a Serbian architect, who was born in Senta (today Serbia). He studied Architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna ("Akademie der bildenden Künste") from 1871 to 1873 as a student of the famous Professor Teophil von Hansen (1813-1891). During his studies he lived in Theresianumgasse 13 (1040 Vienna) from 1871 to 1872. Dušan Živanović worked later as an architect in the Ministry of Infrastructure of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes in Belgrade. He designed many public buildings and Orthodox churches, among which the most important is the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity in Banja Luka (today Republic of Srpska, Bosnia and Hercegovina) from 1925 to 1929.
location_description: Here lived Dušan Živanović (1853-1937), Serbian architect and student of the famous Professor Teophil von Hansen (1813-1891), during his studies in Vienna from 1871 to 1872.

name: Karadžić Wilhelmine-Mina (1828-1894)
entity_description:
Wilhelmine-Mina Vukomanović (né Karadžić, 1828-1894) was a Serbian painter and a daughter of Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864). She was born in Landstraße 291 (today 66, 1030 Vienna) on 12 July 1828 and was baptised in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54-56, 1030 Vienna). Her godfather was Theodor Demeter Tirka (1764-1839), a Greek merchant and banker from Vienna, her father’s benefactor and private banker of the Obrenović Dynasty.
Mina was a secretary to her father and accompanied him on his journeys. She was very active in Vienna's social events and is described as a very educated and beautiful girl, who maintained contacts with numerous writers and artists. She spoke with her mother in German and with her father in Serbian. In addition to her bilingualism, she also learned Italian, French and English. She played piano and painted (over 50 paintings are preserved). In addition to the translation of Vuk's poems into German, which Jacob Grimm (1785-1863) praised, Mina also worked on the translation of the work of the publisher Ludwig August Frankl Ritter von Hochwart (1810-1894) entitled "Gusle, der Freund des Hauses" (Vienna 1852). Mina wrote to her brother Dimitrije in 1848 that she goes to Belvedere park and paints there five to six hours a day and three times a week. In 1858 she married Professor Aleksa Vukomanović (1826-1859) from Belgrade and converted to Orthodoxy. After his death in 1859 she moved to Vienna with their son Janko. In Vienna Mina looked after her parents. Vuk died in 1864 and Anna on 11 August 1876 in Beatrixgasse 16a (1030 Vienna). Mina died in the same house on 12 June 1894.
location_description: The fourth Slavic Ball took place in the Sofiensäle on 27 January 1847. The music was performed by Johann Strauss Senior (1804-1849) and his orchestra. Among the 2,000 guests were the Prince-Bishop Petar II Petrović Njegoš of Montenegro (1813-1851), Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) and his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina Karadžić (1828-1894).

name: Karadžić Stefanović Vuk (1787-1864)
entity_description:
Vuk Stefanović Karadžić (1787-1864) was a Serbian philologist and linguist and greatest reformer of the Serbian language. He became also well known for his collection of Serbian folk songs, fairy tailes and riddles. Vuk Stefanović Karadžić lived and worked in Vienna for more than 50 years. He moved there in 1813 after the end of the First Serbian Uprising (1804-1813) against the Ottoman Empire. In Vienna Vuk Stefanović Karadžić met Jernej Kopitar (1780-1844), a Slovenian philologist and censor at the Imperial Library, who encouraged Vuk in his collection of folk material. Vuk met Dimitrije Davidović, Dimitrije Frušić and Sava Mrkalj in Pest and stayed in contact with them also in Vienna. Vuk printed his first book entitled "Pesnarica" (a collection of Serbian folk songs) in Vienna in the Schnierer publishing house in 1,500 copies. In the same year Vuk printed the book "Pismenica"  ("Pismenica serbskoga jezika"), the first grammar of the reformed Serbian language. Vuk published a new edition in 1818, which was translated by the famous German philologist Jacob Grimm (1785-1863) into the German language in 1824 (entitled "Kleine serbische Grammatik"). Grimm was impressed by the Serbian cultural heritage in the form of folk poems and songs. Vuk met Jacob Grimm in 1823 and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832) in his house in Weimar in 1824. Goethe was interested in Serbian folk poetry since the year 1778, when he translated "Hasanaginica", a South Slavic folk ballad. From 1823 to 1827 Goethe translated folk songs from Vuk's books in the journal "Über Kunst und Alterthum", the first one was "Dioba Jakšića" ("Erbschaftsteilung"). Apart from Goethe and Grimm Vuk's folk songs were translated into Czech ("Prostonárodní srbská muza, do Cech převedená", 1817), English ("Servian popular poetry", 1827), Swedish ("Serbiska folksänger", 1830), Hungarian ("Szerb népdalok hősregék", 1836) and into Polish ("Narodowe piesni serbskie", 1853). Kopitar introduced Vuk to Leopold von Ranke (1795-1886), one of the greatest German historians, in 1827. On the basis of Vuk's knowledge of the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire, Ranke published his book on the "Serbian revolution" in 1828.
Vuk's Serbian-German Dictionary, printed in 1818 in the publishing house of the Armenian Mechitarist Monastery (Mechitaristengasse 4, 1070 Vienna), was the first book ever printed in the newly reformed Serbian language. Vuk standardised the Serbian Cyrillic alphabet based on the phonemic principle of Johann Christoph Adellung (1732-1806), a great German philologist. His motto was: "Write as you speak, and read as it is written". This book was printed from donations, firstly by Theodor Demeter Tirka (1764-1839), a Greek merchant and banker from Vienna, who was also godfather of Vuk's children.
Vuk married Anna Kraus (1788-1876) in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rochus (Landstraßer Hauptstraße 54-56, 1030 Vienna) on 28 January 1818. His best man was Jernej Kopitar. Vuk's first rented apartment was that of Anna's father, where they met. During his life in Vienna Vuk changed address more than 20 times. The couple had 12 children, but only two of them overlived Vuk: his daughter Wilhelmine-Mina (1828-1894) and his son Dimitrije (1836-1883).
Vuk was very active in the social life among the Viennese Serbs. He was a friend of Prince Miloš Obrenović and Prince Mihailo Obrenović, Petar Petrović Njegoš, Djura Daničić, Branko Radičević, Anastas Jovanović, etc. Vuk was also very reputable among all Slavs, his friends and associates were the Russian priest Michail Fjodorowitsch Rajewski (1811-1844), Jernej Kopitar, Josef Dobrovský (1753-1829), František Palacký (1798-1876), Pavel Jozef Šafárik (1795-1861), Franz Xaver Ritter von Miklosich (1813-1891), etc. Vuk was often guest in the so-called "Slavonic Café" (also "Café Gerlovich"), also "Zum Weissen Wolfen" (Fleischmarkt 20/Wolfengasse 3, 1010 Vienna), and other places where the Slavs gathered in Vienna.
In 1823 Vuk became honorary Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Jena. In 1826 Vuk received a Russian and in 1835 a Serbian pension. He was very reputable in the Russian Empire. Apart from the pension the Russian Emperor Nikolaj I Pavlovič (1796-1855) honored him with the Gold medal in 1841 and in 1862 he was awarded with the Order of St. Anna 2nd class with crown. Vuk became a corresponding member of the Imperial Academy of Sciences in Vienna on 14 January 1848. Three days before he had received a ring with brilliants as a gift of the Austrian Emperor Ferdinand I (1793-1875), who thanked him for his book of Serbian folk songs entitled "Srpske Narodne pjesme". In 1850 the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I (1830-1916) honored Vuk with the Knight's Cross of the Franz Josef Order 3rd class and in 1851 with the Gold Medal for Science. Vuk was also awarded the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle 3rd class in 1852.
Vuk died in his appartment, where he spent his last 15 years of life, in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) on 7 February 1864. After the memorial service in the Greek Orthodox Church of St. George in Griechengasse 5 (1010 Vienna) he was buried in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery (1030 Vienna). His mortal remains were transferred to Belgrade in 1897, while the tombstone still stands in the Orthodox part of the St. Marx Cemetery. On the house in Marokkanergasse 3 (1030 Vienna) a memorial plaque was placed in the 1950s, and Vuk’s monument was erected in Rasumofskygasse 22 (1030 Vienna) in 1987.
location_description: In front of the house Rasumofskygasse 20-24 a monument for Vuk Stefanović Karadžić was erected in 1989 as a donation of the City of Belgrade.
